A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n As of 28 Mar 2017, a cumulative total of 26 suspected cases including 4 deaths (case fatality rate of 15 percent) has been reported since onset of the outbreak on 21 Jan 2017. During reporting week 13 (week ending 31 Mar 2017), 6 new cases were reported from 3 districts, distributed equally (2 cases each) among Betou, Dongou and Impfondo. As noted in previous ProMED-mail posts, the monkeypox virus clade in the Congo Basin causes more severe disease in humans, with a case fatality rate of 11-17 percent, than the clade in Ghana, which causes few fatalities. Occurrence of sporadic cases is not surprising because monkeypox virus is endemic in the Republic of the Congo, the DR Congo, and human cases occur sporadically there as well in the Central African Republic. \n\nPeople at risk for monkeypox are those who get bitten by an infected animal or who have contact with the animal's rash, blood or body fluids. \n\nRodents such as rope squirrels, door mice and pouched rats are the suspected reservoir hosts, with monkeys and humans as secondary, spill-over hosts. According to the CDC, the symptoms of monkeypox are as follows: About 12 days after people are infected with the virus, they will get a fever, headache, muscle aches, and backache; their lymph nodes will swell; and they will feel tired. In addition, the high population movement between Congo, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Central African Republic, including influx of refugees from these countries and others like Chad, poses a high risk of propagation of the outbreak to other provinces of Congo and the neighboring countries.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-01-21 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Likouala province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Betou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Enyelle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the DR Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Likouala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4903754", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Monkeypox - The virus is seldom transmitted directly from one person to another, but there is a documented instance of that in the Republic of the Congo. Monkeys are not the reservoirs of the virus, despite the name that the virus has received. Although not determined, the main reservoirs of monkeypox are suspected to be rodents, including rope squirrels (_Funisciurus_ sp; an arboreal rodent) and terrestrial rodents in the genera _Cricetomys_ and _Graphiurus_. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/166.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Monkeypox virus is endemic in the Republic of the Congo, and human cases occur sporadically there as well in DR Congo and the Central African Republic. \n\nFaced with this epidemic, the government has officially declared monkey pox as an epidemic in Congo to avoid any risk of it spreading and calls on its financial partners to help tackle the disease. The index case was a hunter who fell ill on 17 Aug [2016] and died in his village without specimens being collected for laboratory testing. Between 4 Sep and 7 Oct [2016], 26 cases have been admitted and of these, 3 have been laboratory confirmed for monkeypox. Epidemiological investigations are currently on-going to evaluate the magnitude of the outbreak.\n\nPublic health response:\n- strengthening public health surveillance for possible cases;\n- training healthcare workers on using personal protective equipment, and advocating proper hand hygiene and cleaning procedures in the health care setting;\n- installing 2 isolation units for case management;\n- provision of free care for patients affected with monkeypox;\n- increasing public awareness to take precautionary measure to prevent monkeypox transmission;\n- engaging International Medical Corps and the Catholic Organisation for Relief and Development Aid (CORDAID) to support case management and prevention measures.\n\nWHO risk assessment\nSmall scale monkeypox outbreaks regularly occur in tropical Africa. Monkeypox is usually transmitted to humans through contact with an infected animal or through infected animal bites. Person-to-person transmission can also occur during outbreaks through close contact with patients but there is no evidence to date that person-to-person transmission alone can sustain monkeypox transmission in humans.\n\nGiven the lack of adequately equipped isolation units in healthcare facilities in the area and the known transmission dynamics of monkeypox between humans, WHO encourages individuals and healthcare workers to follow infection prevention and control procedures when caring for patients, to prevent transmission of disease.\n\nGiven the location of the outbreak in a relatively remote and sparsely populated area at this stage the risk of international spread seems limited.\n\nWHO does not recommend any restriction for travel and trade to Central African Republic based on available information at this point in time.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[A previous ProMED-mail report on 28 Sep 2016 indicated that there were human monkeypox cases in both Basse-Kotto and Haute-Kotto health districts. The above WHO report only mentions the Haute-Kotto district. The number of cases continues to increase.\n\nMonkeypox cases are reported sporadically in the Central African Republic (CAR). This is a summary of the 2nd reported outbreak this year (2016). There have been human cases of monkeypox virus infection reported previously in the CAR. As noted in the comment in a previous ProMED-mail post (archive no. 20160119.3947756), Dr Mirdad Kazanji, director of the Institut Pasteur at Bangui, indicated that the phylogenetic tree showed that a 2010 monkeypox isolate was identical to the Democratic Republic of the Congo strain circulating in central Africa. This reported strain was identical to one associated with an outbreak of monkeypox in 2001 in a Bantu family living on the border between the CAR and the DRC, 480 km (about 300 miles) from the 2010 cases.\n\nIt would be of interest to know to which clade the current monkeypox virus belongs, and which wild animals are the reservoirs in the Central African Republic. Given the human fatalities, one would assume that the monkeypox virus responsible in the current outbreak is the Central African one that occurs in the DR Congo.\n\nThe virus is seldom transmitted directly from one person to another, but there is a documented instance in the Republic of the Congo. Monkeys are not the reservoirs of the virus, despite the name that the virus has received. Further deaths have been reported from other villages in Haute-Kotto, the country's largest province.\n\nPreparations are being made for a rapid intervention team to be sent to the area to help those affected cope with the monkeypox outbreak, Tenguere added.\n\nThe 1st symptoms of monkeypox are aches, pains and a fever. A bumpy localised rash then appears on any part of the skin. This lesion gradually falls off. [See http://www.cdc.gov/poxvirus/monkeypox/symptoms.html for photographs of human cases. - Mod.TY]\n\nThe highly contagious disease usually strikes in remote rural areas surrounded by rainforests although the chances of catching it are very slim, according to experts.\n\nAs well as monkeys, African squirrels are among the main carriers of this lethal virus, which was 1st discovered by scientists in the Democratic Republic of Congo in 1970.\n\nSome fatal cases of the disease were detected in neighbouring DR Congo several months ago.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Apparently, the current monkeypox outbreak is not limited to the Basse-Kotto prefecture, but cases are occurring in the Haute-Kotto prefecture as well, although a case number is not given. The number of cases in Basse-Kotto prefecture is increasing. There were 14 cases with one fatality reported on 23 Sep 2016, and just 5 days later, on 28 Sep 2016, there are 19 cases and at least 10 deaths reported above. That appears to be an unusual high number of deaths. The USA CDC states that the case fatality rate is around 10 percent (http://www.cdc.gov/poxvirus/monkeypox/symptoms.html), suggesting that there is significant underreporting of total cases.\n\nMonkeypox cases are reported sporadically in the Central African Republic (CAR). This is the 2nd reported outbreak this year (2016). There have been human cases of monkeypox virus infection reported previously in the CAR. As noted in the comment in the previous ProMED-mail post (archive no. 20160119.3947756), Dr Mirdad Kazanji, director of the Institut Pasteur at Bangui, reported that in June 2010, 2 boys aged 14 and 15 years were found to have diffuse maculopapular lesions associated with pustules and crusts (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20111129.3488). Dr Kazanji indicated that the phylogenetic tree showed that the 2010 virus strain was identical to the Democratic Republic of the Congo strain circulating in central Africa. This reported strain was identical to one associated with an outbreak of monkeypox in 2001 in a Bantu family living on the border between the CAR and the DRC, 480 km (about 300 miles) from the 2010 cases.\n\nIt would be of interest to know to which clade the current monkeypox virus belongs, and which wild animals are the reservoirs in the Central African Republic. Given the human fatalities, one would assume that the monkeypox virus responsible in the current outbreak is the Central African one that occurs in the DR Congo.\n\nThe virus is seldom transmitted directly from one person to another, but there is a documented instance in the Republic of the Congo. Monkeys are not the reservoirs of the virus, despite the name that the virus has received. (Hominidae) / 0.33 / 0.33 / 100 / 0.33\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Within the framework of wild diseases surveillance, the Cameroon network of Animal diseases epidemio-surveillance (RESCAM), Ministry of Livestock, Fisheries and Animal industries, was informed about the mortality of a chimpanzee from the Mefou Primate Sanctuary, on 16 Aug [2016]. Following epidemiological investigation and sampling, the Research center for Armies health (CRESAR) performed analyses and confirmed the presence of simian orthopoxvirus, which is the causal agent responsible for a zoonotic disease known as Monkeypox. Poxvirus Congo basin strain was identified. The group of 22 chimpanzees (1 sick plus 1 dead) used to live in a 3-hectares enclosure isolated from the other compartments of the sanctuary (18 enclosures). Clinical signs were: lack of appetite and progressive occurrence of nodules and blisters on the face. The sanctuary is populated with chimpanzees, gorillas and monkeys (300 in total) over about 900 hectares. It is compartmentalized and fenced. Animals were introduced within the sanctuary. Quarantine was applied (sick animals kept inside the enclosure) and biosecurity measures are reinforced for the staff working within the enclosure. Epidemiological investigation is continuing and active surveillance of rodents and the environment is being performed within the sanctuary.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestations; quarantine; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nArmy Health Research Center (CRESAR) (national laboratory) / Common chimpanzee / gene sequencing / - / Pending\nArmy Health Research Center (CRESAR) (national laboratory) / Common chimpanzee / real-time PCR / 17 Aug 2016 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sporadic human cases of monkeypox occur in Cameroon. The monkeypox virus clade in the Congo Basin causes more severe disease in humans, with a case fatality rate of 11-17 percent.\n\nBecause human-to-human transmission appears to be limited, most monkeypox cases are closely associated with spillover transmission from animal reservoirs. The main reservoirs of monkeypox are believed to be rope squirrels (_Funisciurus_ spp.; an arboreal rodent), which were implicated in monkeypox outbreaks elsewhere in the DRC in the 1980s, or terrestrial rodents in the genera _Cricetomys_ and _Graphiurus_. - CopyEd.LMI, edited]\nhttp://www.journaldebangui.com/article.php?aid=9242\n\n\nMonkeypox virus: outbreak reported in Mbomou (Central African Republic)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nThe public health minister confirmed the news on Thu 14 Jan 2016, during a press conference. A monkeypox virus outbreak has struck the region.\n\nInformation about the disease in Mbomou has been circulating the past few days, where 2 deaths were recorded and several patients were put in quarantine. The Ministry of Health confirmed the outbreak. Ms Marguerite Maliavo Samba said that tests and investigations carried out by her department confirmed the disease in Mbomou. The government official gave details on disease patterns of contamination, saying 'there are 2 modes of transmission of this disease. The 1st mode is transmission of contaminated living or dead animals to humans. The 2nd mode is from a sick or dead person to another healthy person in close contact with body fluids including blood, urine, vomit, sweat, semen, or by handling objects contaminated by secretions.' [This is extremely rare. - Mod.TY]\n\nThe disease was detected for the 1st time in humans in 1970 in the Democratic Republic of Congo. This is the 3rd time it has occurred in the Central African Republic. The 1st time was in Mbomou in 2001, and the 2nd time in Haute Kotto in 2014.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There have been human cases of monkeypox virus infection previously in the Central African Republic (CAR). Dr Mirdad Kazanji director of the Institut Pasteur at Bangui, reported that in June 2010, 2 boys aged 14 and 15 years were found to have diffuse maculopapular lesions associated with pustules and crusts (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20111129.3488). They had been living in a settlement in the deep forest area of the southern CAR. The cases were reported to the Institut Pasteur at Bangui. The lesions developed after the boys had hunted and eaten a wild rodent (bemba). They both presented to a health centre one week after eruption of the extensive lesions, which covered the face, torso, and limbs. Both boys were systemically well, with no fever or notable lymphadenopathy.\n\nDr Kazanji indicated that the phylogenetic tree showed that the 2010 strain was identical to the Democratic Republic of the Congo strain circulating in central Africa. This reported strain was identical to one associated with an outbreak of monkeypox in 2001 in a Bantu family living on the border between the CAR and the DRC, 480 km [about 300 miles] from the 2010 cases.\n\nIt would be of interest to know to which clade the current monkeypox virus belongs, and which wild animals are the reservoirs in the Central African Republic.\n\nThe USA's Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and their cooperators have been conducting field and laboratory studies to determine which rodent species are reservoirs of the virus. The virus is seldom transmitted directly from one person to another, but there is a documented instance in the Republic of the Congo. Monkeys are not the reservoirs of the virus, despite the name that the virus has received. Although not determined, the main reservoirs of monkeypox are suspected to be rodents, including rope squirrels (_Funisciurus_ sp.; an arboreal rodent), and terrestrial rodents in the genera _Cricetomys_ and _Graphiurus_.\n\nMaps of the Central African Republic can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/cen_african_rep_pol01.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34458. - Mod.TY]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< LMI, edited]\nhttp://www.journaldebangui.com/article.php?aid=9242\n\n\nMonkeypox virus: outbreak reported in Mbomou (Central African Republic)\n This reported strain was identical to one associated with an outbreak of monkeypox in 2001 in a Bantu family living on the border between the CAR and the DRC, 480 km [about 300 miles] from the 2010 cases. \n\nIt would be of interest to know to which clade the current monkeypox virus belongs, and which wild animals are the reservoirs in the Central African Republic. \n\nThe USA's Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and their cooperators have been conducting field and laboratory studies to determine which rodent species are reservoirs of the virus. Congo DR (02): (BU)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4014697", "date": "2016-02-12 14:43:11", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX - CONGO DR (02): (BAS-UELE)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 10 Feb 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/monkeypox-outbreak-dozens-of-cases-reported-in-bas-uele-district-drc-25667/\n\n\nHealth officials in Bas-Uele [province], [formerly a district of] Orientale province of northern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) are reporting a monkeypox outbreak, which has affected more than 50 and killed 2, according to a Radio Okapi report today [10 Feb 2016] ([in French], computer translated).\n\nDr Innocent Akonda said that 51 cases were reported during the 1st week of February [2016], with cases reported in the Bombongolo health area, Aboso, and other health areas. With the new cases, the health zone recorded 195 cases including 8 deaths, said Akonda.\n\nThe battle against the outbreak is especially problematic due to lack of qualified medical personnel, equipment, collection kits, and lack of sanitation. 'We only have one qualified nurse in Bombongolo. When he moves, it is the orderlies who care for the sick. Healers also monopolize the sick to offer them miracle healings, ' added Dr Innocent Akonda.\n\nMonkeypox is a relatively rare virus found primarily in central and western Africa. The disease is caused by monkeypox virus. It is closely related to the smallpox virus (variola), the virus used in the smallpox vaccine (vaccinia), and the cowpox virus. Infection with monkeypox is not as serious as its cousin, smallpox; however, human deaths have been attributed to monkeypox.\n\nAccording to the CDC, the symptoms of monkeypox are as follows:\n- About 12 days after people are infected with the virus, they will get a fever, headache, muscle aches, and backache; their lymph nodes will swell; and they will feel tired.\n- 1 to 3 days (or longer) after the fever starts, they will get a rash. This rash develops into raised bumps filled with fluid and often starts on the face and spreads, but it can start on other parts of the body too.\n- The bumps go through several stages before they get crusty, scab over, and fall off.\nThe illness usually lasts for 2 to 4 weeks.\n\nRodents, such as rope squirrels, door mice, and pouched rats, are the suspected reservoir hosts, with monkeys and humans as secondary, spill-over hosts. The monkeypox virus in the Congo has a higher case fatality rate than the virus in West Africa, where fatal cases are rare or absent, according to a ProMED moderator [Monkeypox, human - Congo DR: susp. 20120917.1297716].\n\nPeople at risk for monkeypox are those who get bitten by an infected animal or if you have contact with the animal's rash, blood, or body fluids. It can also be transmitted person to person through respiratory or direct contact and contact with contaminated bedding or clothing [this is extremely rare. - Mod.TY]. There is no specific treatment for monkeypox.\n\nA 2010 study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences [http://www.pnas.org/content/107/37/16262.full], says that since the last doses of smallpox vaccine were given in 1980 and smallpox was officially eradicated, cases of monkeypox have increased 20-fold according to the study.\n\nMuch of this is likely due to the immunity that smallpox vaccine granted to related viruses like monkeypox. Most of the patients infected with monkeypox were born after the discontinuation of smallpox vaccination.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report does not indicate if these 51 cases were laboratory confirmed. This area in the DRC is endemic for monkeypox virus, and sporadic human cases occur in this region.\n\nThe monkeypox virus clade in the Congo Basin causes more severe disease in humans, with a case fatality rate of 11-17 percent, than the clade in Ghana, which causes few fatalities. It was this latter clade that was introduced into the USA with the importation of African rodents in the pet trade, with resulting human cases in several states and no fatalities.\n\nMaps of the Democratic Republic of Congo can be seen at https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/monkey-cage/files/2015/06/Decentralized-provinces-of-the-DRC-CDRC_DG002_122.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/33637. Bas-Uele, in northern DRC had a population of approximately 900 000 in 2007 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bas-Uele_District). - Mod.TY]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The monkeypox virus in the Congo has a higher case fatality rate than the virus in West Africa, where fatal cases are rare or absent, according to a ProMED moderator [Monkeypox, human - Congo DR: susp. Date: Fri 23 Sep 2016\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "smallpox", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-12-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-06-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mingala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mbomou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3643887", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Monkeypox, human - Congo DR: susp. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3643887", "date": "2015-09-14 09:44:21", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX, HUMAN - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO: SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Sep 2015\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/suspected-monkeypox-outbreak-reported-in-drc-18451/\n\n\nAt least 20 suspected monkeypox cases have been reported since the beginning of the week in Tshuapa district, Democratic Republic of the Congo, according to a Radio Okapi report.\n\nSources say that 18 of the suspected cases are hospitalized at a hospital in the town of Ikela. Despite not being laboratory confirmed, the Chief Health officer in the Mbamba health area, Dr. Jean-Pierre Inonga, said they are calling the cases monkeypox based on several telltale symptoms presented: fever, scabs and generalized skin rash.\n\nConfirmation testing is being performed at the National Institute of Biomedical Research (INRB) in Kinshasa as of this writing. The resurgence of the viral disease is believed to be due to consumption of game animals found dead in the forest by the public.\n\nMonkeypox is a relatively rare disease caused by the virus with the same name, which is found primarily in central and western Africa. It is closely related to the smallpox virus (variola), the virus used in the smallpox vaccine (vaccinia), and the cowpox virus. Infection with monkeypox is not as serious as its cousin, smallpox; however, human deaths have been attributed to monkeypox.\n\nAccording to the CDC, the symptoms of monkeypox are as follows: About 12 days after people are infected with the virus, they will get a fever, headache, muscle aches, and backache; their lymph nodes will swell; and they will feel tired. One to 3 days (or longer) after the fever starts, they will get a rash. This rash develops into raised bumps filled with fluid and often starts on the face and spreads, but it can start on other parts of the body too. The bumps go through several stages before they get crusty, scab over, and fall off. The illness usually lasts for 2 to 4 weeks.\n\nRodents, such as rope squirrels, door mice and pouched rats, are the suspected reservoir hosts, with monkeys and humans as secondary, spill-over hosts.\n\nPeople at risk for monkeypox are those who get bitten by an infected animal or who have contact with the animal's rash, blood or body fluids. It can also be transmitted person-to-person through respiratory or direct contact and contact with contaminated bedding or clothing.\n\nThere is no specific treatment for monkeypox.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This area in the DRC is endemic for monkeypox virus, and sporadic human cases occur there.\n\nThe monkeypox virus clade in the Congo Basin causes more severe disease in humans, with a case fatality rate of 11-17 percent, than the clade in Ghana, which causes few fatalities. It was this latter clade that was introduced into the USA with the importation of African rodents in the pet trade, with resulting human cases in several states and no fatalities.\n\nThe USA CDC and their cooperators have been conducting field and laboratory studies to determine which rodent species are reservoirs of the virus. The virus is seldom transmitted directly from one person to another, but there is a documented instance in the Republic of the Congo. Monkeys are not the reservoirs of the virus, despite the name that the virus has received. - Mod.TY]\n\n[Because human-to-human transmission appears to be limited, most monkeypox cases are closely associated with spillover transmission from animal reservoirs. Two clades of monkeypox viruses, the West African and Congo Basin viruses, have been identified. The Congo Basin viruses are more virulent. Monkeypox virus is closely related to some other orthopoxviruses such as variola (smallpox) virus, and it cannot be distinguished from these viruses in some laboratory tests.\n\n'Monkeypox is endemic in central Africa (the Congo Basin) and West Africa. An outbreak of human monkeypox occurred in the US in 2003. In the US, cases were seen in pet prairie dogs, other small mammals in captivity, and people who had been exposed to infected prairie dogs. There have been no reports of infections among humans or domesticated animals in North America since 2003, and limited surveys suggest that the virus probably did not enter wild animal populations.\n\n'Most cases of monkeypox in humans are zoonotic. This virus is thought to be transmitted to people in bites from animals, in aerosols during close contact, or by direct contact with lesions, blood or body fluids. In Africa, human outbreaks have often been linked to handling, preparing and eating wild animals. In the US, most cases occurred among people who had close direct contact with prairie dogs; some infections were apparently acquired in scratches and bites, or through open wounds. Human-to-human transmission can also occur. Potential routes of transmission between people include contact with skin lesions or infectious body fluids, or aerosol transmission during prolonged face-to-face contact.\n\n'The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends disinfection of contaminated surfaces with 0.5 percent sodium hypochlorite or other EPA-approved high-level disinfectants. Incineration or autoclaving is appropriate for some contaminated materials. Burial without decontamination is not recommended.'\n\nFor the above and additional background information, including diagnostic methods and references, please refer to the fact sheet 'Monkeypox' (last updated in February 2013), prepared by the Center for Food Security and Public Health, Iowa State University, available at http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/monkeypox.pdf.\n\nPictures of postmortem lesions caused by monkeypox disease can be seen at http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/DiseaseInfo/clinical-signs-photos.php?name=monkeypox.\n\nA map of Cameroon's administrative divisions can be seen at http://www.ephotopix.com/image/africa/cameroon_political_map.gif. - Mod.CRD\n\nProMED-mail thanks Giuseppe Michieli <gimi69@libero.it> for sending a copy of this OIE report.\n\nThe outbreak in the USA was traced to pet shops with recently imported rodents from Africa. The cases were reported to\nthe Institut Pasteur at Bangui. The lesions developed after the boys\nhad hunted and eaten a wild rodent (bemba). They both presented to a\nhealth centre one week after eruption of the extensive lesions, which\ncovered the face, torso, and limbs. Both boys were systemically well,\nwith no fever or notable lymphadenopathy.\n\nLaboratory investigations were done on serum and scabs and on a biopsy\nsample from the brain of a young mouse that had been inoculated 5 days\nearlier with scab material from the lesions. Monkeypox virus was\ndetected by quantitative PCR based on partial haemagglutinin gene and\nidentified by sequencing. The phylogenetic tree showed that the strain\nwas identical to the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC, formerly\nZaire) strain circulating in central Africa. This reported strain was\nidentical to one associated with an outbreak of monkeypox in 2001 in a\nBantu family living on the border between the CAR and the DRC, 480 km\n[about 300 miles] from the cases reported here.\n\nOur patients were admitted to the local health centre and kept in\nisolation until they were no longer infectious. When last seen a week\nafter discharge, in June 2010, both were well and neither showed any\nsequelae.\n\nMonkeypox virus has a wide range of hosts, so it can maintain a\nreservoir in wild animals while sporadically causing human disease,\ngenerally in remote villages in the rainforest areas of central and\nwest Africa. Large outbreaks, with transmission between people, occur\nonly in the DRC. The case-fatality rate in Africa is between 1 percent\nand 10 percent. There is no specific treatment or vaccine although\nsmallpox vaccination is 85 percent effective in preventing monkeypox.\nIn 2003, the 1st human monkeypox outbreak in the western hemisphere\nwas reported in the USA after importation of rodents from Ghana.\n\nWe have describe the occurrence of 2 typical cases of monkeypox,\ncaused by the same viral genotype, 10 years after the previous\ninfections with this strain. Although monkeypox is rare, its\ndifferentiation from other similar presenting illnesses is important.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Mirdad Kazanji\nDirecteur\nInstitut Pasteur de Bangui\nBP 923, Bangui, RCA\n<mirdad.kazanji@pasteur.fr>\n\n[Interested readers should consult the full text of this report:\nMaculopapular lesions in the Central African Republic. MONKEYPOX, HUMAN - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO: SUSPECTED\n**************************************************************\n The monkeypox virus in the Congo has a higher case fatality rate than the virus in West Africa, where fatal cases are rare or absent. However, unlike smallpox virus, monkeypox virus is not efficiently transmitted from person to person. Monkeypox can infect humans and cause lesions clinically similar to those caused by smallpox virus. \n\n\nA suspected case of monkeypox, was recorded in the city of Butembo, North Kivu province (eastern DRC), and was reported to the press on 15 Sep [2012] by Dr. Mundama Witende, Chief Medical Officer of the District of Butembo. \n\nMonkeypox is a viral disease identified in primates and rodents.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["smallpox", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Butembo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DRC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Kivu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liberia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Butembo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virunga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "658819", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Monkeypox - Congo DR (02): (ET)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=658819", "date": "2011-02-21 15:00:06", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (02): (EQUATEUR)\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 14 Feb 2011\nFrom: Karen Saylors <ksaylors@gvfi.org>[edited]\n\n\n[Re: ProMED-mail Monkeypox - Congo DR: (ET) 20110113.0148]\n----------------------------------------------------------\nBased on the Global Viral Forecasting and UCLA's field presence in\nDemocratic Republic of Congo through the USAID Emerging Pandemic\nThreats (EPT) PREDICT initiative, this report of 114 cases of\nmonkeypox, resulting in 5 deaths, seems exaggerated. There is limited\ndiagnostic and confirmatory capacity for monkeypox in Equateur\nProvince and elsewhere in the country, outside of Kinshasa: of the\n2000 suspected monkeypox cases reported across DRC in 2010, only 120\nsamples were taken and sent to INRB (National Institute for\nBiomedical Research) in Kinshasa, of which only 20 were confirmed\npositive for monkeypox.\n\nFurthermore, monkeypox symptoms are often confused with chickenpox.\nOur field team, working in collaboration with the Ministry of Health\nand INRB, reported the following clarifications from Bikoro health\nzone in Equateur: of the 3 samples received at INRB, 2 were confirmed\npositive for chickenpox and one confirmed monkeypox. From Gbadolite\nin Equateur province, of 3 samples received, 2 were confirmed\nmonkeypox and one was chickenpox.\n\nDue to the capacity limitations in DRC, the Ministry of Health and\nEPT partners (PREDICT, RESPOND, and CDC) and other NGOs are\nrecommending a national training mission through health structures,\nfocused on training field personnel, sampling techniques and\nsupplies, cold chain, and personal protective devices. One important\nconclusion in collaborative meetings concerned the fact that\nmonkeypox is an endemic disease in DRC which often gets exaggerated\nin the press. The latest news is that CDC has sent a team to Kinshasa\nto prepare for a field visit to Boende, Equateur Province, to begin training.\n\n--\nKaren Saylors, Ph.D.\nDirector, Behavioral Sciences\nGlobal Viral Forecasting Initiative\n1 Sutter Street, Suite 600/ San Francisco, CA 94104, USA\n<ksaylors@gvfi.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail apologises for the delay in posting Dr Saylors' relevant\ncomment on the recent outbreak of monkeypox virus infection in the\nDemocratic Republic of Congo. This occurred because of technical\nproblems with our email system. In the absence of laboratory\ndiagnostics it is clear that there is high risk of overestimation of\ncase numbers in view of the clinical similarity of monkeypox and\nchickenpox. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "There is limited\ndiagnostic and confirmatory capacity for monkeypox in Equateur\nProvince and elsewhere in the country, outside of Kinshasa: of the\n2000 suspected monkeypox cases reported across DRC in 2010, only 120\nsamples were taken and sent to INRB (National Institute for\nBiomedical Research) in Kinshasa, of which only 20 were confirmed\npositive for monkeypox. Mod.MPP, edited]\n<http://radiookapi.net/actualite/2011/01/12/equateur-114-cas-de-monkey-pox-dont-5-deces-signales-a-bikoro/>\n\n\nEquateur province: 114 cases with 5 deaths due to monkeypox reported in Bikoro\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nThe disease [known as] monkeypox, also known as monkey variola, has raged\nin the north and south of Equateur province. At least 3 health zones are\naffected. For example, in the Bikoro health zone, 114 people have\ncontracted the disease and 5 have died.\n\nAccording to the WHO Equateur provincial branch, the Bikoro health zone has\nbroken the record with 114 cases. Most of the cases have been reported in\nthe Mooto health area, about 82 kilometers [51 mi] from Mbandaka.\n\nTwo weeks ago, medical authorities suspected the presence of a similar\ndisease in the Gbadolite health zone. According to the WHO/Equateur\nregional medical officer, Louis Pia, laboratory tests on specimens from\npatients that were sent to the INRB (National Institute for Biomedical\nResearch) in Kinshasa, confirmed that the cause was monkeypox virus.\n\nThe disease has been reported also in Boende health zone. The same\nconfirmation has been made on specimens taken from patients [in Boende]. It\nis still unclear how many have been infected [overall in Equateur].\n\nTo deal with this epidemic, medical advice is for observation of hygiene\nrules. The medical officer also asked farmers in the affected health zones\nnot pick up dead animals in the forest, including monkeys, squirrels, and\npangolins that transmit this disease to humans.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A recent investigation suggests that monkeypox virus, to which the\nsmallpox vaccine also provides immunity, is now at least 20 times as common\nas it was shortly after the eradication of smallpox and the relaxation of\nimmunisation. (For a detailed discussion see ProMED-mail Monkeypox,\nincreased incidence - Congo DR 20100901.3124, and AW Rimoina et al. Major\nincrease in human monkeypox incidence 30 years after smallpox vaccination\ncampaigns cease in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Proc Natl Acad Sci\nUSA. 2010; 107(37): 16262-7. <http://www.pnas.org/content/107/37/16262.long>.)\n\nWhereas monkeypox virus infection is somewhat less serious than smallpox,\nit can still scar and even kill its victims. And in contrast to smallpox,\nmonkeypox is not only able to jump between humans, but can infect through\ncontact with the small animals that harbor the virus (such as rodents,\nsquirrels, and monkeys). As a result, its control may be more difficult to\nachieve.\n\nThe virus species _Monkeypox virus_ is a member of the genus\n_Orthopoxvirus_. Monkeypox virus can cause a disease in humans that is\nclinically similar to smallpox and outbreaks in central Africa have been\nassociated with significant mortality (such as reported above), although\nnone occurred in an outbreak in the USA in 2003 associated with introduced\nAfrican rodents. An important difference between monkeypox virus and\nsmallpox virus (variola virus) is that monkeypox virus so far has not\ntransmitted from person-to-person as efficiently as variola virus. Indeed\nmonkeypox virus is normally resident in rodents and squirrels but can be\ntransmitted to other species as zoonoses. Phylogenetically the species\n_Monkeypox virus_ is among the most divergent viral species from the\nspecies _ Variola virus_. In fact variola virus is more closely related to\ncamelpox virus than to monkeypox virus. Consequently evolution of monkeypox\nvirus into a variola-like virus by mutation and selection is improbable.\nNonetheless it has potential to cause significant disease in the human\npopulation and might require in limited situations reuse of vaccinia virus\nvaccine.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Democratic Republic of\nCongo can be accessed at <http://healthmap.org/r/0m0C>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 12 Jan 2011\n Monkeypox virus can cause a disease in humans that is\nclinically similar to smallpox and outbreaks in central Africa have been\nassociated with significant mortality (such as reported above), although\nnone occurred in an outbreak in the USA in 2003 associated with introduced\nAfrican rodents. 39 cases of monkeypox recorded since March\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe cases include 19 children from 0 to 5 years, including 3 deaths, in\nBokungu in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (Congo-Kinshasa).\n\nRadiookapi.net has reported that according to Dr Didier Lolobi, the interim\nmedical officer of the health zone, since the epidemic was declared, the\nhealth area office of Bokungu has received no outside assistance and the\nvalue of treatment available is problematic.\n\nDr Didier Lolobi indicated that a doctor who was treating the patients has\nalso contracted infection. He stated that: 'Our chief of staff, Dr Robert\nTrabongo Bongo, who was in contact with a sick child, has contracted\ninfection. He is in isolation and is under treatment but we have no\neffective means of treatment, such as protective clothing, disinfectants,\nand pharmaceuticals products to address this epidemic. We have not\nbenefited from external assistance. The Diocesan Office for Medical Affair\n(BDOM) have given us some drugs but these are insufficient. The area health\norganisation does not have enough resources to supervise remote localities\nin order to detect still unknown cases in the community.'\n\nAccording to the WHO/Equateur medical epidemiologist, 250 kg of drugs\nshould reach Bokungu by Wednesday [16 Jul 2008].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nPro-MED-FRA <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC) website monkeypox is a rare viral disease that occurs mostly in\ncentral and western Africa. It is called 'monkeypox' because it was first\nfound in 1958 in laboratory monkeys. Blood tests of animals in Africa later\nfound that other types of animals probably had monkeypox. Scientists also\nrecovered the virus that causes monkeypox from an African squirrel. These\ntypes of squirrels might be the common host for the disease. Rats, mice,\nand rabbits can get monkeypox, too. Monkeypox was reported in humans for\nthe first time in 1970.\n\nIn humans, the signs and symptoms of monkeypox are like those of smallpox,\nbut usually they are milder. Another difference is that monkeypox causes\nthe lymph nodes to swell. About 12 days after people are infected with the\nvirus, they will get a fever, headache, muscle aches, and backache; their\nlymph nodes will swell; and they will feel tired. One to 3 days (or longer)\nafter the fever starts, they will get a rash. This rash develops into\nraised bumps filled with fluid and often starts on the face and spreads,\nbut it can start on other parts of the body too. The bumps go through\nseveral stages before they get crusty, scab over, and fall off. The illness\nusually lasts for 2 to 4 weeks. In Africa, monkeypox has killed between 1\nper cent and 10 per cent of people who get it. There is no specific\ntreatment for monkeypox. Physicians caring for monkeypox patients are\nadvised to receive smallpox vaccination.\n\nA map of the Democratic Republic of the Congo can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>. Regarding the moderators' observation that this disease affected pet =20\nrats and not wild ones, if you look at the picture that ran with the =20\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "- Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "513411", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Monkeypox, increased incidence - Congo DR", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=513411", "date": "2010-09-01 17:00:03", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX, INCREASED INCIDENCE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 31 Aug 2010\nSource: Reuters Health [edited]\n<http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE67U4RH20100831>\n\n\nMonkeypox rising in wake of smallpox eradication\n------------------------------------------------\nSome 30 years after authorities doled out the\nlast dose of smallpox vaccine, the world faces\nanother multiplying menace: monkeypox. A new\nstudy suggests that the monkeypox virus, which\nthe smallpox vaccine also grants immunity\nagainst, is now at least 20 times as common as it\nwas shortly after victory over smallpox had been declared.\n\n'The eradication of smallpox was one of the\ngreatest achievements known to man,' lead\nresearcher Anne Rimoin of the University of\nCalifornia, Los Angeles School of Public Health\ntold Reuters Health. 'But a consequence of\nceasing smallpox vaccinations is that now the\nworld's population is vulnerable to other (related viruses) such as monkeypox.'\n\nWhile the infection is somewhat less serious than\nsmallpox, it can still scar and even kill its\nvictims. And in contrast to its cousin, monkeypox\nis not only able to jump between humans, but can\ninfect through contact with small animals that\nharbor the virus. As a result, its control could\nbe all the more challenging, warned Rimoin.\n\nConverging political, social, economic and\nenvironmental factors make African nations -- in\nparticular, the Democratic Republic of the Congo\n-- especially vulnerable to the infection, she\nexplained. The virus's favorite animal hosts such\nas squirrels and monkeys are endemic [abundant]\nthere, and civil war has forced many people to\nrely heavily on hunting wildlife for sustenance.\nSome have even migrated deep into the animals'\nforest habitats to seek refuge from the violence.\n\n'The virus has probably been on the rise for\nyears, but the country lacked surveillance,'\nRimoin noted. 'To find disease, you have to look\nfor it.' So she and her colleagues, who included\nmany local Congolese, did just that. Using\nChinese bicycles like pack mules to transport\nsupplies, and with funding from the U.S. National\nInstitutes of Health, they surveyed 9 local\nhealth zones for signs of monkeypox between\nNovember 2005 and November 2007. They identified\n760 cases of laboratory-confirmed monkeypox.\n\nCompared to similar surveillance conducted in the\n1980s, Rimoin's team found a 20-fold increase in\nmonkeypox cases -- far more than they ever\nexpected to find. In a single health zone, the\naverage number of yearly cases rose from less\nthan 1 to roughly 14 per 10 000 people.\n\nMost of the victims were born after smallpox\nvaccination was officially discontinued in 1980.\nVaccinated individuals were more than 5 times\nless likely to become infected with monkeypox\ncompared to those without the vaccine's\nprotection, the researchers report in the\nProceedings of the National Academy of Sciences [Abstract reproduced below].\n\n'What we're seeing is a harbinger of things to\ncome,' said Rimoin. She warned that the virus\ncould grow more widespread with further\ndeforestation, continued movement of people from\nrural to urban areas, bushmeat trafficking and\nimportation of exotic pets. 'And every new\ninfection provides the virus with the opportunity\nto evolve into a more serious or transmissible virus,' she added.\n\nIt's already clear that the Democratic Republic\nof the Congo isn't the only home for the virus.\nThe Republic of the Congo and Sudan also reported\ncases in recent years. And in 2003, monkeypox\narrived in the U.S. Midwest with imported African\nrodents, before spreading among prairie dogs and\nsickening 90 people. Experts fear an even more\nvirulent and efficient virus could return to the western world.\n\n'The higher the rate of new infections, the\ngreater the chance that travelers from the U.S.\nwill be exposed, and that the disease will be\nimported into the U.S. -- possibly establishing\nitself in U.S. rodent populations,' Dr. Dan\nDiGiulio of Stanford University School of\nMedicine in California, who was not involved in\nthe study, noted in an e-mail message to Reuters Health.\n\nSo what can be done to keep the virus at bay?\nRimoin suggested that behavioral interventions\nmay be the most effective strategy at this point,\nincluding teaching people at risk of infection\nwhat animals may be most likely to carry\nmonkeypox and how to handle them to avoid\ninfection, as well as isolating infected\nindividuals. Continued active surveillance is\nalso important to better identify the animal\nreservoirs and rates of animal-to-human versus\nhuman-to-human transmission. 'Once we understand\nmore about this virus and what it may mean for\nus,' she said, 'we may be able to consider\nspecific interventions, perhaps vaccinating\ngroups that are at significant risk of\ninfection.' DiGiulio added the need for animal\nimportation policies, and research into effective\nantiviral treatments and vaccine development.\n\n'Three decades after the eradication of smallpox,\npox viruses still deserve our close attention,'\nsaid Rimoin. 'And we shouldn't only worry about\nits accidental introduction but also as a deliberate terrorist release.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is the reference and abstract for\nthe publication discussed in the above press report.\n\nTitle: Major increase in human monkeypox\nincidence 30 years after smallpox vaccination\ncampaigns cease in the Democratic Republic of Congo.\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nAuthors: Anne W. Rimoina and 18 others.\nProceedings of the National Academy of Sciences,\n2010; DOI:10.1073/pnas.1005769107, online edition.\n\nAbstract: 'Studies on the burden of human\nmonkeypox in the Democratic Republic of the Congo\n(DRC) were last conducted from 1981 to 1986.\nSince then, the population that is\nimmunologically naive to orthopoxviruses has\nincreased significantly due to cessation of mass\nsmallpox vaccination campaigns.\n\nTo assess the current risk of infection, we\nanalyzed human monkeypox incidence trends in a\nmonkeypox-enzootic region. Active,\npopulation-based surveillance was conducted in 9\nhealth zones in central DRC. Epidemiologic data\nand biological samples were obtained from\nsuspected cases. Cumulative incidence (per 10 000\npopulation) and major determinants of infection\nwere compared with data from active surveillance\nin similar regions from 1981 to 1986.\n\nBetween November 2005 and November 2007, 760\nlaboratory-confirmed human monkeypox cases were\nidentified in participating health zones. The\naverage annual cumulative incidence across zones\nwas 5.53 per 10 000 (2.18\u00ad14.42). Factors\nassociated with increased risk of infection\nincluded: living in forested areas, male gender,\nage <15, and no prior smallpox vaccination.\nVaccinated persons had a 5.2-fold lower risk of\nmonkeypox than unvaccinated persons (0.78 vs. 4.05 per 10,000).\n\nComparison of active surveillance data in the\nsame health zone from the 1980s (0.72 per 10 000)\nand 2006\u00ad07 (14.42 per 10 000) suggests a 20-fold\nincrease in human monkeypox incidence. 30 years\nafter mass smallpox vaccination campaigns ceased,\nhuman monkeypox incidence has dramatically\nincreased in rural DRC. Improved surveillance and\nepidemiological analysis is needed to better\nassess the public health burden and develop\nstrategies for reducing the risk of wider spread of infection.'\n\nThe virus species _Monkeypox virus_ is a member\nof the genus _Orthopoxvirus_. Monkeypox virus can\ncauses a disease in humans that is clinically\nsimilar to smallpox and outbreaks in central\nAfrica have been associated with significant\nmortality, although none occurred in the outbreak\nin the USA in 2003 associated with introduced African rodents.\n\nAn important difference between monkeypox virus\nand smallpox virus (variola virus) is that\nmonkeypox virus has not transmitted from\nperson-to-person as efficiently as variola virus.\nIndeed monkeypox virus is normally resident in\nrodents and squirrels but can be transmitted to\nother species as zoonoses. Phylogenetically the\nspecies _Monkeypox virus_ is among the most\ndivergent viral species from the species _\nVariola virus_. Indeed variola virus is more\nclosely related to camelpox virus than to monkeypox virus.\n\nConsequently evolution of monkeypox virus into a\nvariola-like virus by mutation and selection is\nimprobable. Nonetheless it has potential to cause\nsignificant disease in the human population and\nmay require in limited situations reuse of vaccinia virus vaccine.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the\nDemocratic Republic of Congo can be accessed at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01Cl>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The higher the rate of new infections, the\ngreater the chance that travelers from the U.S.\nwill be exposed, and that the disease will be\nimported into the U.S. -- possibly establishing\nitself in U.S. rodent populations,' Dr. Dan\nDiGiulio of Stanford University School of\nMedicine in California, who was not involved in\nthe study, noted in an e-mail message to Reuters Health. According to\ntestimonies from the villagers, Mombouli said, there were at least\n150 cases in the district. Most of those affected were refugees from\nthe Democratic Republic of the Congo younger than 15. 'The clinical\nsigns confirmed the disease,' he said.\nMonkeypox is a rare viral disease found mostly in the rainforest\ncountries of central and West Africa, characterized by a high fever\naccompanied by intense fatigue and [pox-like] lesions, Mombouli said.\n'There is no treatment or vaccine for the disease,' he said. 'The\nrecovery is spontaneous.' [In fact, smallpox vaccination protects\nagainst infection, or failing that, mitigates the severity. -\nMod.JW] Infection follows physical contact with animals, especially\nmonkeys, during the preparation of meat, he said. According to\nMombouli, the virus had adapted to the human species. 'If we neglect\nthe virus and let it evolve, it will become more virulent and lethal,' he said.\nThe outbreak started in January [2007], with the last case being\nregistered at end-August [2007]. The disease was spread out over a\n200km [124-mile] radius in Likouala and affected villages along the\nRiver Oubangui. The river is a natural border between the Congo\nRepublic, Democratic Republic of the Congo, and the Central African\nRepublic [see map URL below].\nMeanwhile, 4 experts from the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention (CDC) in Atlanta, GA, are expected in Brazzaville this\nweek [24-28 Sep 2007] to analyse samples taken by Congolese health\nexperts in the affected areas in order to identify the origin of the\noutbreak, which so far remains unknown.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nOtavio Silva <otavio_uff104@yahoo.com.br>\n[A recent review by Parker, Buller and Schultz (Future Microbiology\n2: 17-34, Feb 2007) has identified monkeypox virus infection as an\nemerging zoonotic disease. Zoonotic monkeypox virus is maintained in\na large number of rodent and, to a lesser extent, nonhuman primate\nspecies in West and central Africa. Although monkeypox virus was\ndiscovered in 1958, the prototypic human cases were not witnessed\nuntil the early 1970s. Before this time, it is assumed that\ninfections were masked by smallpox, which was then widely endemic.\nNevertheless, since the 1970s, reported monkeypox virus infections of\nhumans have escalated, as have outbreaks with reported human-to-human\ntransmission. This increase is likely due to numerous factors, such\nas enhanced surveillance efforts, environmental degradation and human\nurbanization of areas where monkeypox virus is maintained in its\nanimal reservoir(s) and, consequently, serve as a nidus for human\ninfection. Furthermore, viral genetic predispositions enable\nmonkeypox virus to infect many animal species, represented in\nexpansive geographic ranges.\nMonkeypox virus was once restricted to specific regions of Africa,\nbut its range has expanded, suggesting that human monkeypox\ninfections could continue to intensify. As a zoonotic agent,\nmonkeypox virus is far less sensitive to typical eradication measures\nsince it is maintained in wild-animal populations. Moreover, human\nvaccination is becoming a less viable option to control poxvirus\ninfections in today's increasingly immunocompromised population,\nparticularly with the emergence of HIV in Sub-Saharan Africa. An\nincreased frequency of human monkeypox virus infections, especially\nin immunocompromised individuals, may permit monkeypox virus to\nevolve and maintain itself independently in human populations.\nThe apparent increased frequency of human monkeypox virus infections\nin Africa may be a consequence of the increased prevalence of\nimmunocompromised individuals in the human population, promoting\nmaintenance of the virus in humans and possibly enhanced virulence. - Mod.CP]\n[Although monkeypox virus has been isolated from monkeys and human\ncases have been associated with contact with monkeys, the reservoirs\nof the virus most likely are rodents. The giant pouched rat\n(_Cricetomys_), rope squirrels (_Funisciuris_ sp.) and dormice\n(_Graphiuris_ sp.) are suspected. In that epidemic, spread was not\nfrom meat but by the respiratory route and possibly from handling the\nanimals (hand-to-mouth contact). More field research is needed to\ndefine the range of the virus and its relationship to its mammalian\nreservoirs. There is just one documented instance of human-to-human\ntransmission.\nReferences:\n-----------\nLevine RS, Peterson AT, Yorita KL, Carroll D, Damon IK, Reynolds MG.\n2007. MONKEYPOX, HUMAN - CONGO DR (KASAI OCCIDENTAL): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************************\n [A map of the Democratic Republic of Congo showing the location of\nKananga in Kasai Occidental province is available via\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/english/htmain.htm>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis", "varicella", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kasai Occidental", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kananga", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209443", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Monkeypox - Sudan: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209443", "date": "2006-03-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX - SUDAN: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 20 Mar 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO EMRO (Eastern Mediterranean Regional Office) website [edited]\n<http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/pdf/MonkeyPox.pdf>\n\nOn 27 Oct 2005, the Medecins Sans Frontieres France team in Bentiu, Unity\nState, Sudan, were alerted by the case of an 8-month-old infant who\npresented a generalized vesiculo-papular rash that could resemble pox\ndiseases. The child had fever of sudden onset, cough, coryza and enlarged\nlymph nodes. These symptoms appeared 2 days before the onset of the rash.\nFrom 27 Oct 2005 until 18 Nov 2005, an additional 18 suspected cases were\nidentified. All of the cases evolved well and no deaths were\nreported. There has been no report of any new case since 18 Nov 2005.\nSpecimens were sent to the WHO Reference Center for Orthopoxvirus in CDC\nAtlanta, USA. CDC Atlanta confirmed the Monkeypox infection on the samples\nof the index case. They isolate the virus and found that it was related to\nthe DRC clade.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has learned from a reliable source that in fact there has been\ncontinued monkeypox activity in Sudan, with cases continuing to occur in 2006.\nMonkeypox has not previously been reported in Sudan. (A map of Sudan with\nstates is available at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/sudan.pdf>. Bentui can\nbe seen on this map in the south-central area of the country.)\nBorrowing from my colleague Mod.CP's previous comments on a suspected\nmonkeypox outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, 'Human\ninfection with monkeypox virus has been reported in rural areas of the\ntropical rain forests of west and central Africa, especially in the\nDemocratic Republic of Congo. The signs and symptoms are similar to those\nof smallpox, with generalized pustular rash, fever, and toxemia. The\ndisease, which is rare, became apparent only after the eradication of\nsmallpox. Monkeypox virus is a zoonotic agent and is acquired by humans\nthrough direct contact with the presumptive natural hosts: squirrels and\nmonkeys. Person-to-person transmission has been recorded, but the secondary\nattack rate is low. Nonetheless, the fear has been expressed that monkeypox\nmight evolve to become an endemic human infection. Determination of the\ncomplete sequence of the genome of monkeypox virus, however, has indicated\nthat monkeypox virus lacks some of the immunomodulatory genes possessed by\nsmallpox virus, which suggests that monkeypox virus is unlikely to become\nendemic in the human population.'\nProMED-mail would appreciate more information on this outbreak from\nknowledgeable sources. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "Determination of the\ncomplete sequence of the genome of monkeypox virus, however, has indicated\nthat monkeypox virus lacks some of the immunomodulatory genes possessed by\nsmallpox virus, which suggests that monkeypox virus is unlikely to become\nendemic in the human population.' (A map of Sudan with\nstates is available at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/sudan.pdf>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["smallpox", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2005-11-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208418", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Monkeypox virus, cross-protective immunity - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208418", "date": "2005-08-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX VIRUS, CROSS-PROTECTIVE IMMUNITY - USA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\nDate: Mon 8 Aug 2005\nFrom: George Robertson <grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\nSource: Reuters Health, Mon 8 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.reutershealth.com/en/index.html>\n\nMonkeypox Outbreak Shows Smallpox Vaccine Works\n-----------------------------------------------\nA 2003 outbreak of monkeypox in the United States has helped prove\nthat smallpox vaccinations can protect for decades, U.S. researchers\nsaid on Monday [8 Aug 2005]. The study could help officials trying to\ncome up with a plan for mass-vaccination against the often deadly\nsmallpox virus and its relatives, should such a virus ever be used in\na biological attack.\nThe researchers found 3 people who were evidently infected by the\nmonkeypox virus, spread mostly by pet prairie dogs in the Midwest,\nwho never had any symptoms. The 3 had last been vaccinated against\nsmallpox before the jabs were discontinued. One was vaccinated 13\nyears ago, another 29 years ago and the third 48 years ago. 'These\nindividuals were unaware that they had been infected, because they\nwere spared any recognizable disease symptoms,' Mark Kenneth Slifka,\nof Oregon Health & Sciences University, and colleagues wrote in their\nreport, published in the journal Nature Medicine [see below].\n'Together, this shows that the U.S. monkeypox outbreak was larger\nthan previously realized and, more importantly, shows that\ncross-protective antiviral immunity against West African monkeypox\ncan potentially be maintained for decades after smallpox vaccination.'\nSmallpox was eradicated in 1979 after a global vaccination program.\nBut experts fear the virus or a related virus could be used as a\nbiological weapon. About half the U.S. adult population has been\nvaccinated as part of routine efforts that stopped in 1972 for\ncivilians and 1990 for the military. Studies have shown that immunity\nlasts as long as 75 years.\nNow work is underway to stockpile doses of vaccine in case of an\nattack, while tests are also underway to see whether perhaps some\npeople might be protected by their old vaccinations. But no one has\nbeen able to do a real test of how well the vaccine protects, until\nthe monkeypox outbreak, traced to pet rodents imported from West\nAfrica, where the close relative of smallpox is well entrenched and\nstill common.\nThe team tested 44 people from Wisconsin, the epicenter of the\noutbreak, which originated at a pet store in Illinois. At least 39\npeople were reported infected with monkeypox in Wisconsin, they said.\n'We screened subjects and included in the study only those who had\nclose contact with monkeypox-infected individuals or\nmonkeypox-infected prairie dogs,' they wrote. They found 3 people who\nhad clear evidence of infection in their blood, yet never showed any\nsymptoms of monkeypox. All had been previously vaccinated against\nsmallpox.\nThey also found that the monkeypox viruses spread even without direct\ncontact, something to be aware of should there ever be a smallpox\nattack. 'A common misconception of the U.S. monkeypox outbreak is\nthat infection requires direct contact or direct inoculation through\nscratches or bites in order for infected prairie dogs to transmit\nmonkeypox to humans,' the researchers wrote. But the virus apparently\ncan be carried in the air and by tiny sneezed droplets. 'In one case,\na subject contracted monkeypox after an infected prairie dog was\ncarried into her home when she was not present. The prairie dog was\napparently not placed on the floor or furniture, and yet this\nsubject, who had no contact with prairie dogs or other individuals\nwith monkeypox, contracted the disease,' they wrote.\n--\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nVice President, Research and Development\nDOR Biopharma\nSuite 435, 1691 Michigan Ave.\nMiami, FL 33139, USA\n<grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\n[The report in Nature Medicine referred to above was published online\non Sun 7 Aug 2005:\n<http://www.nature.com/nm/journal/vaop/ncurrent/abs/nm1273.html>.\nThe report is entitled 'Multiple diagnostic techniques identify\npreviously vaccinated individuals with protective immunity against\nmonkeypox' by Erika Hammarlund and 9 others at the Vaccine and Gene\nTherapy Institute, Oregon Health & Science University, Beaverton,\nOregon 97006, USA. The Abstract states that 'Approximately 50 percent\nof the US population received smallpox vaccinations before routine\nimmunization ceased in 1972 for civilians and in 1990 for military\npersonnel. Several studies have shown long-term immunity after\nsmallpox vaccination, but skepticism remains as to whether this will\ntranslate into full protection against the onset of\northopoxvirus-induced disease. The US monkeypox outbreak of 2003\nprovided the opportunity to examine this issue. Using independent and\ninternally validated diagnostic approaches with 95 percent\nsensitivity and 90 percent specificity for detecting clinical\nmonkeypox infection, we identified 3 previously unreported cases of\nmonkeypox in preimmune individuals at 13, 29 and 48 years after\nsmallpox vaccination. These individuals were unaware that they had\nbeen infected because they were spared any recognizable disease\nsymptoms. Together, this shows that the US monkeypox outbreak was\nlarger than previously realized and, more importantly, shows that\ncross-protective antiviral immunity against West African monkeypox\ncan potentially be maintained for decades after smallpox vaccination.'\nIn similar vein, Yvette Edghill-Smith et al., in an article published\nin Nature Medicine on 1 Jul 2005 (Nature Medicine 11, 740-747),\nconcluded from experiments using a Rhesus macaque model of infection\nwith monkeypox virus that: 'Smallpox vaccine-induced antibodies are\nnecessary and sufficient for protection against monkeypox virus.'\nThese findings are not unexpected in that vaccinia virus (i.e.\nsmallpox vaccine) and 21 other orthopoxviruses share the same\ninventory of 90 essential genes for infection and multiplication in\ncells, see: Upton, C., Slack, S., Hunter, A. L., Ehlers, A. & Roper,\nR. L. Poxvirus orthologous clusters: towards defining the minimum\nessential poxvirus genome. USA (Midwest): 2003", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208289", "date": "2005-07-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX VIRUS, VIRULENCE DIFFERENCES - USA (MIDWEST): 2003\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, organizer of\nThe 1st International Conference for the Journal of Travel Medicine and\nInfectious Disease\n<http://tinyurl.com/8vv5p>\n[1]\nDate: Sat 16 Jul 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: HealthCentral, ex HealthDay News, Fri 15 Jul 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.healthcentral.com/PrinterFriendly/408/526876.html>\n\nUSA: Weaker Strain of Monkeypox Responsible for Outbreak in 2003\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nThe outbreak of monkeypox that occurred in the United States in the summer of\n2003 didn't cause any deaths because the strain of virus that caused the\noutbreak is the less virulent of 2 known strains of monkeypox, researchers\nreport. During the outbreak, health officials counted 72 confirmed or suspected\ncases of human monkeypox, but no deaths. The disease usually kills about 10\npercent of infected people.\n'We have at least 2 biological strains of monkeypox virus -- one on the west\ncoast of Africa, and the other in the Congo basin. The 2003 outbreak in the\nUnited States was from West Africa. If it had come from the Congo, we might\nhave had a bigger problem on our hands and very well might have seen patient\ndeaths,' study senior author Mark Buller of Saint Louis University Health\nSciences Center, said in a prepared statement.\nMonkeypox belongs to a family of viruses that causes human smallpox, cowpox,\ncamelpox [and includes several other related orthoviruses]. Monkeypox symptoms\ninclude fever, respiratory problems, and pus-filled blisters on the body.\nMonkeypox is a zoonosis -- an animal disease that can be transmitted to humans.\nRecent studies suggest that cases of monkeypox in Africa are on the rise due to\nhuman encroachment into the habitats of animals that carry the virus, Buller\nsaid.\nThe U.S. outbreak was caused by a shipment of West African rodents imported for\nthe pet trade. At a pet distribution center, the African rodents infected\nprairie dogs that were sold as pets. The findings are reported in the July\nissue of the Journal 'Virology' [see below].\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 16 Jul 2005\nFrom: Pablo Nart <pablo11@hotPOP.com>\nSource: The Milwaukee Channel online, Fri 15 Jul 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.themilwaukeechannel.com/news/4730260/detail.html>\n\nUSA: Monkeypox Outbreak in 2003 Involved Weaker Virus\n-----------------------------------------------------\nMonkeypox virus, a less deadly relative of smallpox virus, kills up to 10\npercent of its victims in Africa. Yet the monkeypox outbreak 2 years ago in the\nUnited States killed no one, and scientists have wondered why.\nNow they have a good idea. New research finds that there are 2 distinct strains\nof the virus, and that the U.S. outbreak involved the weaker West African\nstrain rather than the more deadly Congolese strain. The illness was spread by\nprairie dogs after they were infected by imported African rodents at a pet\ndistribution center. 'If it had come from Congo, we might have had a bigger\nproblem on our hands and very well might have seen patient deaths,'said Mark\nBuller, a St. Louis University virologist who led the federally funded study,\npublished on Fri 15 Jul 2005 in 'Virology' [see below].\nScientists from the U.S. Army Research Institute of Infectious Diseases\n[USAMRIID], the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], and 4 other\nuniversities in the United States and Canada worked on the report.\nThe monkeypox outbreak 2 summers ago was the 1st in the Western Hemisphere. An\nestimated 72 people in the Midwest were sickened by the virus, which causes\nblisters and a rash that resemble smallpox. Cases were reported in Wisconsin,\nIllinois, Indiana, Kansas, Ohio & Missouri. 16 people were hospitalized, though\nnot all were sick. 2 children required intensive care and recovered. The\nmonkeypox outbreak included 39 confirmed or suspected cases from Wisconsin,\nwhere the disease was first detected. The initial case involved a 3-year-old\nchild in Wausau, who got it from a pet prairie dog her mother bought at a 4-H\nswap meet in the spring of 2003. It and other infected prairie dogs had been\nhoused near imported Gambian rats by animal distributors.\nDoctors thought better U.S. medical care and generally better health than in\nAfrica were the reasons no one died. But genetic analysis suggests the germ\nitself made the difference. Researchers compared several strains similar to the\nWest African one in the U.S. outbreak to a Congolese strain from a gene bank.\nThey also looked back at previously unpublished experiments Army researchers\nhad done in the 1990s on such viruses in monkeys as part of an effort to find\nways to test new smallpox vaccines. Monkeys infected with the West African\nstrain got only mildly ill and none died. 5 out of 6 of those given the other\nstrain got severely ill and all 3 that got the higher dose of it died.\nAfter the 2003 outbreak, federal officials banned the importation of African\nrodents and the sale of U.S. prairie dogs [but is exchanging them at a 'swap\nmeet' -- see above -- still legal? - Mod.JW], but importing animals from other\ncountries is still legal, along with breeding captive exotic and wild\nanimals. 'We definitely are better off than we were' before the outbreak in\nterms of regulation, said Dr. Marty Cetron, the CDC's director of quarantine,\nbut he added, 'there's still more that could be done.' 'We do think there is a\nrisk of emerging infections being spread by or amplified by the exotic pet\ntrade,' he said [but prairie dogs are not exotic in the sense of not imported.-\nMod.JW].\n--\nPablo Nart\n<pablo11@hotPOP.com>\n[The paper referred to in the above reports is published in the current issue\nof Virology\n(<http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_aset=V-WA-A-W-AV-MsSA\nYWW-UUA-U-AAWVAWAZYY-AAWADUWVYY-WBUEDDWZC-AV-U&_rdoc=1&_fmt=summary&_udi=B6W\nXR-4GMJ900-1&_coverDate=07%2F14%\n2F2005&_cdi=7165&_orig=search&_st=13&_sort=d&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&\n_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=fb43d5830e6\ne05c8f89ffb2fd429f647>.\nThe paper is authored by Nanhai Chen and 15 others and is entitled: ' Virulence\ndifferences between monkeypox virus isolates from West Africa and the Congo\nbasin'.\nThe Abstract of the paper reads as follows: 'Studies indicate that West African\nand Congo basin isolates of monkeypox virus (MPXV) are genetically distinct.\nHere, we show Congo basin MPXV-ZAI-V79 is more virulent for cynomolgus monkeys\nas compared to presumed West African MPXV-COP-58. This finding may explain the\nlack of case-fatalities in the U.S. 2003 monkeypox outbreak, which was caused\nby a West African virus. Virulence differences between West African and Congo\nbasin MPXV are further supported by epidemiological analyses that observed a\nsimilar prevalence of antibodies in non-vaccinated humans in both regions,\nwhile more than 90 percent of reported cases occurred in the Congo basin, and\nno fatal cases were observed outside of this region. To determine the basis for\nthis difference in virulence, we sequenced the genomes of one human West\nAfrican isolate, and 2 presumed West African isolates and compared the\nsequences to Congo basin MPXV-ZAI-96-I-16. The analysis identified D10L, D14L,\nB10R, B14R, and B19R as possible virulence genes, with D14L (ortholog of\nvaccinia complement protein) as a leading candidate.' - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Virulence differences between West African and Congo\nbasin MPXV are further supported by epidemiological analyses that observed a\nsimilar prevalence of antibodies in non-vaccinated humans in both regions,\nwhile more than 90 percent of reported cases occurred in the Congo basin, and\nno fatal cases were observed outside of this region. They did\na lot of research, visited the sites, interviewed and examined patients,\ntook more samples, and sent them to a lab in South Africa.
