All\nthese victims are from Kanama in the Kabinda District of the central region\nof the Democratic Republic of Congo.\n--\nShirley Bannatyne\nMASTA (Medical Advisory Service for Travellers Abroad)\n<shirley.bannatyne@masta.org>\n[Human infection with monkeypox virus has been reported in rural areas of\nthe tropical rain forests of west and central Africa, especially in the\nDemocratic Republic of Congo. The signs and symptoms are similar to those\nof smallpox, with generalized pustular rash, fever, and toxemia. The\ndisease, which is rare, became apparent only after the eradication of\nsmallpox. Monkeypox virus is a zoonotic agent and is acquired by humans\nthrough direct contact with the presumptive natural hosts: squirrels and\nmonkeys. Person-to-person transmission has been recorded, but the secondary\nattack rate is low. Nonetheless, the fear has been expressed that monkeypox\nmight evolve to become an endemic human infection. Determination of the\ncomplete sequence of the genome of monkeypox virus, however, has indicated\nthat monkeypox virus lacks some of the immunomodulatory genes possessed by\nsmallpox virus, which suggests that monkeypox virus is unlikely to become\nendemic in the human population.\nIn a comment relating to an outbreak in the same region of the Democratic\nRepublic of Congo in the year 2000 (see: Monkeypox - Congo, Dem. Rep.\n(Mbuji-Mayi): comment 20000506.069), Francois Merouze wrote that:\n'Monkeypox is a zoonosis among African tree squirrels (_Heliosciurus_,\n_Funisciurus_). Human cases happen by direct contacts with sick animals.\nHuman to human subsequent cases are not very frequent. The usual mode for\nthis disease is anademic. There is no really prove[n] example of an\nimportant outbreak of monkeypox. The clinical diagnosis of monkeypox is not\nso easy, and chickenpox can be mistaken for monkeypox. Moreover, varicella\n(chickenpox), which is considered as an ordinary mild disease, can wear a\nvery different clinical aspect and even be a fatal disease for an\nimmunodepressed organism. In DRC, the prevalence rate of HIV is quite high.'\nIt would be relevant to know whether chickenpox virus (a herpesvirus) has\nbeen excluded as the possible cause of this outbreak, since chickenpox is a\nvaccine-preventable disease. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Determination of the\ncomplete sequence of the genome of monkeypox virus, however, has indicated\nthat monkeypox virus lacks some of the immunomodulatory genes possessed by\nsmallpox virus, which suggests that monkeypox virus is unlikely to become\nendemic in the human population. The finding of so many mild cases\nand no deaths so far is surprising. Some have commented that it is the\n'comorbidity' present in Africa that enhances the impact of monkeypox. I\nfind this explanation to be facile; there is no evidence that any\nparticular disease impacts on the outcome of infection with the virus in\nAfrica and there is no evidence that concomitant malnutrition or other\ncondition is needed to make monkeypox a serious disease. This may be so,\nbut I don't know of any data.\nIn fact, the only cases of monkeypox I have seen were in pygmies in the mid\n1980s and the general health of the group was quite good, although the\nstate of the recovering children reminded me very much of that of persons\nrecovering from measles with the added visible lymphadenopathy. Which of\ncourse brings to mind another obvious explanation for the mild course in\nthe US. There is better supportive care. This doesn't wash because the\ncases seem to be quite mild and not snatched from the jaws of death by\nnursing, antipyretics, rehydrations, and antibiotic treatment of secondary\ninfections as we attribute to differences in measles mortality.\nThere are, of course, many possible speculations including host and viral\ngenetics, recent passage in prairie dogs, etc. I would like to suggest a\nrather off-the-wall, but not unreasonable, idea that should be factored\ninto the equation: route of inoculation. This idea originates from the old\npractice of smallpox prevention by 'variolation' or 'inoculation'. Smallpox\nvirus was introduced into the skin or nasal mucous membrane of a\nsusceptible person and the resulting disease was relatively mild and\nimmunized. If one reads the old English literature, one finds that the low\nmortality of about two per cent was obtained by a shallow inoculation in\nthe skin. The subsequent local cutaneous lesion appeared quickly and\napparently initiated a vigorous immune response that attenuated the disease\nwith the result of few pocks (appearing later) and mild host impact. This\nseems to fit some of the situations floating about on the rumor mill,\nalthough I have had no contact with these cases.\n--\nClarence J Peters\n<cjpeters@utmb.edu>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n I\nfind this explanation to be facile; there is no evidence that any\nparticular disease impacts on the outcome of infection with the virus in\nAfrica and there is no evidence that concomitant malnutrition or other\ncondition is needed to make monkeypox a serious disease. The Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention (CDC) is confident that this shipment is the\nsource of the current U.S. outbreak of monkeypox. As a result, the\nagency is recommending the quarantine and euthanasia of all animals\nfrom the shipment, as well as prairie dogs from the U.S. that were\nexposed to the imported species or to other animals suspected of\nhaving monkeypox.\nPet prairie dogs are believed to be the main source of the human\nmonkeypox outbreak that emerged in the U.S. last month. 'The goal is\nto protect people, pets and wildlife in the United States, by\npreventing the monkeypox virus from spreading or becoming established\npermanently,' the CDC's Dr. Martin Cetron said in a statement.\nThe CDC previously recommended quarantine of animals infected or\nexposed to monkeypox. The new recommendations call for euthanizing\nthese animals. 'These measures are essential in order to effectively\naddress this public health issue,' Cetron said. 'This truly\ncollaborative effort requires the support of public health officials,\nthe pet industry, and pet owners to successfully contain this\noutbreak.'\nAs of Tue 1 Jul 2003, the CDC was investigating 81 suspect or\nprobable human cases of monkeypox -- 39 in Wisconsin, 22 in Indiana,\n16 in Illinois, 2 in Missouri, and one each from Kansas and Ohio. 32\nhuman cases have been laboratory-confirmed. Wisconsin has the highest\nnumber of lab-confirmed cases at 14, followed by Illinois with 8,\nIndiana with 7, Kansas with 2, and Missouri with one.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 2 Jul 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR 2 Jul 2003 / 52(Dispatch);1-3\n\nUpdate: Multistate Outbreak of Monkeypox --- Illinois, Indiana,\nKansas, Missouri, Ohio, and Wisconsin, 2003\nCDC and state and local health departments continue to investigate\ncases of monkeypox among persons who had contact with wild or exotic\nmammalian pets or persons with monkeypox (1--3). This report updates\nepidemiologic, laboratory, and smallpox vaccine use data for U.S.\ncases, and summarizes the laboratory-based evidence implicating\nimported African rodents as the probable source of the outbreak.\nAs of 2 Jul 2003, a total of 81 cases of monkeypox have been reported\nto CDC from Wisconsin (39), Indiana (22), Illinois (16), Missouri\n(2), Kansas (one), and Ohio (one) (Figure); these include 32 (40\npercent) cases laboratory-confirmed at CDC and 49 (60 percent)\nsuspect and probable cases under investigation. One case was excluded\nfrom those reported in the previous update because it met the\nexclusion criteria outlined in the updated case definition, and 3\nwere added (3). Of the 81 cases, 43 (53 percent) were among females;\nthe median age was 27 years (range: 1--51 years). Age data were\nunavailable for one patient. Among 78 patients for whom data were\navailable, 19 (24 percent) were hospitalized. The previously reported\nchild with painful adenopathy associated with diffuse pox lesions\nimproved clinically and was discharged from the hospital after 6 days\n(3). Confirmatory testing of skin rash lesions at CDC was positive\nfor monkeypox virus.\nOf the 81 reported cases, 31 have been laboratory confirmed at CDC\nfor monkeypox by detection of virus in skin rash lesions by using\nculture, polymerase chain reaction (PCR), immunohistochemical\ntesting, and/or electron microscopy; one case was confirmed by virus\nisolation and PCR testing of an oropharyngeal specimen. The number of\nconfirmed cases by state includes Wisconsin (14), Indiana (7),\nIllinois (8), Missouri (2), and Kansas (one). For these\nlaboratory-confirmed cases, the onset of illness ranged from 16 May\nto 20 Jun 2003. All confirmed patients reported a rash, and all but\none reported at least one other clinical sign or symptom, including\nfever, respiratory symptoms, and/or lymphadenopathy. The median\nincubation period* was 12 days (range: 1--31 days). The majority of\npatients with confirmed monkeypox reported exposure to wild or exotic\nmammals, including prairie dogs; some patients also had contact with\nother persons with monkeypox virus infection in a household setting.\nNo cases of monkeypox that could be attributed exclusively to\nperson-to-person contact have been confirmed.\nUse of Smallpox Vaccine\nTo prevent further transmission of monkeypox, 28 residents of 6\nstates have received smallpox vaccine since 13 Jun 2003; recipients\nincluded 26 adults and 2 children. Vaccine was administered to 2\nlaboratory workers and 2 health-care workers pre-exposure and to 24\npersons post-exposure (10 health-care workers, 7 household contacts,\n3 laboratory workers, 2 public health veterinarians, one public\nhealth worker, and one work contact). One child vaccinated\npost-exposure had a rash 6 days after vaccination; PCR testing of\nskin lesions from the child was positive for monkeypox virus. The\nchild lived in a household with 2 ill prairie dogs and an adult with\nlaboratory-confirmed monkeypox virus infection. One prairie dog had\nbeen present in the household for approximately 1 year and became ill\nafter the introduction of a second ill prairie dog into the home. The\nchild's period of exposure began 25 days before vaccination, when the\nill prairie dog was brought into the home; the child's rash began 12\ndays after the onset of rash illness in the adult household member.\nAnimal Laboratory Testing\nTraceback investigations have implicated a shipment of animals from\nGhana that was imported to Texas on 9 Apr 2003 as the probable source\nof introduction of monkeypox virus into the United States (1,2). The\nshipment contained approximately 800 small mammals of 9 different\nspecies, including 6 genera of African rodents. These rodent genera\nincluded rope squirrels (Funiscuirus sp.), tree squirrels\n(Heliosciurus sp.), Gambian giant rats (Cricetomys sp.), brushtail\nporcupines (Atherurus sp.), dormice (Graphiurus sp.), and striped\nmice (Hybomys sp.). Gambian rats from this shipment were kept in\nclose proximity to prairie dogs at an Illinois animal vendor\nimplicated in the sale of infected prairie dogs.\nCDC laboratory testing of some animals by using PCR and virus\nisolation demonstrated that one Gambian giant rat, 3 dormice, and 2\nrope squirrels from the 9 Apr 2003 importation were infected with\nmonkeypox virus. Evaluation of other animals associated with the\nshipment is ongoing. Evidence of infection was found in some animals\nthat had been separated from the rest of the shipment on the day of\ntheir arrival into the United States, indicating early and possibly\nwidespread infection among the remaining animals in the shipment. The\nlaboratory investigation confirmed that multiple animal species are\nsusceptible to infection with monkeypox virus.\nCDC had recommended previously that state health officials place\nquarantines on commercial facilities or households that had infected\nanimals or received African rodents from the 9 Apr 2003 shipment (1).\nCDC has issued guidance on the quarantine and euthanasia of all\nrodents from the shipment, as well as prairie dogs that were exposed\nto the imported rodents or other animals with illnesses consistent\nwith the case definition for monkeypox.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/quarantineremoval.htm>\nAnimals that are euthanized according to the guidance should be\nincinerated and not buried in a landfill or backyard setting.\nCDC and the Food and Drug Administration issued a joint order on 11\nJun 2003 prohibiting the importation of any African rodent. In\naddition, the order prohibits the sale and transport within the\nUnited States of prairie dogs and 6 genera of African rodents.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/pdf/embargo.pdf>\nTo prevent the spread of monkeypox virus into domestic or wild animal\npopulations, the order also prohibits releasing any of these animals\ninto the wild. State and local health departments or departments of\nagriculture should be consulted for guidance on the safe disposal of\nanimals. The joint order remains in effect regardless of the actions\nrelated to the guidance for quarantine and euthanasia of animals of\nconcern.\nHealth-care providers, veterinarians, and public-health officials who\nsuspect monkeypox in animals or humans should report such cases to\ntheir state and local health departments. State health departments\nshould report suspect cases to CDC, telephone 770-488-7100. An\nupdated case definition with revised case exclusion criteria is\navailable:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/index.htm>\nClinical specimens should be submitted for testing after consultation\nwith the state and local health department. Interpretation of\nlaboratory results requires completion of specimen submission forms,\nwhich are available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/diagspecimens.htm>.\nReported by: State and local health departments. Monkeypox\ninvestigation team, CDC.\nReferences\n1. CDC. Multistate outbreak of monkeypox---Illinois, Indiana, and\nWisconsin, 2003. MMWR 2003;52:537--40.\n2. CDC. Update: multistate outbreak of monkeypox---Illinois, Indiana,\nKansas, Missouri, Ohio, and Wisconsin, 2003. MMWR 2003;52: 561--4.\n3. CDC. Update: multistate outbreak of monkeypox---Illinois, Indiana,\nKansas, Missouri, Ohio, and Wisconsin, 2003. MMWR 2003;52: 589--90.\n* Defined as first possible exposure date to illness onset date;\nhowever, some persons reported intermittent or continuous exposure.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[These positive tests finally remove all doubts about the origin of\nthis outbreak of monkeypox in the U.S. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Vaccine was administered to 2\nlaboratory workers and 2 health-care workers pre-exposure and to 24\npersons post-exposure (10 health-care workers, 7 household contacts,\n3 laboratory workers, 2 public health veterinarians, one public\nhealth worker, and one work contact). USA (13)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204047", "date": "2003-06-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX, HUMAN, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (13)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 26 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, Fri 27 Jun 2003 /\n52(25);589-590 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5225a4.htm>\n\nUpdate: Multistate Outbreak of Monkeypox --- Illinois, Indiana, Kansas,\nMissouri, Ohio, and Wisconsin, 2003\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCDC and state and local health departments continue to investigate cases of\nmonkeypox among persons who had contact with wild or exotic mammalian pets\nor persons with monkeypox (1,2). This report updates epidemiologic,\nlaboratory, and smallpox vaccine use data for U.S. cases.\nAs of 25 Jun 2003, a total of 79 cases of monkeypox had been reported to\nCDC from Wisconsin (39), Indiana (20), Illinois (16), Missouri (2), Kansas\n(one), and Ohio (one); these include 29 cases laboratory-confirmed at CDC\nand 51 cases under investigation by state and local health departments. A\ntotal of 19 cases were excluded from those reported in the previous update\nbecause they met the exclusion criteria outlined in the updated case\ndefinition (2), and 11 were added. Of the 79 cases, 37 (47 percent) were\namong males; the median age was 28 years (range: 1 to 51 years). Age data\nwere unavailable for 2 patients. Among 75 patients for whom data were\navailable, 19 (25 percent) were hospitalized. Two patients have had a\nserious clinical illness. The first patient was a child with a previously\nreported laboratory-confirmed case of severe monkeypox-associated\nencephalitis (1,2); the child subsequently improved and was discharged\nafter requiring hospitalization for 14 days. A second child, who was\nexposed to 3 ill prairie dogs, was hospitalized with profound painful\ncervical and tonsillar adenopathy and diffuse pox lesions, including\nlesions in the oropharynx. Although the child had difficulty breathing and\nswallowing, mechanical ventilation was not required. The adenopathy peaked\n5 days after rash onset and 7 days after onset of initial prodromal\nsymptoms of general malaise, myalgia, and fever. Preliminary testing of\nskin rash lesions was positive for orthopoxvirus infection; confirmatory\ntesting for monkeypox virus is pending at CDC.\nOf the 79 reported cases, 29 (37 percent) have been laboratory confirmed at\nCDC for monkeypox by detection of virus in skin rash lesions by using\nculture, polymerase chain reaction (PCR), immunohistochemical testing,\nand/or electron microscopy. One patient had monkeypox virus detected by PCR\nand culture in throat and nasopharyngeal swabs obtained when the patient\nwas ill with prodromal symptoms and a macular rash. In addition, an IgM\nresponse to orthopoxvirus antigen was detected in an acute serum sample.\nFor these laboratory-confirmed cases, dates of illness onset ranged from 16\nMay 2003 to 11 Jun 2003. All confirmed patients reported a rash and at\nleast one other clinical sign or symptom, including fever, respiratory\nsymptoms, and/or lymphadenopathy. The median incubation period (i.e., first\nexposure date to illness onset date) was 12 days (range: 2 to 26 days). The\nmajority of confirmed patients reported exposure to wild or exotic mammals,\nincluding prairie dogs; some patients also had contact with other persons\nwith monkeypox virus infection in a household setting. No cases of\nmonkeypox that could be attributed exclusively to person-to-person contact\nhave been confirmed.\nUse of Smallpox Vaccine\n-----------------------\nTo prevent further transmission of monkeypox, 26 residents of 5 states have\nreceived smallpox vaccine since 13 Jun 2003; recipients included 24 adults\nand 2 children. Vaccine was administered to 2 laboratory workers\npre-exposure and to 24 persons post-exposure (11 health-care workers, 7\nhousehold contacts, 3 laboratory workers, 2 public health veterinarians,\nand one work contact). One adult who was vaccinated as a child did not have\na major vaccine reaction or 'take' 7 days after vaccination and required\nrevaccination.\nCDC has issued updated interim guidance on the use of smallpox vaccine,\ncidofovir, and vaccinia immune globulin for prevention and treatment in the\nsetting of an outbreak of monkeypox (3). Principal changes in the updated\nguidance include a revision of the definition of close contact with an ill\nanimal, recommendations for vaccination of clinical laboratory workers\nhandling specimens from ill animals and persons infected with monkeypox\nvirus, and instructions for reporting smallpox vaccine-related serious\nadverse events to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS).\nHealth-care providers, veterinarians, and public health officials who\nsuspect monkeypox in animals or humans should report such cases to their\nstate and local health departments. State health departments should report\nsuspect cases to CDC, telephone 770-488-7100. Clinical specimens should be\nsubmitted for testing after consultation with the state and local health\ndepartment. Interpretation of laboratory results requires completion of\nspecimen submission forms, which are available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/diagspecimens.htm>. Additional\ninformation about monkeypox is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox>.\nReported by State and local health departments. Monkeypox investigation\nteam, CDC.\nReferences:\n----------\n1. CDC. Multistate outbreak of monkeypox---Illinois, Indiana, and\nWisconsin, 2003. MMWR 2003;52:537--40.\n2. CDC. Update: multistate outbreak of monkeypox---Illinois, Indiana,\nKansas, Missouri, Ohio, and Wisconsin, 2003. MMWR 2003;52:561--4.\n3. CDC. Interim guidance for use of smallpox vaccine, cidofovir, and VIG\nfor prevention and treatment in the setting of an outbreak of monkeypox\ninfections. Available at <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/clinicians.htm>.\nAcknowledgments:\n----------------\nThis report is based on data contributed by MG Anderson, MD, Crusader\nClinic; S Homann, MD, Rockford Infectious Disease Consultants, Rockford; L\nFrenkel, Dept of Pediatrics, Univ of Illinois, Chicago, Illinois.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Results of testing the rodents presumed to be the cause of the outbreak\nare still lacking, leaving the precise origin of the outbreak\nunresolved. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Principal changes in the updated\nguidance include a revision of the definition of close contact with an ill\nanimal, recommendations for vaccination of clinical laboratory workers\nhandling specimens from ill animals and persons infected with monkeypox\nvirus, and instructions for reporting smallpox vaccine-related serious\nadverse events to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 26 Jun 2003\n Source: Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, Fri 27 Jun 2003 /\n52(25);589-590 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5225a4.htm>\n\nUpdate: Multistate Outbreak of Monkeypox --- Illinois, Indiana, Kansas,\nMissouri, Ohio, and Wisconsin, 2003\n Vaccine was administered to 2 laboratory workers\npre-exposure and to 24 persons post-exposure (11 health-care workers, 7\nhousehold contacts, 3 laboratory workers, 2 public health veterinarians,\nand one work contact). Both confirmed\ncases demonstrated 'significant viremia at the vesiculo-pustular stage of\ndisease, which may indicate a poor prognosis and significant viral\nshedding.' The third patient was one of the first infected. All her\nlesions were already healed when we collected her blood, therefore it makes\nsense that she is no longer shedding virus. These are the first confirmed\ncases of monkeypox in the Republic of Congo (Brazzaville).\n\nThe fact that this epidemic is centered at the government hospital among\nclose contacts of health-care staff who have limited exposure to forest\nanimals, but ongoing exposure to patients with active lesions at the\nhospital, underscores the urgent need for administration of smallpox\nvaccine. We will do what we can using barrier methods, waste disposal,\npatient isolation, and ongoing training of staff in universal precautions\n(a misnomer, because the equipment needed for such precautions is not\nuniversally available) to try to prevent the human-to-human transmission\nthat is obviously occurring.\nIn talking with other health-care providers working in the Likouala region,\nit is clear that this disease has likely been present in the Likouala\nRegion for quite some time. This would make sense, given the fact that the\nclimate and living conditions of this inundated tropical rain forest region\nare virtually identical to those of Equateur Province in Democratic\nRepublic of Congo (DRC), which is located just across the Oubangui River\nfrom the Likouala Region in Republic of Congo, where the world's largest\nrecorded outbreak of human monkeypox infection occurred in 1996-97. There\nis significant daily interchange of foodstuffs, bush meat, and persons\nbetween the 2 countries. In fact one of the biggest bulk-food markets in\nImpfondo (district capital of the Likouala Region) is on a no-man's island\nin the middle of the River, located on the border between the 2 countries\n(we call it affectionately 'Market in the Middle'). There are also still\ntens of thousands of refugees from DRC Equateur Province living on the ROC\nbanks of the River. Many people in Impfondo have relatives living on both\nsides of the River. It is not at all uncommon for Congolese from ROC to\nplant gardens (for subsistence farming) in the forest in DRC and vice-versa.\nThis epidemic is not over. An 18 year old female was admitted to the\ngovernment hospital on Tue 24 Jun 2003. We appreciate all of your support\nand encouragement in trying to deal with this epidemic. Here in Congo, the\nUS Embassy staff has been very helpful, as have been the folks from the\nMinistry of Health, and the staff at the government hospital. We'd also\nlike to thank MSF-Holland in Brazzaville who just donated an initial supply\nof barrier/protection equipment.\nMore help is needed. As in many other places where monkeypox is known to\nbe transmitted to humans from indigenous species (not imported vectors), in\nImpfondo, there is no adequate facility or infrastructure to deal with this\nsituation. That's why we are here: striving to start a mission hospital,\nto help alleviate/prevent this kind of situation.\n--\nJoseph M. Harvey, MD, MPH&TM\nRebecca Harvey, RN\nLynne Learned, 2nd year Medical Student (UB)", "summary": "This would make sense, given the fact that the\nclimate and living conditions of this inundated tropical rain forest region\nare virtually identical to those of Equateur Province in Democratic\nRepublic of Congo (DRC), which is located just across the Oubangui River\nfrom the Likouala Region in Republic of Congo, where the world's largest\nrecorded outbreak of human monkeypox infection occurred in 1996-97. Dr. Harvey has worked for many years as a medical\nmissionary in Republic of Congo (Brazzaville), and he reports an\noutbreak of a disease that looks very much like smallpox in Impfondo,\na provincial capital in the northern part of that country. He has\nsent us some impressive photos of patients with pustular and\nvesicular lesions, all appearing to be at the same stage, with\numbilication. Some patients had significant lymphadenopathy. Unlike\nsmallpox, the mortality he describes in this outbreak so far has been\nlow, so monkeypox is a distinct possibility. This report is currently\nunconfirmed, but CDC is involved and is aiding in the investigation.\n--\nRichard A. Oberhelman, MD\nAssociate Professor of Tropical Medicine and Pediatrics,\nTulane School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine,\n1440 Canal Street, Suite 2210,\nNew Orleans, Louisiana 70112 U.S.A.\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 19 Jun 2003\nFrom: Dr. Joseph Harvey <JHarvey@UUPlus.com>\n\nDr. Joseph Harvey's Report [edited]\n-----------------------------------\nImpfondo is a remote, isolated town of approximately 45 000 people in\nthe center of the Congo Basin Rain Forest. Impfondo is the Capital\nof the Likouala Region, which is the northernmost region of the\nRepublic of Congo. Impfondo is located on the western banks of the\nOubangui River, a major tributary of the Congo River. It is\nsurrounded by dense tropical rain forest.\nMonkeypox is known to occur primarily in the rain forest countries of\nCentral and West Africa. People here do have frequent contact with\nforest animals, including monkeys, which are often used as bush-meat.\nVery limited, basic, village, lab facilities do exist in Impfondo,\nbut most of the 'labs' are chronically short on supplies and reagents.\nLast week (I believe it was Sat 14 Jun 2003), while driving through\nImpfondo, I saw an otherwise health-appearing young man (probably in\nhis early 20s) with multiple, widely-disseminated, impressive,\nhealing smallpox-like lesions walking on the sidewalk near Impfondo's\nbiggest market.\nThis evening, Thu 19 June 2003, Dr. Wassa-Wassa, Chief of Medicine\nand Pediatrics at the government hospital in Impfondo stopped by our\nhouse to request my assistance in educating the population about the\nneed for strict isolation procedures to prevent the spread of an\noutbreak of 'variola'. As soon as I heard about this, I went to the\nhospital to examine the patients. I examined 4 patients.\nIn the first private room: (1) An approximately 9-month old baby boy\nwith numerous widely-disseminated, healing, deep-seated, firm,\nwell-circumscribed\nround umbilicated and some coalescing lesions, all at the same stage\nof development. The child was listless, febrile, and had coryza. [I\nhave borrowed some of the descriptive terms from 'Evaluating Patients\nfor Smallpox' information guide Version 1.0: 31 Jan 2002 published by\nCDC, because they describe these cases perfectly]. (2) A 6 year-old\ngirl, (the baby's maternal aunt) with malaise and fever, and the same\nlesions in an earlier stage, more vesicle-like. (3) The 16 year-old\nmother of the baby (and older sister to patient #2) who had recovered\nfrom a similar illness, showing only rare, healed lesions. The mother\nreported that the index case was her 12-year old brother, who had\nalready been discharged from the hospital.\nIn a separate private room: (4) A 4 year-old boy (unrelated to the\nother patients, but living on the same hospital compound) with fewer\nsmaller, papular, widely-disseminated, firm, well-circumscribed round\nlesions. According to his mother, his illness began with a febrile\nprodrome 5 days ago, followed by the lesions 2 days ago. He has\nsignificant lymphadenopathy with a 3 cm node in the right anterior\ncervical region, and significant rhinorrhea and some cough. No\nhepatosplenomegaly. His father is the head nurse for the medical\nward, and they live on the hospital compound. His 10-year old\nsister died last week of a similar illness.\nI should note that the nurse on call who showed us to the patients'\nrooms did not have access to examination gloves, masks, protective\ngowns, goggles or face shields, running water, soap, bleach, or\nalcohol. The first room had no lights. The patients were being fed\nand attended to by several unprotected family members. Apparently the\nindex case (the younger brother of patient #3) was a 12-year old boy\nwho had traveled to a village 12 kms outside of Impfondo for Easter\nvacation. He got sick on 15 Apr 2003, and was hospitalized after\nreturning to Impfondo. He has since been discharged from the\nhospital. He lives on the hospital compound in the same house with\npatients 1, 2 and 3. His father is the physician's assistant in\ncharge of medicine and pediatrics. I was told by family members and\nhospital staff that there have been 10 cases, with one 10 year old\nchild who died last week. All of the cases treated at the hospital\nseem to be family members or close contacts of hospital staff that\nlive on the hospital compound.\nAfter examining the patients, I interviewed some of the staff\nmembers. Dr.Wassa-Wassa was very knowledgeable and extremely helpful.\nHe had taken photos of several patients, and sent them to his\nsuperiors in Brazzaville, trying to sound the alarm. Apparently the\nreply was that this must be varicella [chickenpox], because variola\n[smallox] had been eradicated years ago. I believe we are most likely\ndealing with a monkeypox outbreak (it is definitely not chickenpox),\nbut we can't be sure without viral laboratory studies which are\nunavailable in this region. I feel strongly that positive\nidentification of the causative agent should be pursued in a timely\nfashion. I would like to rule out smallpox, since people in this area\nhaven't been vaccinated in years, and given the high threat of\ninternational bioterrorism. If smallpox were to reoccur someday, or\nif it has remained undetected since 1977, it would probably show up\nin someplace like the Likouala Region, one of the most isolated spots\non earth.\nIt is clear that person-to-person spread of this infection is continuing to\noccur. Also, immediate measures need to be taken to prevent the spread of\nthis disease. These would include the institution of general infection\ncontrol precautions; e.g. according to the CDC Health Advisory (contained in\nHealth Alert Priority #44, dated 9 Jun 2003, from NY County of Erie\nDepartment of Health, Anthony J. Billittier IV, MD, FACEP,\nCommissioner of Health). I am planning to obtain serum and vesicular\nfluid samples from the active cases, and send them on the plane to\nBrazzaville tomorrow morning [Fri 20 Jun 2003].\n--\nJoseph M. Harvey, MD, MPH&TM\nDiplomate ABFP\nGO Mission Congo\nBP 24\nBrazzaville\nRepublic of Congo\n<JHarvey@UUPlus.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail greatly appreciates the receipt of this first-hand\nreport. The excellent clinical descriptions by Dr. Harvey are\ncertainly suggestive of monkeypox. Further information is awaited\nwith interest, in particular confirmation of the tentative diagnosis\nby laboratory testing. Dr. Richard Oberhelman has indicated that\nupdated information may be obtainable direct from Dr. Harvey. -\nMods.CP & LM]", "summary": "--\nRichard A. He has\nsent us some impressive photos of patients with pustular and\nvesicular lesions, all appearing to be at the same stage, with\numbilication. Dr. Harvey has worked for many years as a medical\nmissionary in Republic of Congo (Brazzaville), and he reports an\noutbreak of a disease that looks very much like smallpox in Impfondo,\na provincial capital in the northern part of that country. I should note that the nurse on call who showed us to the patients'\nrooms did not have access to examination gloves, masks, protective\ngowns, goggles or face shields, running water, soap, bleach, or\nalcohol. If smallpox were to reoccur someday, or\nif it has remained undetected since 1977, it would probably show up\nin someplace like the Likouala Region, one of the most isolated spots\non earth. All of the cases treated at the hospital\nseem to be family members or close contacts of hospital staff that\nlive on the hospital compound. I was told by family members and\nhospital staff that there have been 10 cases, with one 10 year old\nchild who died last week. The 16 year-old\nmother of the baby (and older sister to patient #2) who had recovered\nfrom a similar illness, showing only rare, healed lesions. (2) A 6 year-old\ngirl, (the baby's maternal aunt) with malaise and fever, and the same\nlesions in an earlier stage, more vesicle-like. The mother\nreported that the index case was her 12-year old brother, who had\nalready been discharged from the hospital. I would like to rule out smallpox, since people in this area\nhaven't been vaccinated in years, and given the high threat of\ninternational bioterrorism. He has\nsignificant lymphadenopathy with a 3 cm node in the right anterior\ncervical region, and significant rhinorrhea and some cough. Unlike\nsmallpox, the mortality he describes in this outbreak so far has been\nlow, so monkeypox is a distinct possibility. I am planning to obtain serum and vesicular\nfluid samples from the active cases, and send them on the plane to\nBrazzaville tomorrow morning", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "smallpox", "varicella", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-04-15 00:00:00", "2003-06-19 00:00:00", "2002-01-31 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "1440-03-26 00:00:00", "1977-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NY County of Erie \n Department of Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Impfondo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazzaville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Orleans", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204135", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Monkeypox, human, prairie dogs - USA (15)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204135", "date": "2003-07-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX, HUMAN, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (15)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 10 Jul 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, Fri 11 Jul 2003\n/52(27);642-646. [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5227a5.htm>\n\nUpdate: Multistate Outbreak of Monkeypox --- Illinois, Indiana, Kansas,\nMissouri, Ohio, and Wisconsin, 2003\n------------------------------------------------\nCDC and state and local health departments continue to investigate cases of\nmonkeypox among persons in the United States who had contact with wild or\nexotic mammalian pets or with persons with monkeypox (1, 2, 3, 4). This\nreport updates results of the epidemiologic investigation, provides\ninformation on the use of smallpox vaccine during the outbreak, and\nsummarizes the animal tracing activities to identify the origin and\nsubsequent distribution of infected animals.\nEpidemiologic Investigation\n---------------------------\nAs of Tue 8 Jul 2003, a total of 71 cases of monkeypox have been reported\nto CDC from Wisconsin (39), Indiana (16), Illinois (12), Missouri (2),\nKansas (one), and Ohio (one); these include 35 (49 percent) cases\nlaboratory-confirmed at CDC and 36 (51 percent) suspect and probable cases\nunder investigation by state and local health departments. 11 cases were\nexcluded from those reported previously because they met the exclusion\ncriteria outlined in the updated national case definition, and one new case\nwas added (1). The number of cases increased from 15 May 2003 through the\nweek ending 8 Jun 2003 and declined subsequently; the date of onset for the\nlast case was 20 Jun 2003.\nOf the 71 cases, 39 (55 percent) occurred among females; the median age was\n28 years (range: 1 to 51 years). Age data were unavailable for one patient.\nAmong 69 patients for whom data were available, 18 (26 percent) were\nhospitalized; some patients were hospitalized for isolation precautions\nonly. 2 patients, both children, had serious clinical illness (1, 2, 3, 4);\nboth of these patients have recovered. The majority of patients were\nexposed to prairie dogs. Some patients were exposed in premises where\nprairie dogs were kept, and others were exposed to persons with monkeypox.\nNo patients have been confirmed to have had exposure to persons with\nmonkeypox as their only possible exposure.\nOf the 35 laboratory-confirmed cases, 32 (91 percent) tested positive for\nmonkeypox by polymerase chain reaction (PCR), culture, immunohistochemical\ntesting (IHC), and/or electron microscopy in skin rash lesions; two tested\npositive by PCR and/or culture of an oropharyngeal or nasopharyngeal swab;\nand one tested positive by PCR and culture of a lymph node aspirate. For\nlaboratory-confirmed cases, onset of illness ranged from 16 May to 20 Jun\n2003. The majority of patients reported a clinical illness that included\nrash (one patient had a single, atypical plaque-like skin lesion) and\nfever. The median incubation period* was 12 days (range: 1 to 31 days).\nUse of Smallpox Vaccine\n-----------------------\nTo prevent transmission of monkeypox, 30 persons (28 adults and 2 children)\nin 6 states have received smallpox vaccine since 13 Jun 2003. Vaccine was\nadministered pre-exposure to 7 persons (3 veterinarians, 2 laboratory\nworkers, and 2 health-care workers) and post-exposure to 23 persons (10\nhealth-care workers, 7 household contacts, 3 laboratory workers, one public\nhealth veterinarian, one public health epidemiologist, and one work\ncontact). No serious adverse events were reported following smallpox\nvaccination, and no requests for vaccinia immune globulin have been\nreceived. Among the 30 persons who received smallpox vaccine, 3 (10\npercent) reported rash within 2 weeks of vaccination. One of the 3 was\nconfirmed as having monkeypox; another person had 2 skin lesion specimens\nthat tested negative for orthopoxvirus and varicella zoster virus at the\nstate health laboratory; no specimens were obtained for the third person\nwho reported a single, dime-sized, pruritic and erythematous skin lesion\n(not pustular) remote from the vaccination site that appeared 4 days after\nvaccination and faded within a week.\nAnimal Traceback and Trace-Forward Investigations\n------------------------------------------------\nTraceback investigations have determined that all 35 confirmed human cases\nof monkeypox were associated with prairie dogs obtained from an Illinois\nanimal distributor (IL-1), or from animal distributors who purchased\nprairie dogs from IL-1 [The text is accompanied by an excellent diagram\nwhich cannot be reproduced here, but should be consulted for better\nappreciation of the situation. - Mod.CP]. Traceback of animal exposures are\nongoing for other cases. Prairie dogs at IL-1 appear to have been infected\nthrough contact with Gambian giant rats and dormice that originated in\nGhana and were purchased on 21 Apr 2003 by IL-1. Approximately 200 prairie\ndogs had been at the IL-1 facility during the period April to May; an\nunspecified number overlapped with the arrival of the imported African\nrodents on 21 Apr 2003 and probably were exposed to monkeypox. A total of\n93 infected or potentially infected prairie dogs were traced from IL-1 to 6\nstates; in addition, an unknown number of prairie dogs died or were\nreportedly sold (as pets for sale or exchange) at animal swap meets for\nwhich no records were available for tracing. At CDC, laboratory testing of\n4 prairie dogs originating from IL-1 confirmed the presence of monkeypox\nvirus by PCR and IHC.\nTraceback investigations to identify the source of introduction of\nmonkeypox into the United States identified a Texas animal distributor\n(TX-1) that had imported a shipment of approximately 800 small mammals from\nGhana on 9 Apr 2003 that contained 762 African rodents, including rope\nsquirrels (_Funiscuirus_ sp.), tree squirrels (_Heliosciurus_ sp.), Gambian\ngiant rats (_Cricetomys_ sp.), brushtail porcupines (_Atherurus_ sp.),\ndormice (_Graphiurus_ sp.), and striped mice (_Hybomys_ sp.). CDC\nlaboratory testing of some animals from this shipment confirmed the\npresence of monkeypox by PCR and virus isolation in several rodent species,\nincluding one Gambian rat, 3 dormice, and 2 rope squirrels (1).\nTrace-forward investigations of the rodents on the shipment were initiated\nbefore the availability of laboratory results because of concerns that\nanimals were a potential source of continued spread of monkeypox. Of the\n762 rodents from the original shipment, 584 (77 percent) have been traced\nto distributors in 6 states. A total of 178 (23 percent) African rodents\ncould not be traced beyond the point of entry in Texas because records were\nnot available. No suspect, probable, or confirmed cases of human monkeypox\nhave been associated with direct contact with the African rodents from the\n9 Apr 2003 shipment. In addition, other than the prairie dogs traced from\nIL-1 to subsequent sites, no cases of monkeypox in other animals that had\ncontact with the African rodents from the 9 Apr 2003 shipment have been\nreported.\n(Reported by: State and local health departments. Monkeypox investigation\nteam, CDC.)\nMMWR Editorial Note\n-------------------\nThe outbreak described in this report highlights the public health threat\nposed by importation, for commercial purposes, of exotic pets into the\nUnited States. Epidemiologic and animal traceback investigations confirm\nthat the first community-acquired human cases of monkeypox in the United\nStates resulted from contact with infected prairie dogs that had been\nhoused or transported with African rodents imported from Ghana.\nImported, exotic wild animals can carry non-indigenous, zoonotic pathogens,\nwhich can spread rapidly among indigenous susceptible animal populations in\nthe United States, particularly when mixed together in close proximity. In\naddition, inter-species exchange of pathogens is possible because of close\nrelations between humans and their pets. In this outbreak, the rapid and\nwidespread distribution of monkeypox-infected and potentially infected\nimported wild animals to distributors and potential buyers in several\nsettings (e.g., pet stores, swap meets, and wild animal trade centers) in\nthe United States and to other countries enabled epizootic spread through\nmultiple states before effective interventions could be implemented.\nPublic health strategies to control this outbreak, including the Food and\nDrug Administration-CDC joint order banning importation and prohibiting\nmovement of the implicated animal species, state-enacted measures to\nfurther restrict intrastate animal shipment and trade (4), premise\nquarantine, and animal euthanasia, appear to have been effective in\nreducing exposure of humans to infected animals, with few cases reported\nsince its implementation on 11 Jun 2003. Additional control measures have\nincluded pre- and post-exposure vaccination of potentially exposed persons\nwith smallpox vaccine (5).\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/pdf/embargo.pdf>)\nLaboratory tests have demonstrated the presence of monkeypox virus in\nseveral rodents from the original shipment from Ghana that died\nunexpectedly and did not exhibit characteristic signs of monkeypox in\nanimals (e.g., conjunctivitis, lymphadenopathy, and skin lesions). For this\nreason, CDC guidance for premise quarantine and animal euthanasia is based\non the possibility that infected rodents from the 9 Apr 2003 shipment could\nbe asymptomatic, shed virus, and potentially cause infection in other\nsusceptible animals or humans.\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/quarantineremoval.htm>)\nAlthough no human monkeypox cases have been associated with contact with\nrodents from the 9 Apr 2003 shipment, these animals are considered to pose\na continued risk for infection for other animals and humans. Euthanasia,\nfollowing American Veterinary Medical Association guidelines, is\nrecommended for all rodents from the 9 Apr 2003 shipment and for any\nprairie dogs that were on the premises at the same time as any of the\nAfrican rodents.\n(<http://www.avma.org/noah/members/policy/default.asp>)\nIn addition, mammals in facilities that housed a rodent from the 9 Apr 2003\nshipment should be placed under quarantine for 6 weeks following the last\ndate a rodent of concern was present. Efforts are underway to collect\nadditional epidemiologic and laboratory data on both human and animal cases\nand their contacts, including animal handlers who might have been exposed\nto infected rodents.\nImportation of exotic animals and indigenous, wild animals harvested for\nthe commercial pet trade have been associated with previous outbreaks of\ninfectious diseases in humans, including salmonella associated with\nreptiles (e.g., lizards, snakes, and turtles) and tularemia associated with\nprairie dogs (6, 7); prairie dogs also have been documented to be infected\nwith other human pathogens (e.g., plague) (8). The Institute of Medicine\nrecently highlighted the role of international travel and commerce in the\nemergence of infectious diseases through the dissemination of pathogens and\ntheir vectors throughout the world (9). CDC and other federal agencies, in\ncollaboration with state and local health departments and professional\norganizations, are developing long-term strategies to coordinate the\ncontrol of importation, exportation, interstate trade, and intrastate sale\nof exotic and native wild animals (10).\nHealth-care providers, veterinarians, and public health officials who\nsuspect monkeypox in animals or humans should report such cases to their\nstate and local health departments. State health departments should report\nsuspect cases to CDC, telephone 770-488-7100. An updated case definition\nwith revised case exclusion criteria is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/index.htm>. Rash illnesses suspected\nto be monkeypox should be confirmed by laboratory evaluation. Clinical\nspecimens should be submitted for testing after consultation with the state\nand local health departments. Protocols for specimen collection, including\ncompletion of specimen submission forms, should follow CDC guidance\navailable at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/diagspecimens.htm>.\nBecause information included in the specimen-submission and case-reporting\nforms is essential for accurate interpretation of laboratory results, these\nforms should be completed by state health departments. Preferred specimens\nfor testing are those from skin lesions. Because smallpox vaccine might\nmodify monkeypox disease, evaluation of any rash post-vaccination in a\nperson exposed to monkeypox should include laboratory testing for monkeypox\nvirus.\nReferences\n----------\n1. USA (10): Kentucky", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204000", "date": "2003-06-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX, HUMAN, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (10): KENTUCKY\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 17 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Courier-Journal, Tue 17 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.courier-journal.com/localnews/2003/06/17ky/met-front-monkey0617-5853.html>\n\nKentucky: 5 new cases of suspected monkeypox bring total to 6\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nAs Kentucky health officials investigated up to 5 new suspected cases of\nmonkeypox, governor Paul Patton yesterday banned the importation into the\nstate of most rodents, primates, and rabbits. Only zoos and research\nlaboratories will be permitted to bring in these animals under the\ngovernor's executive order, which also requires the state Agriculture\nDepartment to quarantine any potential source of the unusual viral disease.\nThe state Department for Public Health announced that 3 members of a\nWestern Kentucky household had developed rashes, fever, and cold-like\nsymptoms after exposure to prairie dogs from a Paducah pet store. The 3,\nand 2 other family members who also came into contact with the animals,\nhave agreed to remain isolated at home, pending the outcome of tests by the\nUS Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\nKentucky's first suspected case of monkeypox, reported on Fri 13 Jun 2003,\nwas a woman who had handled prairie dogs in the same pet store. The store\nhad received degus [a rodent similar to the chinchilla] and squirrels \u0097-\nbut not prairie dogs \u0097- from a pet supplier in Illinois. Infected prairie\ndogs from the Illinois supplier have been linked to an outbreak of\nmonkeypox in the Midwest \u0097- the first known cases in the western\nhemisphere. The prairie dogs were apparently infected at the Illinois\nsupplier by a Gambian giant rat that had been imported from Africa, where\nmonkeypox was first identified in 1970.\nThe disease is related to smallpox and causes similar rashes and blisters,\nbut it is less serious and less easily spread. None of the 12 confirmed US\ncases \u0097- four each in Indiana, Illinois, and Wisconsin \u0097- has been fatal.\nAs of noon yesterday, CDC reported that 82 cases were being investigated in\nIllinois, Indiana, Missouri, Ohio, and Wisconsin, but the suspected cases\nin Kentucky are not included in that total. Like the initial suspected case\n[in Kentucky], the new ones are not serious, said Gwenda Bond, a\nspokeswoman for the Cabinet for Health Services. She said there were two\npossible sources of exposure in the new cases: family members had contact\nwith prairie dogs at the pet store and with a neighbor's prairie dog that\nwas purchased at the pet store. Bond said neither the neighbor's prairie\ndog nor any of the 11 others sold by the store since it opened last month\nhave shown signs of illness. Denise Marshall, the store's owner, said that,\ndespite publicity about monkeypox, customers are still coming in asking to\nbuy prairie dogs, which have become a popular pet.\nThe governor's executive order prohibits the importation of rodents,\nrabbits, and primates for distribution to the public. The ban is more\nfar-reaching than one issued last week by the Department of Fish and\nWildlife Resources, which applied only to non-domesticated animals. The\norder also requires the Agriculture Department to quarantine any potential\nsource of monkeypox until suspect animals have been either isolated or\neuthanized, and the site has been cleaned and disinfected under the\ndepartment's supervision. The order gives the animal owner the option of\nisolating the animals for 30 days or surrendering them to the Agriculture\nDepartment or the Department of Fish and Wildlife Resources. The governor\nalso authorized the Department for Public Health to 'take any and all\nappropriate measures' if a human case of monkeypox is confirmed in Kentucky.\nAgriculture officials balked last week at issuing a quarantine on the\nPaducah pet store, which had been requested by Fish and Wildlife, but the\ngovernor's order, which followed a meeting yesterday among officials of the\n3 agencies involved, appears to have resolved the dispute. Bond said the\norder clarifies the agencies' roles. 'This is such a unique situation, and\nthere are a lot of overlapping powers,' she said. Agriculture officials\ncould not be reached late yesterday, and it was unclear whether the agency\nhad taken any steps to implement the quarantine.\n(byline: Gideon Gil)\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It is not clear from this report whether the prairie dogs, the humans, or\nboth, are being tested for presence of monkeypox virus. Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2003; 52(24): 561-4, Fri 20 Jun [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5224a1.htm>\n\nUpdate: Multistate Outbreak of Monkeypox: Illinois, Indiana, Kansas,\nMissouri, Ohio, and Wisconsin, 2003\n-----------------------------------------\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and state and local\nhealth departments continue to investigate cases of monkeypox among people\nwho had close contact with wild or exotic mammalian pets or people with\nmonkeypox (1). This report updates epidemiological, laboratory, and animal\ndata for US cases.\nEpidemiological investigation\n-----------------------------\nAs of 18 Jun 2003, a total of 87 cases of monkeypox have been reported to\nCDC from Wisconsin (38), Indiana (24), Illinois (19), Ohio (4), Kansas (1),\nand Missouri (1). Of the 87 cases, 41 were males. The median age for the 82\npatients for whom age data were available was 28 years (range: 1 to 55\nyears). Data on symptom onset were available for 78 persons [shown\ngraphically in the original report]).\nAmong the 75 patients for whom data were available, 20 were admitted to\nhospital. The majority of patients were not seriously ill; some were\nadmitted to facilitate proper isolation.\nTwenty cases were laboratory confirmed at CDC [data tabulated in the\noriginal report]. Among these 20, one was a child admitted to hospital with\nsevere encephalitis 3 days after developing a vesicular rash, which was\noriginally thought to be varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Diagnostic testing\nfor VZV and for herpes simplex virus in serum, cerebrospinal fluid, and\nskin lesion biopsy was negative. A skin lesion biopsy was positive for\nmonkeypox DNA by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and for orthopox antigens\nby immunohistochemical (IHC) testing.\nThe majority of patients had direct or close contact with wild or exotic\nmammals such as prairie dogs (_Cynomys_ sp.). In one instance, 28 children\nattending a day care facility in Indiana were potentially exposed to 2\nprairie dogs that subsequently became ill and died; 12 reported handling or\npetting the prairie dogs, and 7 subsequently became ill with symptoms\nconsistent with monkeypox infection. Laboratory evaluation of these\nchildren is in progress.\nLaboratory investigation\n------------------------\nClinical specimens obtained from 82 patients in Illinois, Indiana, Ohio,\nand Wisconsin were forwarded to CDC for testing. Twenty of 27 patients with\nskin rash-lesion specimens were laboratory confirmed for monkeypox by viral\nisolation, PCR, electron microscopy, and/or IHC; four were negative for\nmonkeypox virus; one patient was found to have varicella by PCR testing;\nand 2 are pending. Two health care workers in Wisconsin who were suspected\ninitially of acquiring disease by human-to-human transmission had no\nevidence of monkeypox-specific DNA signatures in blood and nasopharyngeal\nand/or oropharyngeal swabs; culture results are pending. These people did\nnot have a rash, and IgM testing has not revealed any anti-orthopoxvirus\nimmune reactivity.\nAnimal investigation\n--------------------\nTraceback investigations of animals are ongoing to identify how monkeypox\nvirus was introduced into the US. Preliminary results have determined that\nan animal vendor in Wisconsin (distributor A) sold prairie dogs to the\nindex patient in Wisconsin; this vendor had obtained prairie dogs from an\nanimal vendor in Illinois (distributor B), who had housed prairie dogs and\nGambian giant rats (_Cricetomys_ sp.) in close proximity.\nBecause Gambian giant rats often are imported from regions of Africa where\nmonkeypox is endemic, traceback investigations of the Gambian giant rats\nwere initiated. These investigations identified a shipment of animals from\nGhana, including Gambian giant rats that were delivered to a Texas animal\nimporter (distributor C) on 9 Apr 2003. Distributor C's Gambian giant rats\nwere sold subsequently to an Iowa animal vendor on 15 Apr 2003 (distributor\nD) who in turn supplied them to distributor B. The shipment of animals from\nGhana contained about 800 small mammals of nine different species,\nincluding 6 genera of African rodents that might have been the source of\nintroduction of monkeypox. These rodent genera included rope squirrels\n(_Funiscuirus_ sp.), tree squirrels (_Heliosciurus_ sp.), Gambian giant\nrats, brushtail porcupines (_Atherurus_ sp.), dormice (_Graphiurus_ sp.),\nand striped mice (_Hybomys_ sp.). Laboratory testing of animals from the 9\nApr 2003 importation from Africa is underway to determine which, if any,\nanimals in the shipment might have introduced the virus into the US.\nOn the basis of the epidemiological link between the shipment from Ghana\nand distributor B, trace-forward investigations have been initiated to\nlocate animal vendors and owners who purchased imported African rodents\nfrom the 9 Apr 2003 shipment or purchased prairie dogs from distributors A,\nB, C, and D after 15 Apr 2003. In addition to routine sales by animal\nvendors, animals also were sold or traded at 'swap meets' (that is,\ngatherings of animal traders, exhibitors, and buyers). An investigation of\ndistributor B revealed that infected prairie dogs from this animal vendor\nmight have been sold or traded at swap meets to unidentified buyers in\nSchaumburg, Illinois, on 20 Apr 2003, 3 May 2003, and 18 May 2003;\nIndianapolis, Indiana, on 27 Apr 2003 and 18 May 2003; and Columbus, Ohio,\non 19 Apr 2003. In addition, distributor A sold infected prairie dogs at a\nswap meet in Wausau, Wisconsin, on 11 May 2003. In several instances,\nidentifying individuals who purchased animals has been impossible. Invoices\nand other records are incomplete for many of these sales, especially those\ntransacted at swap meets.\n(Reported by: CW Langkop, C Austin, M Dworkin, K Kelly, Illinois Dept of\nPublic Health. H Messersmith, R Teclaw, J Howell, J Michael, P Pontones,\nIndiana State Dept of Health. Monkeypox Investigation Team, G Pezzino, GR\nHansen, Kansas Dept of Health and Environment. Monkeypox Investigation\nTeam, MV Wegner, JJ Kazmierczak, C Williams, DR Croft, S Ahrabi-Fard, L\nWill, HH Bostrom, JP Davis, Wisconsin Dept of Health and Family Svcs.,\nMonkeypox Investigation Team; A Fleischauer, M Sotir, G Huhn, R Kanwal, J\nKile, J Sejvar, EIS officers, CDC.)\nMMWR editorial note\n-------------------\nPreliminary findings from these investigations suggest that the primary\nroute of monkeypox transmission to humans is from close contact with\ninfected wild and exotic mammalian pets. Person-to-person transmission has\nnot been identified in this outbreak. Investigations are underway to assess\nthe possibility of secondary transmission among health care workers and\nhousehold contacts exposed to patients with laboratory-confirmed monkeypox\ninfection.\nCompared with previous reports of monkeypox among persons in central Africa\n(2), the illness associated with the current outbreak in the US has been\nrelatively mild. Monkeypox infection in adults has been described rarely in\nAfrica; among adults, previous vaccination against smallpox might attenuate\nclinical illness (3). The report of encephalitis in a child indicates the\npotentially serious consequences of the disease.\nBecause suspected cases of monkeypox might actually represent varicella\ninfections, patients should be assessed for history of varicella or having\nreceived varicella vaccine. Rash illness suspected to be monkeypox should\nbe confirmed by laboratory evaluation, particularly if use of smallpox\nvaccine is being considered for purposes of monkeypox outbreak control. CDC\nhas issued interim recommendations for use of smallpox vaccine, cidofovir,\nand vaccinia immune globulin (VIG) for prevention and treatment in the\nsetting of outbreaks of monkeypox infections (4).\nHealth care providers, veterinarians, and public health officials who\nsuspect monkeypox in animals or humans should report such cases to their\nstate and local health departments. CDC requests that reports of suspect\ncases from state health departments be directed to the CDC Emergency\nOperations Center, telephone 770-488-7100. Additional information about\nmonkeypox, including a revised interim case definition [attached to the\nabove report and available at <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox>.\nReferences:\n(1) CDC. The\ninformation available cannot exclude the possibility that contamination of\nprairie dogs is linked to contacts with rodents of non domestic species\n(Gambian rat) imported from Africa where the disease is endemic. The known\nreservoirs in the endemic zone are squirrels and rodents of non domestic\nspecies in the African rain forest. (Gambian rat) imported from Africa where the disease is endemic.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "smallpox", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-06-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203977", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Monkeypox, human, prairie dogs - USA (07): transmission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203977", "date": "2003-06-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX, HUMAN, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (07): TRANSMISSION\n*****************************************\nA proMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 13 Jun 2003\nFrom: Richard Knox <rknox@npr.org>\nSource: National Public Radio News, Fri 13 Jun 2003 [edited]\n\nWisconsin: 3 suspected cases of human-to-human transmission of monkeypox\n---------------------------------------------------------\nSo far the US outbreak of monkeypox has involved people who got infected\nfrom pets. Now National Public Radio (NPR) has learned that Wisconsin\nofficials are investigating at least 3 possible cases of human-to-human\ninfection. If confirmed, experts say the cases will pose new challenges for\npublic health.\nFrom experience in Africa, where monkeypox sometimes causes epidemics,\nexperts in infectious disease already knew that monkeypox can be transmitted\nfrom one person to another. But they hoped it would be mainly an animal-to-\nhuman disease in this country. Yesterday there were signs they may be\ndisappointed. Dr. John Melski of Wisconsin's Marshfield Clinic says the very\nfirst American case of monkeypox -- a 4-year-old child -- may have infected\none of her caregivers. 'A medical assistant at the Mansfield Clinic who acts\nvery much like a nurse had contact with the index case, the young child, long\nbefore we knew what disease she had. But she did have direct contact and did\nhold the child on 22 May 2003. 19 days later -- this Tuesday -- the medical\nassistant developed chills, sweats and fatigue. The next day, one of her\nclose contacts got sick too. Her boyfriend on the 11 Jun 2003 had some\ngeneralized aches and pains and experienced shaking chills with sweats. And\nhe has approximately 6 skin lesions.' Neither case has been confirmed yet as\nmonkeypox.\nMeanwhile, a nurse in Milwaukee came down with flu-like symptoms and a rash\nafter caring for a pet distributor with suspected monkeypox.\nThe cases are under investigation by state and federal health authorities.\nDr. David Daigle, a spokesman for the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention (CDC), said that: 'We know that human-to-human spread can occur.\nBut it's not the most efficient method of transmission. Monkeypox can be\nspread by direct contact with body fluids, an infected person, or virus\ncontaminated objects such as beds or clothing.' Dr. Daigle stated that the\nCDC had already warned health care workers to treat suspected monkeypox cases\nas though they were dangerously infectious. But the Milwaukee nurse\nreportedly wore a mask, gloves and gown when she treated the pet dealer.\nMelski says he and his colleagues are debating whether they should get\nsmallpox vaccine to reduce their risk of monkeypox. The CDC has advised\nvaccination for health care workers who have 'unprotected contact' with\npossible cases. Melski said that: 'We need to know the details of what\nexactly unprotected contact means. Does it mean you breathed the same air\nthat the patient breathed? How close? Same hall? Same room? Or does it mean\ncontact with body fluids -- which to the best of my knowledge makes the most\nsense from what we know so far. But obviously no one knows all of the\nanswers.'\n--\nRichard Knox\n<RKnox@npr.org>\n[The evidence for human-to-human transmission of monkepox in the USA is still\ncircumstantial and confirmation of its reality must await the outcome of\nlaboratory diagnostic test. - Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: 'Douglas E Docherty' <doug_docherty@usgs.gov>\nComments and Questions\n----------------------\nI followed with great interest the ProMED-mail posts on the outbreak of\nmonkeypox in the Midwest. I am concerned with both the human and North\nAmerican wildlife potential of this virus. After reading the posts I have\nthe following comments and questions about the information presented, and\nwould greatly appreciate it if someone currently close to these cases could\naddress them.\n1. Has it been determined that the Gambian giant rat ('which apparently\ncarried the virus') had monkeypox, or was it assumed to be the source because\nof its African origin? If it is not determined to be the source, perhaps the\nvirus came from somewhere else along the prairie dog 'pipeline' to the\ndistributor/pet owner.\n2. Were the carcasses of the prairie dogs that the distributor\nvoluntarily 'put to death' disposed of in a way that would make the virus non-\ninfectious to any rodents that might investigate or consume those carcasses?\n3. In northwest Missouri, the 38-year-old\nvictim bought a prairie dog from Phil's Pocket Pets, in Villa Park, Illinois,\nwhere a number of other infected prairie dogs were sold, said Mary Menges,\nadministrator for communicable diseases at Missouri's Department of Health\nand Senior Services. 'His prairie dog became ill and died; then he became\nill,' Menges said. The man's symptoms were typical of monkeypox, she said,\nand included fever, body aches, swollen lymph nodes and pustules. The man,\nwho has not been identified publicly, has agreed to remain isolated in his\nhome, and 'he is doing quite well,' Menges said. The man will remain isolated\nuntil his symptoms are gone and the monkeypox scabs have fallen off, which\ncould take 2-3 weeks, she said. Tissue samples taken from the man have been\nsent to the CDC in Atlanta for confirmation, 'but on our preliminary test it\nwas positive,' she said.\nOn Sat 14 Jun 2003, the CDC issued new case numbers for the disease. As of\nSaturday morning, before the Missouri case was reported, 79 cases were being\ninvestigated, 17 of them confirmed, said CDC spokeswoman Kathy Harben. They\ninclude: 34 in Wisconsin, 17 in Illinois, 26 in Indiana and 2 in Ohio, she\nsaid.\nMonkeypox symptoms include chills and cough, followed by a rash and sometimes\ndiarrhea, sore throat and mouth sores. Because the symptoms are so common,\nmonkeypox is easily confused with other illnesses.\nAbout 16 children at a day care center in Adams County, Indiana, as well as\nthe woman who runs the center, are among suspected cases of monkeypox in that\nstate, said Dr. Brian Zurcher, a health officer for Adams County. The owner's\ndaughter has been hospitalized and is 'extremely ill,' he said. None of the\nother children was hospitalized, and all have recovered, he said. The family\nthat owns the center had bought 2 prairie dogs that had come from the\ncontaminated group, and used them to entertain and teach the 18 children\nenrolled there, he said. He would not identify the center. 'About 80 percent\nof the children in the day care had some signs or symptoms consistent with\nmonkeypox,' Zurcher said. Specimens from the children have been sent to the\nCDC.\nThe monkeypox outbreak is believed to have begun with a shipment of more than\n800 rodents, including 50 Gambian giant pouched rats, from Africa to a\ndistributor in Texas. The rats are believed to have passed the disease to the\nprairie dogs, which were then sold or traded in the Midwest.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 15 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York Times, Sat 14 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/14/national/14POX.html>\n\nWisconsin: One Prairie Dog Has Played Critical Role in Transmission\n----------------------------------------------\nContact with one prairie dog has accounted for more than half of the 34 human\ncases of monkeypox in Wisconsin, a state health official said on Fri 13 Jun\n2003. The people affected in 18 cases in Wisconsin -- 3 confirmed, 6 probable\nand 9 suspected -- were exposed to the prairie dog as it was moved from place\nto place, said Dr. Jeffrey P. Davis, the Wisconsin state epidemiologist. 'The\nprairie dog was moved quite a bit from a pet store to a household to one\nveterinary clinic and then to a second veterinary clinic before it died,' Dr.\nDavis said.\nThe virus that causes monkeypox is usually transmitted by contact with\nlesions on the skin. But federal health officials have recommended that\nhealth care workers use protections against the possibility of airborne\ntransmission. Wisconsin officials said that in a small number of cases those\nwho got the virus from an animal did not appear to have had direct contact\nwith that animal. One Wisconsin resident who apparently caught monkeypox from\nthe prairie dog had 'minimal' contact with the infected animal but slept in\nthe same room as the caged animal, Dr. Davis said. Also, 'a substantial\nnumber of individuals in one particular veterinary clinic became ill as a\nresult of' direct contact, Dr. Davis said. 'We are trying to understand what\nthat all means, precisely what the contact was. There certainly was a lot of\ntransmission associated with the movement of this animal from place to place\nand with contact with this animal, once the animal was in those settings,'\nDr. Davis said.\nEpidemiologists are tracing prairie dogs and other animals that were sold or\ntraded in the Upper Midwest as part of an investigation into the first ever\noutbreak of monkeypox in the Americas. At least 51 additional human\nmonkeypox cases are under investigation in 3 other states in the\noutbreak, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta said.\nThey include 33 in Indiana, 17 in Illinois and 1 in New Jersey [The New\nJersey Case has been discounted; the patient has chickenpox -- see ref. (08)\nbelow. - Mod.CP].\nThe number of cases under investigation in Wisconsin rose by 13 yesterday,\npartly as a result of the publicity that health officials are seeking in\nencouraging people to report any suspected illness. Of the 34 cases under\ninvestigation in Wisconsin, 14 occurred in veterinarians or veterinary\ntechnicians; 8 in exposure to animals in pet stores; 7 in people who had\ncontact with prairie dogs in a household; 3 who may have had exposure to\nprairie dogs in households other than their own; and 2 in health care\nworkers. Tests are pending on 3 suspected cases in which human-to-human\ntransmission of monkeypox may have occurred. Dr. Davis said it appeared\nunlikely that those cases would turn out to be monkeypox.\nSome suspected cases have arisen from people who visited pet stores where\ninfected animals had been housed. In one case, Dr. Davis said, a customer\nvisited a pet store for a substantial amount of time to buy a reptile. It is\nnot clear whether the customer handled an infected animal in the store. In\nanother case, a customer visited a pet store and did not have any contact\nwith prairie dogs, but had been scratched by another animal.\n[By: Larry Altman and Jo Napolitano]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "Of the 34 cases under\ninvestigation in Wisconsin, 14 occurred in veterinarians or veterinary\ntechnicians; 8 in exposure to animals in pet stores; 7 in people who had\ncontact with prairie dogs in a household; 3 who may have had exposure to\nprairie dogs in households other than their own; and 2 in health care\nworkers.
