Source: CNN online, Sat 14 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.cnn.com/2003/HEALTH/06/14/monkeypox/index.html>\n\nMissouri and Indiana: Suspected Cases of Monkeypox\n--------------------------------------", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2003-06-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Adams County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Villa Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203965", "headline": "PRO/AH> Monkeypox - USA: recommendations for vets", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203965", "date": "2003-06-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX \u00ad- USA: RECOMMENDATIONS FOR VETERINARIANS\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 11 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC website 11 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/animalguidance.htm>\n\n\nMonkeypox Infections In Animals: Interim Guidance for Veterinarians and Pet\nOwners\n------\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has been working\nclosely with state and local health department and other partners to\ninvestigate cases of monkeypox virus infection among humans who had direct\nor close contact with recently purchased ill prairie dogs, a Gambian\nrat, and a rabbit that was housed in a veterinary clinic with an ill\nprairie dog.\n\nAs of 7 Jun 2003, at least 6 persons with probable monkeypox infection have\nbeen reported to be veterinarians or staff at veterinary hospitals.\n\nHuman monkeypox is a rare zoonotic viral disease that occurs primarily in\nthe rain forest countries of central and west Africa. In humans, the\nillness produces a vesicular and pustular rash similar to that produced by\nsmallpox.\n\nThe incubation period from exposure to fever onset is about 12 days. In\nhumans, case-fatality ratios in Africa have ranged from 1 to 10 percent\n(for additional information about monkeypox, see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol7no3/hutin.htm>).\n\nThese interim guidelines will be updated as new information becomes\navailable and after consultation with additional public health partners.\n\nIn the current outbreak, illness in animals has been reported to include\nfever, cough, blepharoconjunctivitis, lymphadenopathy, followed by a\nnodular rash. Some animals have died while others reportedly recovered.\n\nThe types of animals that may become ill with monkeypox are currently\nunknown; as a precaution, all mammals should be considered susceptible at\nthis time.\n\nPet owners who suspect their animal may have an illness compatible with\nmonkeypox should immediately isolate the animal from humans and other\nanimals and contact their state or local health department. In most cases,\nevaluation by a veterinarian will be recommended. Owners should notify the\nveterinarian before transporting the animal to the clinic so that\nappropriate infection control precautions can be implemented prior to arrival.\n\nOwners should consider wearing a mask and gloves when handling the animal.\nThe animal\u0092s bedding should be collected and bagged and brought with the\nanimal to the veterinary clinic for disposal as medically regulated waste.\n\nSoiled bedding should not be disposed of as household trash. Following\nidentification of an animal with suspect monkeypox in a household, any\nanimals (including dogs and cats) who may have come in contact with the\nsick animal should be closely observed for signs of illness for a period of\n1 month following the last date of exposure. Contaminated household\nsurfaces should be cleaned and disinfected. Standard household\ncleaning/disinfectants may be used in accordance with manufacturer\u0092s\ninstructions.\n\nTransport of the ill animal to a veterinary clinic should be done by a\nsingle individual to limit unnecessary exposure. At the time of animal\ntransport, the owner should also transport the sick animal\u0092s bagged bedding\nfor disposal. Care should be taken to minimize driver exposure during\ntransport. During transport animals should be confined in a closed\ncontainer such as a cardboard box. If available, the animal should be\nconfined in a separate compartment of the vehicle, such as the bed of a\npickup truck. Following transport, the area of the vehicle where the animal\nwas confined should be cleaned and disinfected. Standard household\ncleaning/disinfectants may be used in accordance with the manufacturer\u0092s\ninstructions.\n\nVeterinarians examining sick prairie dogs, Gambian giant rats, or other\nmammals that may have come in contact with a suspected monkeypox case,\nshould consider the diagnosis of monkeypox infection. Animals that\ncurrently appear healthy but have been implicated as a probable source of\ninfection for a human case should also be treated as a suspected case of\nmonkeypox. All suspected cases of monkeypox in animals should be reported\nimmediately to state or local health department officials.\n\nVeterinarians who have been notified of an arriving animal with suspected\nmonkeypox should admit the animal through a separate entrance to a private\nroom and place it in isolation; the animal should not be admitted to an\nopen waiting room.\n\nWhen examining or euthanizing sick rodents, lagomorphs, and exotic pets,\nespecially prairie dogs, Gambian giant rats, or any ill mammal known to\nhave been in contact with a case of monkeypox, the following precautions\nshould be used:\n\n* Hand hygiene after all contact with a sick animal and contaminated surfaces.\n* Use of gown and gloves for any contact with the sick animal and\ncontaminated surfaces.\n* Eye protection (e.g. goggles or face shield) if splash or spray of body\nfluids is likely.\n* Respiratory protection including a NIOSH-certified N95 filtering\ndisposable respirator for entering the exam room. If N95 respirators are\nnot available for health-care personnel, then surgical masks should be worn.*\n* Contain and dispose of contaminated waste in accordance with\nfacility-specific guidelines for medically regulated infectious waste.\n* Handle used patient-care equipment in a manner that prevents\ncontamination of skin and clothing. Ensure that used equipment has been\ncleaned and reprocessed appropriately.\n* Ensure that procedures are in place for cleaning and disinfecting\ncontaminated environmental surfaces. Any EPA-registered hospital\ndetergent-disinfectant currently used by health-care facilities for\nenvironmental sanitation may be used. Manufacturer\u0092s recommendations for\ndilution (i.e., concentration), contact time, and care in handling should\nbe followed.\n* Laundry (e.g., towels, clothing) may be washed in a standard washing\nmachine with warm water and detergent; bleach may be added but is not\nnecessary. Care should be used when handling soiled laundry to avoid direct\ncontact with contaminated material. Soiled laundry should not be shaken or\notherwise handled in a manner that may aerosolize infectious particles.\n\nAll animals with suspected monkeypox infection should be humanely\neuthanized to prevent further spread of the disease. Humane euthanasia\noptions include pentobarbital injection or gas chamber using isoflurane or\nhalothane for most animals. For small rodent species such as mice, cervical\ndislocation may be considered if performed by a trained person.\n\nCDC is not currently recommending euthanasia of asymptomatic animals that\nmay have been exposed to other infected animals. Exposed asymptomatic\nanimals should be confined to the home and not allowed to come into contact\nwith other animals. They should be observed for development of signs\ncompatible with monkeypox for one month. Should such signs develop, the\nanimal should then be evaluated and euthanized if indicated.\n\nCurrently, CDC is not routinely requesting animal samples for testing.\nHowever, specimens can be collected and stored for possible future testing.\n\nConsultation with the state epidemiologist and state health laboratory is\nnecessary for samples to be sent to CDC for testing.\n<http://www.cste.org/members/state_and_territorial_epi.asp>\n<http://www.aphl.org/public_health_labs/index.cfm>\n\nPrior to euthanasia, whole blood in EDTA tubes or serum can be collected\nand refrigerated at 4 deg C. White' <DMWhite@uwyo.edu>\n\nA comment on transportation of suspected monkeypox-infected animals\n--------------------------------------------------\nAren't the orthopoxviruses known for their environmental stability? It\nseems to me that the recommendation to house a suspect animal in the\n'bed of a pickup truck' could engender aerosol infection of the wild\nprarie dogs that often have colonies near roadways (at least here in the\nWest). Where is the greater risk -- possible contamination of the\nenvironment by an infected animal shedding virus from the bed of a\ntruck, or extended exposure of the already-exposed human driving the\nanimal to the clinic?? A quick check of Field's and the CDC smallpox\nvaccination recommendations did not yield any information on the\nstability of orthopoxviruses in sunlight...\nMaybe the recommendation should be to keep the animal in the vehicle, but\ncover it with a thick blanket or towel to decrease air flow (and then\nthoroughly clean the car).\n--\nDave White D.V.M., Ph.D\n<DMWhite@uwyo.edu>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: 'Javier Nevarez' <JNevarez@mail.vetmed.lsu.edu>\n\nI am writing with respect to the ProMED-mail post about recommendations for\ndealing with animals potentially infected with monkeypox. The following\nstatement is made :\n'During transport animals should be confined in a closed container such as a\ncardboard box. If available, the animal should be confined in a separate\ncompartment of the vehicle, such as the bed of a pickup truck.'\nPrairie dogs and other rodents are very capable of chewing through a\ncardboard box, and if that box was in the bed of a pickup truck then you\nwould have a potentially infected animal on the run. Perhaps a sturdier\ntransport container such as a small dog carrier should be suggested.\n--\nJavier G. However the advice provided by the CDC may relate to the\ntransportation of potentially infected Gambian rats. The Gambian rat is the\nanimal presumed to be the source of the monkeypox outbreak. Prairie dogs are\nground squirrels, whereas the Gambian rat is a type of rodent known as a\npouched rat. Gambian rats can be rather large animals, 2 feet or more in\nlength and 3-5 pounds in weight. The standard housing for these animals\nwould be cages with 3 x 2 x 2 ft dimensions. Consequently it might not be\npractical to transport these animals inside a vehicle as opposed to on the\nbed of a pickup truck.\nProvided adequate care is taken to contain infection, the precise mode of\ntransport is not an issue, since infection is predominantly transmitted by\ncontact rather than by aerosolization. The child was suspected to have\nbeen exposed to monkeypox through contact with prairie dogs in Indiana, New\nJersey Health and Senior Services Commissioner Clifton R. Lacy said. There\nare no other suspected monkeypox cases in New Jersey.\nMeanwhile, initial reports of the first human-to-human transmissions of\nmonkeypox virus to Wisconsin health care workers now seem unlikely, state\nhealth officials said on Friday. An assessment of the symptoms shown by the 2\nhealth care workers, who both had contact with known monkeypox patients, do\nnot appear to fit the viral illness, said Dr. Jeff Davis, the state\nepidemiologist for communicable diseases.\nU.S. health officials have confirmed a total of 12 human cases of monkeypox:\n4 each in Wisconsin, Indiana and Illinois. Also, 53 possible cases had been\nreported: 25 in Indiana, 17 in Wisconsin & 11 in Illinois. No one has died\nfrom the disease in the United States. Monkeypox, a disease never before seen\nin the Western Hemisphere, is related to smallpox but is not as lethal. It\ncauses pus-filled blisters, rashes, chills and fever.\nA shipment of animals believed to have spread monkeypox has been traced to a\npet-distribution center in Iowa, health officials said. Evelee Prokes, owner\nof the Menagerie Hill Farm in Cincinnati, Iowa, said her pet-breeding and\ndistribution business was shut amid a probe by CDC and state health\nofficials. USA(WI,IL,IN)(04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203958", "date": "2003-06-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX, HUMAN, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA(WI,IL,IN)(04)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 10 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Post Gazette online, Tue 10 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.post-gazette.com/healthscience/20030610monkeypox0610p2.asp>\n\nMonkeypox Cases in Midwest Rise to 40\n----------------------------\nHealth officials investigating an outbreak of monkeypox that apparently\nspread from pet prairie dogs to people in 3 Midwestern states said\nyesterday the number of possible cases has risen to at least 40.\nIn a precautionary response to the outbreak, the Allegheny County Health\nDepartment has ordered a quarantine for 2 prairie dogs and 2 hedgehogs that\nwere sold in April 2003 by a pet store in northern Illinois. The health\ndepartment would not say whether the store was the same one that has been\nidentified as the source of the monkeypox outbreak. The county quarantine\nis indefinite, but was ordered solely as a precaution. The Health\nDepartment has no reason to believe the animals were ever infected with\nmonkeypox virus, according to spokesman Guillermo Cole. 'The animals are in\ngood health,' Cole said. 'They are well past the 12-day incubation period\nfor developing illness and spreading monkeypox virus.'\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported 4 confirmed human\ncases yesterday of monkeypox virus infection, a smallpox-related virus that\nhas never before appeared in the Western Hemisphere. 7 people have been\nhospitalized; no one has died. Steve Ostroff, deputy director of the CDC's\nNational Center for Infectious Diseases, said he expects the numbers to\nrise as human and animal samples are tested. But Ostroff said that only\npeople who had direct contact with infected prairie dogs, or in one case a\nrabbit [that was in contact with a sick prairie dog], have come down with the\nillness. 'For the average citizen, I would not necessarily be concerned at\nthis point of being exposed to monkeypox,' he said.\nState health officials have reported 19 suspected cases in Wisconsin, 13 in\nIndiana, and 4 in Illinois. 4 cases have been confirmed in Wisconsin and\nIllinois.\nInvestigators said the prairie dogs were probably infected with the virus\nby a Gambian giant rat, which is native to Africa, at a Chicago-area pet\ndistributor. The Illinois Department of Agriculture, along with state and\nfederal health officials, is trying to track down 115 customers -- both\nindividuals and pet stores -- that bought exotic animals from Phil's Pocket\nPets since 15 Apr 2003. The distributor, Phillip Moberley, said yesterday\nthat he voluntarily quarantined his home-based business and put to death 70\nprairie dogs.\nThe Allegheny County animals will be quarantined in the homes of the 2\nresidents who purchased them. There is no evidence that any people here\nwere sickened by the animals, Cole said. The prairie dogs were sold to a\npet store owner, who kept one of the animals on display in his store and\nthe other in his home. The prairie dog on display had no contact with other\nanimals, Cole said. The hedgehogs went to a woman who bought them as pets.\nAside from their owner, the animals have had contact only with the woman's\ncat, which is in good health. 'It's not clear to us whether hedgehogs can\nbe infected,' Cole noted. [Hedgehogs belong to the Order Insectivora and\nare unrelated to any of the rodents displaying signs of disease. - Mod.CP]\nMonkeypox in humans is not usually fatal but causes rashes, fevers, and\nchills. Doctors initially feared they might be facing smallpox, which\ncauses similar symptoms. 2 patients at Froedtert Memorial Lutheran Hospital\nin Milwaukee were reported in satisfactory condition Sunday. The 2 were\nisolated, and doctors treating them wore caps, gowns, and masks. Other\nsuspected victims were treated and released.\nHealth officials are trying to contain the virus by preventing more animals\nfrom becoming infected. Wisconsin's Department of Agriculture warned people\nnot to release prairie dogs into the wild. The agency also told state\nhumane societies to isolate any prairie dogs people bring in. Both\nWisconsin and Illinois have banned the sale, importation, and display of\nprairie dogs. The Illinois ban also covers Gambian rats.\nThe popularity of prairie dogs as pets has grown in recent years. In a precautionary response to the outbreak, the Allegheny County Health\nDepartment has ordered a quarantine for 2 prairie dogs and 2 hedgehogs that\nwere sold in April 2003 by a pet store in northern Illinois. Investigators said the prairie dogs were probably infected with the virus\nby a Gambian giant rat, which is native to Africa, at a Chicago-area pet\ndistributor. The prairie dogs were sold to a\npet store owner, who kept one of the animals on display in his store and\nthe other in his home. The distributor, Phillip Moberley, said yesterday\nthat he voluntarily quarantined his home-based business and put to death 70\nprairie dogs. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported 4 confirmed human\ncases yesterday of monkeypox virus infection, a smallpox-related virus that\nhas never before appeared in the Western Hemisphere. The Health\nDepartment has no reason to believe the animals were ever infected with\nmonkeypox virus, according to spokesman Guillermo Cole. Source: Post Gazette online, Tue 10 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.post-gazette.com/healthscience/20030610monkeypox0610p2.asp>\n\nMonkeypox Cases in Midwest Rise to 40\n Steve Ostroff, deputy director of the CDC's\nNational Center for Infectious Diseases, said he expects the numbers to\nrise as human and animal samples are tested.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "smallpox", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-06-10 00:00:00", "2003-04-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2003-04-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chicago", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Allegheny County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Milwaukee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203955", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Monkeypox, human, prairie dogs - USA(WI,IL,IN)(03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203955", "date": "2003-06-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX, HUMAN, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA(WI,IL,IN) (03)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 10 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-dmail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Sun online, Tue 10 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.sunspot.net/news/health/bal-te.pray10jun10,0,1955712.story?coll=\nbal-health-headlines>\n\n9 new cases of monkeypox suspected in Midwest\n--------------------------\n9 new cases of suspected monkeypox were reported in the Midwest by state\nand federal health authorities yesterday [Mon 9 Jun 2003], bringing the\nnumber of suspected victims to at least 37.\n4 of the cases have been confirmed as monkeypox by genetic [PCR?] tests,\nbut the disease is so distinct that most of the suspected victims probably\nhave the virus, said Dr. Stephen M. Ostroff of the federal Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention. State and federal officials are trying to\ntrack down other people who might have purchased diseased pet prairie dogs,\nwhich are believed to be the source of the outbreak.\nNone of the victims has died, but authorities are taking aggressive action\nto contain the epidemic for fear that the virus will obtain a permanent\nfoothold in the United States, much as West Nile virus did after a case was\nidentified in New York City in 1999. West Nile virus spread from coast to\ncoast, infecting nearly 4200 people last year and killing 284. Although\nmonkeypox virus does not seem to be [highly contagious] and probably is not\nas lethal, authorities would like to stop it in its tracks. Monkeypox\n[virus] is closely related to smallpox [virus] but is not as infectious nor\nas deadly. It is usually found only in the rain forest countries of western\nand central Africa.\nWisconsin officials were startled last month [May 2003] when a 3-year-old\nchild was hospitalized with a high fever, swollen glands and red pustules on\nher body, typically signs of smallpox. Both of her parents developed a milder\nform of the disease. Scientists at the Marshfield Clinic quickly identified a\nvirus that looked like a poxvirus [by electron microscopy]. The CDC heard\nabout the finding late Wednesday and immediately dispatched a research team,\nwhich returned to Atlanta with samples on Friday night. By Saturday\nafternoon, CDC researchers had confirmed that the virus was monkeypox virus\nand made the information public, looking for other cases. As of yesterday\nafternoon, 22 suspected cases had been reported in Wisconsin, 10 in Indiana\nand 5 in Illinois. Ostroff said it is likely that most of the suspected cases\nwill be confirmed.\nThe cases were quickly linked to contact with prairie dogs and, in one case,\na rabbit. The animals were traced back to a suburban Chicago business, Phil's\nPocket Pets, which specializes in small, friendly rodents. Researchers think\nthe prairie dogs came into contact with a Gambian giant rat, also imported as\na pet, which apparently carried the virus. State and federal health\nauthorities are trying to track down 115 customers, individuals and pet\nstores, that have purchased the prairie dogs from the store since 15 Apr 2003.\nOfficials have seen no evidence of human-to-human transmission of the virus,\nOstroff said. Everyone who has caught it has been in close contact with the\nanimals. That included 6 veterinarians, their assistants and '3 or 4' in pet\nshops, he said. The rest of the victims were in families that purchased the\nanimals. One caught it from a rabbit that had been in contact with a sick\nprairie dog. Officials have warned anyone in the region with a prairie dog\nthat appears to be ill to contact public health authorities or a\nveterinarian. Under no circumstances should a sick animal be released into\nthe wild, where it could infect other animals, they said.\nMonkeypox virus is a member of the [_Orthopoxvirus_ genus of the family\n_Poxviridae_], which includes smallpox virus. Symptoms, which usually begin\nabout 12 days after exposure, include fever, headache, body aches, chills,\ndrenching sweat and sometimes a cough. One to 10 days later, these symptoms\nare followed by a rash with pustules that eventually crust over. Contact\nwith the pustules is the primary source of transmission, but it can be\nspread by coughing.\nThere is no treatment for the disease, although the CDC is testing\ncidofovir, an antiviral drug. Studies in Africa suggest that 1 percent to 10\npercent of victims have died, but researchers note that the higher mortality\nrates occurred in people who were chronically malnourished, making it\ndifficult for them to fight off the infection. Studies in Africa have also\nshown that even though the virus can be passed from person to person, it\nloses much of its virulence and infectiousness after several generations of\ninfection, breaking the transmission chain. Vaccinations against smallpox\napparently provide some protection against monkeypox infections.\n[By Thomas H. Maugh II]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The identity of the infectious agent appears to be have been confirmed\nunequivocally as Monkeypox virus. Monkeypox virus, like smallpox virus, is a\nmember of the genus _Orthopoxvirus_ of the family _Poxviridae_, but the two\nviruses are not the most closely related members of the genus. The name of\nthe virus is misleading as monkeys -- and probably humans -- become infected\nby exposure to the rodent or squirrel natural reservoir host. Person-to-person\ntransmission is rare and does not appear to have occurred in this outbreak\nin the Midwest (the first outside West/Central Africa). The outbreak is\nunlikely to spread beyond those in contact with the infected rodents. The\nprincipal concern is the possibility that the virus might spread to wild\nrodent populations by accidental release, or escape of infected pet animals. -\nMod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \n4 of the cases have been confirmed as monkeypox by genetic [PCR?] tests,\nbut the disease is so distinct that most of the suspected victims probably\nhave the virus, said Dr. Stephen M. The Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention is expected to make the vaccinations\navailable as an option to highly selected groups like health workers who\ncare for patients with monkeypox, people who have been exposed to animals\nsick with monkeypox, veterinarians who care for animals suspected of having\nit, and scientists investigating monkeypox.\n\nThe investigation of human monkeypox cases expanded to a fourth state, New\nJersey, yesterday as the number of suspected monkeypox cases rose to 50: 23\nin Indiana, 20 in Wisconsin, 6 in Illinois, and 1 in New Jersey. No one has\ndied. The total is more than double the 23 cases reported in 3 states when\nthe CDC urgently announced the outbreak over the weekend. The increase in\ncases under investigation has resulted largely from widespread publicity\nthat led people to report rashes and illness to health officials, officials\nof the Centers in Atlanta said. The monkeypox cases are the first detected\nin the Americas. Most suspected cases had direct contact with prairie dogs\nor while working in veterinarian offices and pet shops.\n\nMonkeypox patients typically fall ill with signs and symptoms like fever,\nheadaches, dry cough, swollen lymph nodes, chills, and drenching sweats.\nOne to 10 days later, patients develop rashes consisting of blister-like\npimples which fill with pus, break open, and produce scabs. The rash often\nerupts in different stages, or crops, as it appears on the head, trunk,\narms, and legs.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is also expected today to\nannounce a definition of human monkeypox, which will be critical in\ndetermining who would be eligible for smallpox vaccinations as well as in\ninvestigating the outbreak. United States officials stopped routine\nsmallpox vaccinations in 1970, about a decade before eradication of\nsmallpox from the world.\n\nOn Mon 9 Jun 2003, a subgroup of a national panel of immunization experts\nappointed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to serve on its\nAdvisory Committee on Immunization Practices began discussions on whether\nand how the smallpox vaccine might be used. Discussions focused on the\nbenefits and risks of smallpox vaccine for monkeypox, a viral disease that\ncan be fatal in 10 percent of human cases. The death rate for smallpox was\nabout 30 percent.\n\nBut smallpox vaccination can also be fatal. Studies from the 1960's, when\nsmallpox vaccinations were routine, found that for every million people\nolder than 1 year who were vaccinated, 1 or 2 died, 9 suffered from brain\ninfection, and more than 100 developed eczema vaccinatum, a severe illness\nand skin rash that can leave deep scars and can occasionally be\nlife-threatening.\n\nThe government owns all the smallpox vaccine in the United States. This\nyear, the government began offering it to health care workers to protect\nagainst any cases that might result from an attack in which terrorists\nreleased the virus. The only known stocks of smallpox virus are kept at the\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention and in Russia, both with the\napproval of the World Health Organization. But the Bush administration has\nwarned that Iraq as well as other countries and rogue groups might have\nobtained smallpox virus from the official stores in Russia and begun a\nprogram to vaccinate health care workers before the war began against Iraq.\nThe number of people for whom smallpox vaccine might be offered to protect\nagainst monkeypox would be small, the panel's chairman, Dr. John F. Modlin,\nsaid in an interview before the panel's meeting.\n\n[Byline: Lawrence Altman]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In a paper by Fine, Jezek, Grab, and Dixon (ref.1 below), an 85 percent\nprotective rate of smallpox vaccination in prevention of monkeypox was\nestimated during outbreaks in Zaire in the period 1980-1984. In 1991, the\nUnited States Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP)\nrecommended (see ref. 3 below) its use among laboratory and health-care\nworkers occupationally exposed to vaccinia, recombinant vaccinia viruses,\nand other orthopoxviruses that can infect humans. In the 22 Jun 2002 ACIP\nrecommendations for 'pre-event' smallpox vaccination use (accessible at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5010a1.htm>)\nthere is mention of use among laboratory and health care workers\noccupationally exposed to non-variola orthopoxviruses.\n\nThe risks and benefits must be weighed in any vaccination decision; the\nobserved case fatality rate of human monkeypox infection in the Dem.\nRepublic of the Congo is approximately 10 percent. It has been suggested\nthat the mortality associated with monkeypox is related to the nutritional\nstatus of the host, and in the case of the outbreak in the DRC, may have\nbeen associated with impaired nutritional status. So far in the USA\noutbreak, there have been no deaths reported due to monkeypox infection,\nwith the majority of cases to date described as mild. The cited 'case\nfatality rate' following vaccination with the smallpox vaccine ranged from\n1.1 to 1.5 per million vaccinees (from 1968 studies -- data available for\nreview at:\n<http://www.bt.cdc.gov/agent/smallpox/vaccine-safety/adverse-events-chart.asp>).\n\nThe pre-event smallpox vaccination program has now vaccinated over 500 000\nindividuals, with several deaths temporally associated with receipt of\nvaccine but attributable to myocardial infarction. We await further\nofficial information on a decision to use smallpox vaccination in this\ncurrent outbreak. A difficult decision, especially in the absence of a\nlarge body of data with which to compare various strategic options. - Mod.MPP]\n\nReferences:\n--------\n1: Fine PE, Jezek Z, Grab B, Dixon H. The transmission potential of\nmonkeypox virus in human populations. Int J Epidemiol. 1988 Sep;17(3):643-50.\n\n2: Heymann DL, Szczeniowski M, Esteves K. Re-emergence of monkeypox in\nAfrica: a review of the past six years. Br Med Bull. 1998;54(3):693-702.\n\n3: Vaccinia (smallpox) vaccine. Recommendations of the Immunization\nPractices Advisory Committee (ACIP) MMWR Recomm Rep. 1991 Dec\n13;40(RR-14):1-10. Erratum in: MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 1992 Jan 17;41(2):31.\n\n4. Lane JM, Ruben FL, Neff JM, Millar JD. Complications of smallpox\nvaccinations, 1968: national surveillance in the United States. New Engl J\nMed 1969;281:1201-1208.\n\n5. Lane JM, Ruben FL, Neff JM, Millar JD. Complications of smallpox\nvaccination, 1968: results of ten statewide surveys. J Infect Dis\n1970;122:303-309.\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 11 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters Health Information online, Wed 11 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.reutershealth.com/archive/2003/06/11/eline/links/20030611elin023.html>\n\nU.S. monkeypox cases rise to 48\n------------------------\nThere are 20 confirmed or suspected cases of monkeypox in Wisconsin, 23 in\nIndiana, and 5 in Illinois.\n\nA search for the source of monkeypox -- a smallpox-like illness not seen\nbefore in the Americas -- stretched from the Great Lakes to Texas on Tue 10\nJun 2003 as the number of suspected and confirmed cases rose to 48. 'Close\ncontact with sick prairie dogs, Gambian rats, and other exotic animals\nshould be minimized immediately,' warned Robert Teclaw, state\nepidemiologist for Indiana, where 10 new cases were reported. 'Owners of\nsuch animals should contact a veterinarian and consult with them on the\nsituation.'\n\nPublic health workers were trying to track down dozens of prairie dogs\npossibly infected with the virus and sold as pets during the past 2 months in\nWisconsin, Indiana, and Illinois. While the monkeypox illness is not as\nharmful as smallpox, officials feared the virus could jump to native wildlife\nsuch as squirrels and become endemic, creating a new health hazard in the\nhemisphere.\n\nThe Texas Department of Health said federal agricultural officials had\nordered 2 dealers in that state not to buy or sell any animals until the\nhealth of those now in their possession had been checked out. That action\ncame after a Chicago-area exotic pet dealer said he bought from a Texas\nbreeder Gambian giant rats apparently carrying the virus that then spread\nto his prairie dogs. Doug McBride, a spokesman for the department, said:\n'It appears that there was a shipment of Gambian rats and maybe some other\nanimals from Africa to a Texas dealer. We and other agencies are involved\nin tracking down those animals to see what health they are in and whether\nthere have been any human illnesses.'\n\nSo far, no suspect animal or human cases had been found in Texas, he said.\nMcBride also said investigators had not been able to place the Gambian rats\nat the same location with any prairie dogs in Texas, leading them to\nconclude the infection spread after the animals left the state.\n\nPrairie dogs, a member of the squirrel family, are shipped by the thousands\nfrom the Plains states every year for use as pets. Ranchers consider them\nnuisances because of the holes they dig to house their colonies. The\ndisease is not fatal in all cases in prairie dogs. It causes an eye\ninfection and nose lesions in the animals, and can be spread to humans when\nthey handle them.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[see also;\nMonkeypox, human, prairie dogs - USA (WI, IL, IN) 20030608.1412\nMonkeypox, human, prairie dogs - USA(WI,IL,IN)(02) 20030609.1422\nMonkeypox, human, prairie dogs - USA(WI,IL,IN)(03) 20030610.1433\nMonkeypox, human, prairie dogs - USA(WI,IL,IN)(04) 20030611.1436\n2002\n-----\nMonkeypox - Congo DR (Equateur) (07) 20021025.5638\nMonkeypox - Congo DR (Equateur) 20020228.3654\nMonkeypox - Congo DR (Equateur) (06) 20020410.3926\n2001\n----\nMonkeypox, suspected - Congo DR (Equateur) (02) 20010927.2353\nMonkeypox, suspected - Congo DR (Equateur): RFI 20010315.0523\n2000\n----\nMonkeypox - Congo, Dem. N.\nShchelkunov, A. V. Totmenin, P. F. Safronov, M. V. Mikheev, V. V.\nGutorov, O. I. Ryazankina, N. A. Petrov, I. V. Babkin, E. A. Uvarova,\nL. S. Sandakhchiev, J. R. Sisler, J. J. Esposito, I. K. Damon, P. B.\nJahrling and B. Moss) describes the complete sequencing and analysis\nof the structure of the genome of monkeypox virus, and the\nrelationship of monkeypox virus to smallpox virus.\nMonkeypox virus belongs to the genus _Orthopoxvirus_ of the family\n_Poxviridae_, is endemic in parts of Africa, and causes a human\ndisease that resembles smallpox. The 196 858 base-pair genome of\nmonkeypox virus has been analyzed with regard to its structural\nfeatures and content of open reading frames.\nEach end of the genome contains an identical but oppositely oriented\n6379 base-pair terminal inverted repetition, which is similar to that of\nother orthopoxviruses, includes a putative telomere resolution\nsequence and short tandem repeats. Computer-assisted analysis was\nused to identify 190 open reading frames containing 60 [or more]\namino acid residues. Of these, 4 were present within the inverted\nterminal repetition.\nThe genome of Monkeypox virus contains the known essential\northopoxvirus genes but only a subset of the putative immuno-\nmodulatory and host range genes. Sequence comparisons confirmed\nthe assignment of monkeypox virus as a distinct species of\northopoxvirus that is not a direct ancestor or a direct descendent of\n_Variola virus_, the causative gent of human smallpox.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Human infection with monkeypox virus has been reported in rural\nareas of the tropical rain forests of west and central Africa, especially in\nthe Democratic Republic of Congo. The signs and symptoms are\nsimilar to those of smallpox, with generalised pustular rash, fever, and\ntoxaemia. The disease, which is rare, only became apparent after the\neradication of smallpox. Monkeypox virus is a zoonotic agent and is\nacquired by humans through direct contact with the presumptive\nnatural hosts: squirrels and monkeys.\nPerson-to-person transmission has been recorded, but the secondary\nattack rate is low. Nonetheless, the fear has been expressed that\nmonkeypox might evolve to become an endemic human infection. The\nanalysis reported above, demonstrating the distinct identity of\nmonkeypox virus with its deficit of immunomodulatory genes, suggests\nthat monkeypox virus is unlikely to become endemic in the human\npopulation. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Gutorov, O. Moss) describes the complete sequencing and analysis\nof the structure of the genome of monkeypox virus, and the\nrelationship of monkeypox virus to smallpox virus. Not a Direct Ancestor or Descendent of Smallpox\nVirus\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "smallpox", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-06-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203949", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Monkeypox, human, prairie dogs - USA(WI,IL,IN)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203949", "date": "2003-06-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX, HUMAN, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (WISCONSIN,\nILLINOIS, INDIANA) (02)\n******************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n***[ProMED would like to thank the many readers who sent in news\nreports of this outbreak. - Mod.JW]***\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 9 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Preliminary report,\nMon 9 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/report060903.htm>\n\nMultistate outbreak of monkeypox in persons exposed to pet prairie dogs\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAn extensive multidisciplinary investigation in Wisconsin, Illinois, and\nIndiana has identified cases of febrile rash illness in persons who had\ndirect or close contact with recently purchased ill prairie dogs. Scientists\nat the Marshfield Clinic in Marshfield, Wisconsin, recovered viral\nisolates from a patient and a prairie dog and demonstrated a virus\nmorphologically consistent with a poxvirus by electron microscopy (see\n<http://research.marshfieldclinic.org/crc/prairiedog.asp>\nfor electron microscopy images).\nPreliminary results of serologic testing, polymerase-chain-reaction\n[PCR] analysis, and gene sequencing performed at the Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention (CDC) on 6-7 Jun 2003 indicated that\nthe causative agent is monkeypox virus, a member of the orthopoxvirus\ngroup of viruses. Results of additional evaluation at CDC by electron\nmicroscopy and immunohistochemical studies are consistent with the\nfinding of an orthopoxvirus. These findings represent the first evidence\nof community-acquired monkeypox-like infection in the United States.\nFurther characterization of the virus is in progress.\nHuman monkeypox is a rare zoonotic viral disease that occurs primarily\nin the rain forest countries of central and west Africa. In humans, the\nillness produces a vesicular and pustular rash similar to that of smallpox.\nLimited person-to-person spread of infection has been reported in\ndisease-endemic areas in Africa; the incubation period is about 12 days.\nCase-fatality ratios in Africa have ranged from 1% to 10% -- for\nadditional information about monkeypox, see\n\nAs of Sat 7Jun 2003, cases of suspected monkeypox had been reported\namong residents of Wisconsin (17), northern Illinois (1), and\nnorthwestern Indiana (1). Onset of illness among patients began in early\nMay [2003]. Patients typically experienced a prodrome consisting of\nfever, headaches, myalgias, chills, and drenching sweats. Roughly one-\nthird of patients had nonproductive cough. This prodromal phase was\nfollowed 1-10 days later by the development of a papular rash that\ntypically progressed through stages of vesiculation, pustulation,\numbilication, and crusting. In some patients, early lesions have become\nulcerated. Rash distribution and lesions have occurred on head, trunk, and\nextremities; many of the patients had initial and satellite lesions on palms\nand soles and extremities. Rashes were generalized in some patients.\nAfter onset of the rash, patients have generally manifested rash lesions in\ndifferent stages.\nAll patients reported direct or close contact with prairie dogs, most of\nwhich were sick. Illness in prairie dogs was frequently reported as\nbeginning with a blepharoconjunctivitis, progressing to presence of\nnodular lesions in some cases. Some prairie dogs have died\nfrom the illness, while others reportedly recovered.\nIn May [2003] the prairie dogs were sold by a Milwaukee animal\ndistributor to 2 pet shops in the Milwaukee area and during a pet 'swap\nmeet' (pets for sale or exchange) in northern Wisconsin. The Milwaukee\nanimal distributor had obtained prairie dogs and a Gambian giant rat that\nwas ill at the time from a northern Illinois animal distributor. It is unclear\nwhether other retail outlets are involved. Investigations are under way to\ntrace back the source of the prairie dogs and the Gambian giant rat and\ndetermine if distributors in other states might be involved. Animal\nspecies susceptible to monkeypox virus may include non-human\nprimates, lagomorphs (rabbits), and some rodents.\nOn the basis of preliminary findings from this investigation, it appears\nthat the primary route of transmission may be from infected prairie dogs\nto humans as a result of close contact. However, the possibility of human-\nto-human transmission cannot be excluded at this time. As a precaution\nuntil additional information is available, the measures below should be\nfollowed.\nGeneral Prevention\n------------------\nAvoid contact with any prairie dogs or Gambian giant rats that appear to\nbe ill (e.g., are missing patches of fur, have a visible rash on the skin, or\nhave a discharge from eyes or nose). Wash hands thoroughly after any\ncontact with prairie dogs, Gambian giant rats, or any ill animal.\nDiagnosis\n-----------\nPhysicians should consider monkeypox in persons with fever, cough,\nheadache, myalgias, rash, or lymph node enlargement within 3 weeks\nafter contact with prairie dogs or Gambian giant rats. Inform the treating\nphysician or other clinician of the animal exposure.\nVeterinarians\n-------------\nVeterinarians examining sick exotic animal species, especially prairie\ndogs and Gambian giant rats, should consider monkeypox. Veterinarians\nshould also be alert to the development of illness in other animal species\nthat may have been housed with ill prairie dogs or Gambian giant rats.\nTreatment\n--------\nNo specific treatment recommendations are being made at this time.\nSmallpox vaccine has been reported to reduce the risk of monkeypox\namong previously vaccinated persons in Africa. CDC is assessing the\npotential role of postexposure use of smallpox vaccine as well as\ntherapeutic use of the antiviral drug cidofovir. [A newswire report states\nthat one of the victims had been vaccinated against smallpox back in\n1972. - Mod.JW]\nReporting\n---------\nHealth care providers, veterinarians, and public health personnel should\nreport cases of these illnesses in humans and animals to their state or\nlocal health departments as soon as they are suspected.\nSubmission of Specimens from Patients with Suspected Monkeypox\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nProcedures recommended for collection of samples for diagnosis of\npotential monkeypox disease are essentially the same as those for\ndiagnosis of the related orthopoxvirus diseases, vaccinia and smallpox.\nFor information regarding collection of serum specimens and lesions,\nplease refer to the smallpox laboratory testing guidelines at\n. Consultation with the\nstate epidemiologist\nand state health\nlaboratory\nis necessary for submission instructions before sending specimens to\nCDC.\nAdditional Information\n----------------------\nFor more information contact your state or local health department.\nAdditional information and recommendations will be released as they\nbecome available. Updated information will be posted on CDC's\nmonkeypox Web site\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/index.htm>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At present there still seems to be some ambiguity regarding the identity\nof the etiologic agent responsible for this outbreak. Monkeypox virus has\nnot been observed outside West/Central Africa and its name is something\nof a misnomer. Monkeypox virus causes mild illness in primates but its\nprincipal reservoir hosts may be squirrels and rodents. Monkeypox virus\nis a member of the same poxvirus genus as smallpox virus (i.e. the genus\n_Orthopoxvirus_) and smallpox virus vaccine (i.e. vaccinia virus)\nprovides protective immunity. However, in its natural range outbreaks of\nmonkeypox are infrequent and it has often been confused with outbreaks\nof chickenpox (caused by an unrelated herpesvirus): see a previous\ncautionary comment posted by Dr. D.A. Henderson in 'Monkeypox -\nCongo DR (Equateur) (06) 20020410.3926' - Mod.CP]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 9 Jun 2003\nFrom: 'Robin Nypaver' <RobinNypaver@epchealth.org>\n\nThe Associated Press article on monkeypox quoted on ProMED-mail\nstates that: ['One of the cases] said she got 2 female prairie dogs from\nSK Exotics on 5 May 2003. Hospital staff gave her\naspirin, told her it was a viral infection and she went home, she said.'\nMonkeypox presents very much like smallpox. If the article is accurate\nand the case did go to a hospital, why did the hospital not recognize the\nsimilarities and become fretful?\n--\nRobin Nypaver, R.N., B.S.N.\nCommunicable Disease Specialist\nEl Paso County Department of Health and Environment\n301 South Union Blvd.\nColorado Springs, Colorado 80910\n<robinnypaver@epchealth.org>\n[I would suggest that there is significant reason for concern about the\nefficacy of the BT preparedness training that has gone on, if the patient\npresented with a febrile 'blister' illness to an Emergency Department.\nWho were the targets of the training? USA (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203969", "date": "2003-06-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX, HUMAN, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (06)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: Thomas Benoit <benoitt@mcmurryadm.mcm.edu>\nSource: Texas Department of Health, news release, Wed 11 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.tdh.state.tx.us/news/b_new481.htm>\n\nAuthorities account for most imported Gambian rats\n---------------------------------\nFederal, state and local authorities tracking dispersal of a shipment of\nGambian rats imported from Africa in early April [2003] by a Texas pet\ndistributor have accounted for most of the rats. Some of the Gambian rats\nended up with an Illinois pet dealer believed to have sold prairie dogs\nlinked to a cluster of monkeypox illnesses in the Midwest. Health officials\nsuspect that one or more of the imported Gambian rats infected the prairie\ndogs sold by the Illinois dealer.\nTexas Department of Health officials said that of the 50 Gambian rats\nimported in the early April shipment, 10 died en route to the Texas\ndistributor or shortly after arrival, one died later at the distributor's\npremises, 5 were shipped to a pet store within Texas, 9 remain alive at the\ndistributor's premises, and from 18 to 25 of the rats were sent to an Iowa\ndistributor with 18 of those sent from Iowa to the Illinois dealer. Of the\n5 sold to the pet store in Texas, one was sold to an individual.\nAuthorities said the animal and the owner are fine. The other 4 died.\nOfficials said it is not unusual for deaths to occur in wild animals\nbrought into captivity and that the deaths cannot be assumed to have been\ncaused by monkeypox. TDH officials are hopeful that testing of the live\nGambian rats remaining at the distributor's premises and of a dead Gambian\nrat from the pet store that had been kept frozen may offer additional clues\nin the ongoing multi-state investigation.\nTexas officials also said that while the prairie dogs sold by the dealer in\nIllinois are believed to have come from a Texas distributor, it is not the\nsame dealer who supplied the Gambian rats. They said it does not appear\nthat the prairie dogs and Gambian rats were ever in the same facility in\nTexas. The prairie dogs were shipped directly to the Illinois dealer.\nAuthorities stressed that the investigation is continuing, including the\ntracking of other animals imported with the Gambian rats.\nEarlier today, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food\nand Drug Administration issued a joint order prohibiting the import of\nrodents from Africa and banning the distribution, sale, and transport of\nprairie dogs and 6 species of African rodents within the United States.\n--\nThomas Benoit\nProfessor of Biology\nMcMurry University\nAbilene, TX 79697\n<benoitt@mcmurryadm.mcm.edu>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, 52(23);537-540, Fri 13 Jun\n2003 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5223a1.htm>\n\nMultistate Outbreak of Monkeypox --- Illinois, Indiana, and Wisconsin, 2003*\n--------------------------------------------------\n*[one more case has since been reported from New Jersey -- see section [3]\nbelow. - Mod.JW]\nCDC has received reports of patients with a febrile rash illness who had\nclose contact with pet prairie dogs and other animals. The Marshfield\nClinic, Marshfield, Wisconsin, identified a virus morphologically\nconsistent with a poxvirus by electron microscopy of skin lesion tissue\nfrom a patient, lymph node tissue from the patient's pet prairie dog, and\nisolates of virus from culture of these tissues. Additional laboratory\ntesting at CDC indicated that the causative agent is Monkeypox virus, a\nmember of the _Orthopoxvirus_ [genus of the family _Poxviridae_]. This\nreport summarizes initial descriptive epidemiologic, clinical, and\nlaboratory data, interim infection-control guidance, and new animal import\nregulations.\nAs of Tue 11 Jun 2003, a total of 53 cases had been investigated in\nIllinois, Indiana, and Wisconsin. Of these, 29 (49 percent) cases were\namong males; the median age was 26 years (range: 4 to 53 years). Data were\nunavailable for sex and age for 2 and 14 patients, respectively. A total of\n14 (26 percent) patients have been hospitalized, including a child aged <10\nyears with encephalitis.\nDetailed clinical information was available for 30 cases reported in\nIllinois and Wisconsin. Among these, the earliest reported onset of illness\nwas on 15 May 2003. For the majority of patients (22 [73 percent]), a\nfebrile illness has either preceded or accompanied the onset of a papular\nrash; respiratory symptoms (16 [64 percent]), lymphadenopathy (14 [47\npercent]), and sore throat (10 [33 percent]) also were prominent signs and\nsymptoms (Table). The rash typically progressed through stages of\nvesiculation, pustulation, umbilication, and encrustation. Early lesions\nbecame ulcerated in some patients. Rash distribution and lesions have\noccurred on the head, trunk, and extremities; many patients had initial and\nsatellite lesions on palms, soles, and extremities. Rashes were generalized\nin some patients.\nAll patients have had contact with animals; however, at least 2 patients\nalso reported contact with another patient's lesions or ocular drainage. A\ntotal of 51 patients reported direct or close contact with prairie dogs\n(Cynomys sp.), and one patient reported contact with a Gambian giant rat\n(Cricetomys sp.). One patient had contact with a rabbit (family Leporidae)\nthat became ill after exposure to an ill prairie dog at a veterinary\nclinic. Traceback investigations have been initiated to identify the source\nof the monkeypox virus introduced into the United States and have\nidentified a common distributor where prairie dogs and Gambian giant rats\nwere housed together in Illinois. A search of imported animal records\nrevealed that Gambian giant rats were shipped from Ghana in April 2003 to a\nwildlife importer in Texas and subsequently were sold to the Illinois\ndistributor. The shipment contained approximately 800 small mammals of 9\ndifferent species that might have been the actual source of introduction of\nmonkeypox.\nAs of Mon 9 Jun 2003, specimens obtained from 10 patients in Illinois,\nIndiana, and Wisconsin had been forwarded to CDC for testing; 9 patients\nwith skin lesions had DNA sequence signatures specific for monkeypox virus.\nNo skin lesions were observed in one patient who tested negative by\npolymerase chain reaction. Skin biopsies were available for 5 patients; 4\nshowed orthopoxviral antigens by immunohistochemical testing. Skin lesions\nfrom four of the 10 patients were evaluated by negative stain electron\nmicroscopy, and poxviral particles were found in 3 patients.\nMonkeypox specific DNA signatures also were found in a viral isolate\nderived from lymphoid tissue of a patient's ill prairie dog.\n(Reported by multiple contributors -- see original on web for list)\nMMWR Editorial Note\n---------------\nIn 1970, human monkeypox was first identified in the Democratic Republic of\nthe Congo (DRC) in a region where smallpox had been eradicated in 1968 (1).\nMonkeypox is caused by an orthopoxvirus that clinically resembles smallpox\nvirus but differs both biologically and epidemiologically (2--5). After an\nincubation period of 7 to 17 days, the disease is characterized by the\nonset of a prodrome of fever, headache, backache, and fatigue. The\nmonkeypox rash includes macules, papules, vesicles, pustules, and crusts\nthat evolve in the same stage over 14 to 21 days, similar to smallpox (6).\nA major clinical difference between monkeypox and smallpox is pronounced\nlymphadenopathy in a majority of patients with monkeypox (6). Relatively\ninefficient person-to-person transmission has been documented for\nmonkeypox, and the case-fatality rate has been approximately 1 to 10\npercent in Africa, with higher death rates among young children (2,5,6).\nPreliminary findings from these investigations indicate that the primary\nroute of transmission to humans is close contact with infected mammalian\npets. However, the possibility of human-to-human transmission cannot be\nexcluded. CDC has issued interim guidance for infection control, exposure\nmanagement, monitoring of exposed persons, and duration of isolation\nprocedures in health-care and community settings for patients with\nsuspected monkeypox:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/infectioncontrol.htm>.\nPersons seeking medical care with unexplained fever, rash, or prominent\nlymphadenopathy should be asked about exposure to unusual or exotic pets,\nespecially small mammals such as prairie dogs or Gambian giant rats. If\nmonkeypox infection is suspected, standard, contact, and airborne\nprecautions should be applied in all health-care settings:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/hip/ISOLAT/Isolat.htm>.\nInterim guidance for veterinarians and pet owners also are available at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/animalguidance.htm>. These\nrecommendations are modeled after human infection-control guidelines, with\nmodifications appropriate for veterinary and home settings where airborne\nprecautions might not be feasible. In addition, these guidelines outline\nthe appropriate management of exposed or ill pets to help prevent further\ntransmission of monkeypox among animals.\nIntroduction of exotic species, such as rodents from Africa, poses a\nserious public health threat because of the potential of monkeypox virus\ninfection and other nonindigenous pathogens. Serosurveys of various healthy\nrodents (and nonhuman primates), including _Cricetomys emini_, captured\nwild in Africa, have demonstrated orthopoxvirus antibodies (7). Monkeypox\nvirus also has been isolated from a rope squirrel (_Funisciurus\nanerythrus_) found with skin lesions in the vicinity of monkeypox cases in\nDRC (8). Accordingly, pursuant to 42 CFR 71.32(b), CDC is implementing an\nimmediate embargo on the importation of all rodents from Africa (order\nRodentia). In addition, CDC and the Food and Drug Administration, pursuant\nto 42 CFR 70.2 and 21 CFR 1240.30, are prohibiting the transportation or\noffering for transportation in interstate commerce, or the sale, offering\nfor sale, or offering for any other type of commercial or public\ndistribution, including release into the environment of prairie dogs and\nthe following rodents from Africa: tree squirrels (Heliosciurus sp.), rope\nsquirrels (Funisciurus sp.), dormice (Graphiurus sp.), Gambian giant\npouched rats (Cricetomys sp.), brush-tailed porcupines (Atherurus sp.), and\nstriped mice (Hybomys sp.). States can elect to enact measures to prohibit\nthe importation, sale, distribution, or display of animals that could\nresult in transmission of infectious agents (9,10).\nHealth-care providers, veterinarians, and public health officials who\nsuspect monkeypox in animals or humans should report such cases to their\nstate and local health departments. CDC requests that reports of suspect\ncases from state health departments be directed to the CDC Emergency\nOperations Center, telephone 770-488-7100. Additional information about\nmonkeypox, including an interim case definition, is available at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox> &\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/casedefinition.htm>, respectively.\nReferences\n----------\n1. Landyl ID, Ziegler P, Kima A. A human infection caused by monkeypox\nvirus in Basankusu Territory, Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). Bull\nWHO 1972;46:593-7.\n2. Breman JG. Monkeypox: an emerging infection for humans? In: Scheld WM,\nCraig WA, Hughes JM, eds. Emerging Infections 4. Washington, DC: ASM Press,\n2000:45-76.\n3. Shchelkunov SN, Totmenin AV, Babkin IV, et al. Human monkeypox and\nsmallpox viruses: genomic comparison. FEBS Lett 2001;509:66-70.\n4. Shchelkunov SN, Totmenin AV, Safronov PF, et al. Analysis of the\nmonkeypox genome. Virol 2002;297:172-94.\n5. World Health Organization. Technical Advisory Group on Human Monkeypox:\nreport of a WHO meeting. Geneva, Switzerland, January 11-12, 1999.\n6. Jezek ZM, Scczeniowski KM, Paluku M, Putombo M, Grab B. Human monkeypox:\nclinical features of 282 patients. J Infect Dis 1987;156:293-8.\n7. Hutin YJF, Williams RJ, Malfait P, et al. Outbreak of human monkeypox,\nDemocratic Republic of Congo, 1996-1997. Emerg Infect Dis 2001;7:434--8.\n8. Khodakevich L, Jezek Z, Kinzana K. 1986 Isolation of monkeypox from a\nwild squirrel. Lancet 1986;1:98-9.\n9. State of Wisconsin, Department of Health and Family Services. Emergency\norder. Available at\n<http://www.dhfs.state.wi.us/dph_bcd/monkeypox/Response.htm>.\n10. State of Illinois. Executive order in response to orthopox outbreak.\nAvailable at\n<http://www.idph.state.il.us/pdf/ExecutiveOrder14.pdf>.\nAcknowledgments: see original on web.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: Thu 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: James M. Wilson <IceAxe5@aol.com>\nSource: Newsday.com, Associated Press report, Thu 12 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.newsday.com/news/health/sns-ap-monkeypox-cdc,0,4857917.story?\ncoll=ny-health-headlines>\n\nWisconsin: Suspected case of human-to-human transmission of monkeypox\n-------------------------------------------------\nHealth officials in Wisconsin said on Thu 12 Jun 2003 that a health care\nworker may have contracted monkeypox from a human patient in what would be\nthe first known case of the disease spreading person-to-person in this\ncountry. Wisconsin state epidemiologist Jeff Davis said monkeypox virus\nhadn't yet been confirmed in the worker, but it was suspected and experts\nwere testing tissue specimens.\nThe announcement came a day after U.S. government moved aggressively to\ncontain the first outbreak of monkeypox in the Western Hemisphere by\nprohibiting imports of African rodents, banning the sale of prairie dogs --\nbelieved to have spread the virus to humans -- and recommending smallpox\nshots for people exposed to monkeypox. The government also expanded its\nsearch for infected prairie dogs to 15 states.\nThe smallpox vaccine can prevent monkeypox, an exotic African disease, up\nto 2 weeks after exposure to the virus but is most effective in the first 4\ndays. 'We're optimistic we can deliver the vaccine to these people in time\nto do good,' said Dr. David Fleming, the Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention's deputy director for Public Health and Science.\nAs of Wed 11 Jun 2003, health officials had confirmed a total of 9 human\ncases of the disease -- 4 in Wisconsin, 4 in Indiana, and one in Illinois.\n54 possible cases had been reported -- 25 in Indiana, 17 in Wisconsin, 11\nin Illinois, and one in New Jersey, CDC spokesman Tom Skinner said. No one\nin the United States has died of the disease. Fleming said he is confident\nthe outbreak will be controlled.\n'Monkeypox is a disease that is potentially transmissible from person to\nperson but at a fairly low level,' he said. 'I don't anticipate the same\nkind of problem that we anticipate from SARS.'\nFleming said the smallpox vaccine is 85 percent effective against\nmonkeypox. The smallpox vaccine is widely available because states stocked\nup on it out of fear of bioterrorism. More than 37 000 health workers in\nthe United States have been vaccinated. The CDC said health care workers,\nveterinarians, and family members who have cared for or had close contact\nwith infected people or animals should get vaccinations. The agency also\nwarned veterinarians and doctors to be on the lookout for the symptoms,\nespecially in owners of prairie dogs or exotic rodents from Africa.\nAbout 40 out of every million people given the smallpox vaccine for the\nfirst time will face a life-threatening injury, and one or 2 will die.\nStill, the CDC is recommending vaccinations even for pregnant women,\nchildren, and people with eczema -- for whom the vaccine is usually\ndiscouraged -- who have been exposed to infected prairie dogs. 'Because of\nthe real risk here ... we're recommending a somewhat aggressive approach of\nwho should get the vaccine,' Fleming said.\n[Byline: Daniel Yee]\n--\nJames M Wilson, V, MD\nDivision of Integrated Biodefense\nImaging Science and Information Systems (ISIS) Center\nGeorgetown University Medical Center\nWashington, DC\n<IceAxe5@aol.com>\n[This report of human-to-human transmission of monkeypox virus infection\nshould be regarded with caution until there is laboratory confirmation of\nthe diagnosis. - Mod.CP]\n******\n[4]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: Thomas E. Walton <Thomas.e.walton@usda.gov>\nSource: Official APHIS release [edited]\nSubject: Emergency Management Warning 3: Monkeypox in the United States\n-----------------------------------------------------\nThe Centers for Disease Control posted the following information on their\nMonkeypox webpage regarding the trading of prairie dogs at swap meets.\nInformation on Prairie Dogs with Monkeypox that May Have Been Traded at\nSwap Meets\nFor Immediate Release\nA joint investigation with state and local officials in Illinois, the USDA,\nand CDC is currently in the process of conducting contact tracings from\nPhil's Pocket Pets, Villa Park, Illinois, where prairie dogs infected with\nmonkeypox may have been sold to numerous buyers in 15 states, including IL,\nIN, OH, KY, WI, TX, SC, FL, TN, PA, MS, MA, MI, NJ, NY, since 15 Apr 2003.\nThe Illinois Department of Health is in the process of notifying state\nhealth officials in states that may have received animals from this dealer.\nCDC is recommending that states contact these buyers and inquire about\nrecent illnesses in humans or animals in the 30 days after purchase.\nThe dealer also sold animals at 3 animal swap meets since 15 Apr 2003.\nThese included sales by Phil Mobley (Phil's Pocket Pets) at Lee Watson's\nReptile Show in Schaumburg IL on 20 Apr, 3 May, and 18 May 2003, the\nMidwest reptile show in Indianapolis, IN on 27 Apr and [day missing] May,\nand the All Ohio Reptile Show in Columbus, OH on 19 Apr 2003. In addition,\na dealer from Wisconsin, Scott Knapp of SK Exotics, sold 3 prairie dogs\nacquired from this IL dealer, including one to an unidentified man, at a\nswap meet in Wausau, WI in early to mid May 2003.\nRecords for swap meet sales are not required, and there is no way to\nidentify persons who acquired animals from these dealers at these swap\nmeets. In addition, people at swap meets often handle animals without\npurchasing them. Therefore, broad circulation of this information is\ndesirable to facilitate identification of all possible human infections.\nPersons who purchased ANY animal from one of these dealers are encouraged\nto contact their state health department.\nThe following link is to the Centers for Disease Control's Monkeypox webpage.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/monkeypox/index.htm>\nPlease forward this information to your federal, State, and industry\ncounterparts as necessary.\nIf you have any questions about this situation, please feel free to call\nUSDA, APHIS, VS, Emergency Programs at 800-940-6524, 301-734-8073, or\ne-mail at EMOC@APHIS.USDA.GOV.\n--\nThomas E. Because of\nthe real risk here ... we're recommending a somewhat aggressive approach of\nwho should get the vaccine,' Fleming said. After an\nincubation period of 7 to 17 days, the disease is characterized by the\nonset of a prodrome of fever, headache, backache, and fatigue. Accordingly, pursuant to 42 CFR 71.32(b), CDC is implementing an\nimmediate embargo on the importation of all rodents from Africa (order\nRodentia).
