USA (WI, IL, IN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203943", "date": "2003-06-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX, HUMAN, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (WISCONSIN, ILLINOIS, INDIANA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat, 07 Jun 2003 23:27:03 -0400\nFrom: George Robertson <geo456@comcast.net>\nSource: Associate Press [Edited]\nIllness caused by pet prairie dogs is possibly monkeypox\n-----------------------\nMADISON, Wis. (AP) - A virus related to smallpox that has never been\ndetected in the Western Hemisphere may be the cause of a mysterious\ndisease spreading from pet prairie dogs to people across the upper\nMidwest, health officials said Saturday.\nDr. James Hughes, director of the National Center for Infectious\nDiseases at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said a\ngroup of prairie dogs sold from a suburban Chicago pet distributor\nappears to be infected with the monkeypox virus, a member of the same\nviral family that causes smallpox but is not nearly as deadly.\nMonkeypox has typically been found in West African rain forests,\nHughes said. The death rate among infected humans has ranged from 1\nto 10 percent.\nHughes said although monkeypox is spread primarily through rodents in\nAfrica, scientists haven't ruled out person-to-person transmission.\n'We're in the very early stages of classifying this virus,' Hughes\nsaid. 'We're not certain.'\nSince early May [2003] , 17 possible cases have been reported in\nWisconsin in people as young as 4 and as old as 48. 2 possible cases\nhave been reported in Illinois and one has been reported in Indiana,\nhealth officials from all 3 states said.\nThey appeared to have been exposed to prairie dogs - rodents whose\npopularity as pets has grown in recent years. They reported fever,\ncoughs, rashes and swollen lymph nodes.\nCDC and state health officials are still researching the disease with\nsamples from the infected prairie dogs and humans, but the virus\nappears susceptible to the anti-viral drug Cidofovir, Hughes said. He\nisn't aware of any long-term aftereffects of monkeypox.\nNo one has died or become severely ill in the current outbreak,\nHughes said. But 4 people in Wisconsin had to be hospitalized at\nFroedtert Memorial Lutheran Hospital, hospital spokesman Mark\nMcLaughlin said. 2 remained hospitalized in satisfactory condition\nSaturday.\nAuthorities don't believe bioterrorism was involved. Investigators\nhave traced the origin of the outbreak to a pet distributor in\nVilla Park, Ill. That distributor had a giant Gambian rat, indigenous\nto African countries, that may have infected batches of prairie dogs,\nHughes said.\nSK Exotics, a South Milwaukee pet distributor, bought prairie dogs\nfrom the Villa Park distributor and imported them to Wisconsin.\n2 pet stores, Hoffer TropicLife Pets in Milwaukee and Rainbow Pets in\nShorewood, a Milwaukee suburb, bought some dogs from SK Exotics.\nMore prairie dogs from Villa Park found their way to northern\nWisconsin through a Wausau swap meet, said Dr. Mark Wegner, chief of\nthe Wisconsin Communicable Disease Epidemiology Section.\nWisconsin agriculture officials have taken several emergency steps\nsince word of the outbreak broke earlier this week.\nThe state Department of Health and Family Services issued an\nemergency order Friday banning the sale, importation and display of\nprairie dogs.\nAlso Friday, acting state veterinarian Dr. Robert Ehlenfeldt imposed\nquarantines on SK Exotics, Hoffer TropicLife Pets, Rainbow Pets and\nthe Dorchester home of Tammy Kautzer, who apparently sells animals to\nswap meets, Gilson said.\nThe quarantines prohibit movement of any prairie dogs or mammals that\ncome in contact with them.\n[One of the cases] said she got 2 female prairie dogs from SK Exotics\non 5 May 2003. Neither looked sick at first, she said, but one\neventually began to look tired. [She] said she got sick in mid-May\nwith blisters, coughing and a\n101-degree fever. Hospital staff gave her aspirin, told her it was a\nviral infection and she went home, she said.\nMeanwhile, state and federal investigators are still trying to track\ndown animals sold from the Villa Park distributor. The source of the\nGambian rat is still unknown, they said.\nThe World Health Organization has released facts about the disease:\na. The disease has never before been reported in the Western Hemisphere.\nb. It is usually found in remote villages in Central and West Africa.\nc. Monkeypox is related to the virus that caused smallpox, and smallpox\nvaccinations also gave protection against it.\nd. The death rate among those with monkeypox ranges from 1 to 10\npercent, with the highest rates among young children.\ne. The disease is usually transmitted to people from squirrels and\nprimates through a bite or contact with the animal's blood.\n--\nGeorge A. Robertson\n<geo456@comcast.net>\n[ProMED-mail also thanks the Humanitarian Resource Institute\n<news@humanitarian.net> that submitted a similar news story. - Mod.\nLM]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 7 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org> & H. Larry Penning\n<hlpenning@yahoo.com>\nSource: CDC press release\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/pressrel/r030607.htm>\n\nPublic Health Investigation Uncovers First Outbreak of Human\nMonkeypox Infection in Western Hemisphere\n------------------------------\nPublic health officials from the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention (CDC) and the states of Wisconsin, Illinois and Indiana\nhave reported the first outbreak of human infections with a\nmonkeypox-like virus to be documented in the Western Hemisphere. Thus\nfar, 19 cases have been reported: 17 in Wisconsin, one in Northern\nIllinois, and one in Northern Indiana. All patients who have become\nill reported direct or close contact with ill prairie dogs.\nCDC is advising physicians, veterinarians, and the public to report\ninstances of rash illness associated with exposure to prairie dogs,\nGambian rats and other animals to local and state public health\nauthorities. CDC also has issued interim recommendations for\ninfection control calling for health care personnel attending\nhospitalized patients to follow standard precautions for guarding\nagainst airborne or contact illness. Veterinarians examining or\ntreating sick rodents, rabbits and such exotic pets as prairie dogs\nand Gambian rats are advised to use personal protective equipment,\nincluding gloves, surgical mask or N-95 respirator, and gowns.\nThe prairie dogs were sold by a Milwaukee animal distributor in May\nto two pet shops in the Milwaukee area and during a pet \u0093swap meet\u0094\n(pets for sale or exchange) in northern Wisconsin. The Milwaukee\nanimal distributor obtained prairie dogs and a Gambian giant rat that\nwas ill at the time from a northern Illinois animal distributor.\nInvestigations are underway to trace the source of animals and the\nsubsequent distribution of animals from the Illinois distributor.\nPreliminary information suggests that animals from this distributor\nmay have been sold in several other states.\nHuman monkeypox is a rare, zoonotic, viral disease that occurs\nprimarily in the rain forest countries of Central and West Africa. It\nis a member of the orthopox family of viruses. In humans, infection\nwith monkeypox virus results in a rash illness similar to but less\ninfectious than smallpox. Monkeypox in humans is not usually fatal.\nThe incubation period is about 12 days. Animal species susceptible to\nmonkeypox virus may include non-human primates, rabbits, and some\nrodents.\nScientists at the Marshfield Clinic in Marshfield, Wisconsin,\nrecovered the first viral isolates from a patient and a prairie dog.\nThrough examination with an electron microscope they demonstrated a\npoxvirus.\nPhysicians should consider monkeypox in persons with fever, cough,\nheadache, myalgia, rash, or lymph node enlargement within 3 weeks\nafter contact with prairie dogs or Gambian giant rats. Veterinarians\nexamining sick exotic animal species, especially prairie dogs and\nGambian giant rats, should consider the possibility of monkeypox.\nVeterinarians should also be alert to the development of illness in\nother animal species that may have been housed with ill prairie dogs\nor Gambian giant rats.\nLocal, state, and federal agencies and private institutions that have\nparticipated in this investigation to date have included the\nMarshfield Clinic and Marshfield Laboratories, Froedtert Hospital and\nMedical College of Wisconsin, the City of Milwaukee Health Department\nand at least 10 additional health departments in Wisconsin and\nIllinois, the Wisconsin Division of Public Health, Wisconsin\nDepartment of Agriculture Trade and Consumer Protection and Wisconsin\nState Laboratory of Hygiene, the Illinois Department of Public\nHealth, the Illinois State Department of Agriculture, the Indiana\nState Department of Health, and the US Department of Agriculture.\n<http://research.marshfieldclinic.org/crc/prairiedog.asp> (electron\nmicroscopy images)\nFor additional information about monkeypox, see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol7no3/hutinG1.htm>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As mentioned in the above reports, this is the first identification\nof monkeypox in the Western Hemisphere. In the article by Hutin YJF,\nWilliams RJ, Malfait P, Pebody R. et al, Outbreak of Human Monkeypox,\nDemocratic Republic of Congo, 1996 to 1997. EID Vol. 7, No. 3 May\u0096Jun\n2001, (accessible at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol7no3/hutin.htm#Figure%201>), Table\n2 (Species of animals caught in the wild and monkeypox virus plaque\nreduction neutralization antibody assay results, Katako-Kombe Health\nZone, 23-27 Feb, 1997) shows that 3 out of 19 (15.8 percent) Gambian\nrats (_Cricetomys emini_) tested had evidence of monkeypox infection.\nGiven this, it would not be surprising to learn that the Gambian rat\nmentioned in the above articles was the source of the infection of\nthe prairie dogs. I wonder when and how it arrived on US shores, and\nif it was in the incubation period during transit... or if there has\nbeen an ongoing slow outbreak among these exotic animals for some\ntime that is just coming to notice now that it is spilling over into\nthe human population.\nAs per the newswire report, cases have occurred in individuals ages 4\nthrough 48. It will be very interesting to see the real age\ndistribution of these cases, to see if there is persistent immunity\nfrom earlier smallpox vaccination (pre-1972). It will also be of\ninterest to know the smallpox vaccination status of the cases that\noccurred in individuals born before 1972 when smallpox vaccination\nwas discontinued (a possible natural study on the duration of\nimmunity from earlier smallpox vaccination in the USA). The\ncessation of smallpox vaccination has been associated with an\nobserved increase in monkeypox activity in central Africa (see EID\narticle above and WHO fact sheet information below).\nMonkeypox is a viral disease with a clinical presentation in humans\nsimilar to that seen in the past in smallpox patients. Monkeypox is\nseen as a sporadic disease in parts of Africa. The virus responsible\nfor monkeypox is related to the virus that causes smallpox\n(orthopoxviruses). Vaccination against smallpox gave protection\nagainst monkeypox. Before the eradication of smallpox, vaccination\nwas widely practised and protected against both diseases. However,\nchildren born after 1980 have not been vaccinated against smallpox\nand are likely to be more susceptible to monkeypox than older members\nof the population. The death rate from monkeypox is highest in young\nchildren, reaching about 10 percent.\nMost cases occur in remote villages of Central and West Africa close\nto tropical rainforests where there is frequent contact with infected\nanimals. Monkeypox is usually transmitted to humans from squirrels\nand primates through contact with the animal's blood or through a\nbite.\nAn outbreak of human monkeypox in the Democratic Republic of the\nCongo (DRC) in 1997 was associated with person-to-person\ntransmission; a change from prior limited outbreaks. Previous\nstudies over a twenty-year period had shown that the rate of\ntransmission of monkeypox within households was low, suggesting that\nthe disease had a low potential for transmission from person to\nperson. Outbreaks were generally self-limiting after one or two\nsequential transmissions.\nThe percentage of suspect cases from person-to-person transmission\n(78 percent) was higher in this outbreak than previously reported (30\npercent). This was associated with the clustering of cases in\nhousehold compounds and prolonged chains of transmission from person\nto person;\nThe ending of vaccination programmes against smallpox in the late\n1970s has probably led to an increase in susceptibility to monkeypox\nand could explain the larger size of the most recent outbreak, the\nhigher proportion of patients aged 15 and over, and the spread\nthrough many generations of transmission. (see WHO fact sheet at:\n<http://www.who.int/inf-fs/en/fact161.html>).\nWe await further information on this outbreak. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "Local, state, and federal agencies and private institutions that have\nparticipated in this investigation to date have included the\nMarshfield Clinic and Marshfield Laboratories, Froedtert Hospital and\nMedical College of Wisconsin, the City of Milwaukee Health Department\nand at least 10 additional health departments in Wisconsin and\nIllinois, the Wisconsin Division of Public Health, Wisconsin\nDepartment of Agriculture Trade and Consumer Protection and Wisconsin\nState Laboratory of Hygiene, the Illinois Department of Public\nHealth, the Illinois State Department of Agriculture, the Indiana\nState Department of Health, and the US Department of Agriculture.\n<http://research.marshfieldclinic.org/crc/prairiedog.asp A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Dr. James Hughes, director of the National Center for Infectious\nDiseases at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said a\ngroup of prairie dogs sold from a suburban Chicago pet distributor\nappears to be infected with the monkeypox virus, a member of the same\nviral family that causes smallpox but is not nearly as deadly. -----------------------\nMADISON, Wis. Local\nhealth workers recently reported 170 new cases of suspected\nmonkeypox in the Democratic Republic of Congo, formerly Zaire,\nfrom March through May--the same Katako-Kombe region visited by\nan WHO-organized team earlier this year. The WHO team reported\nin February 92 cases of suspected monkeypox, alarming many medical\nexperts because 73 percent of those cases seemed to be\ntransmitted from human to human; an earlier study in the region\nfound 32 cases in five years, 70 percent of which were\ntransmitted animal to human.\nResearchers say the cases may be\nincreasing because the smallpox vaccine, which is effective\nagainst monkeypox, has not been used since scientists declared\nthe virus eradicated 20 years ago. Additionally, David Heymann\nof the WHO suggests that some of the recent cases may actually be\nchicken pox, which causes similar symptoms to monkeypox.\nHowever, more studies are needed to determine why human-to-human\ntransmission is increasing, and Heymann says the WHO plans to\nsend another team to the region soon.\n-------------------------------------\nImmunization News Service\nSeptember 12, 1997\nThe CDC National Immunization Program (NIP) makes available the\nfollowing information as a public service only. Re: SMALL POX VACCINATION FOR TRAVELERS TO AFRICA ---\nJohn Water's comments (Monkeypox - Zaire [05]) are well taken.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2191513", "headline": "PRO/AH> Monkeypox, threat to humans?", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2191513", "date": "1997-07-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX, THREAT TO HUMANS?\n****************************\n[See Monkeypox - Zaire 970321182605\nMonkeypox - Zaire (02) 970411121901\nMonkeypox - Zaire (09) 970426132523]\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat, 26 Jul 1997 01:58:18 -0700 (PDT)\nFrom: Robert Marshall <marshalr@ohsu.EDU>\nThis was posted in SCIENCE-WEEK a service that distributes synopses of\narticles from newspapers, magazines, as well as journals such as SCIENCE\nand NATURE. The Democratic Republic of Congo is of course the former\ncountry of Zaire, diferrentiated from Republic of the Congo, the DRC's\nneighbor to the west.\nALARM OVER AN OUTBREAK OF HUMAN MONKEYPOX DISEASE\nThe largest and most complex animal viruses are the poxviruses, among them\nsmallpox and a related virus called monkeypox. Smallpox was ostensibly\neradicated completely in 1979. Monkeypox, however, is far from eradicated.\nUntil recently the disease exhibited minor outbreaks, with the incidence\nbeing quickly damped due to the apparent difficulty of human to human\ntransmission. In these outbreaks, the disease was evidently transmitted by\neating the meat of infected monkeys, squirrels, and rats. Now, however,\nduring the last year, there has been a striking outbreak of 92 cases of\nmonkeypox, all within a few villages in the central part of the Democratic\nRepublic of Congo, and the most troubling aspect is the evidence that the\nrate of human to human transmission may have suddenly increased many-fold\nover what it has been in the past.\nPeter Jahrling, a virologist at the U.S. Army Medical Research Institute\n(MD US) says, 'I hate to be accused of pushing the alarmist button, but for\npractical purposes smallpox is back.' And Ali Khan, a medical\nepidemiologist at the U.S. Center for Disease Control and Prevention, who\nrecently visited the area of the Congo in question, says, 'I am personally\nconcerned about what would happen if this disease showed up in a major city.'\nHowever, an argument can be made that the natural immunity of the people of\nthe Congo has been compromised by a high incidence of HIV and the\nvicissitudes of armed conflict in the area. (Science 18 July)\n--\nRobert Marshall\n<marshalr@ohsu.EDU>\n\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Sat, 26 Jul 1997 21:56:34 -0400 (EDT)\nFrom: michaeli@netvision.net.il\nI wish to differ from the position which is traditionally expressed by the\nWHO experts concerning the monkeypox threat to humans. I am not at all sure\nthat the monkeypox virus will never change its adaptation to humans and\nbecome a source of real outbreaks among us. Already in the last episode in\nZaire there were reports of human to human spread. There is agreement that\nin the past when people were vaccinated against smallpox they were also\nprotected against monkeypox. I do not understand why if we have a\nprotective vaccine against monkeypox we should not use it at least in areas\nwhere the disease exists, like in Zaire. WHO is concerned that the ending of\nvaccination programs for smallpox may have led to the seriousness of the\nlatest outbreak.\nThe study revealed that this outbreak represents the largest cluster of\nmonkeypox cases ever reported, and the proportion of patients that were 15\nyears of age or older (27%) was higher than previously reported (8%). Young\nchildren have been most affected in previous outbreaks. These findings\ncontradict previously accepted findings on the nature of the disease.\nThe investigation Studies over a twenty year period have shown that the rate\nof transmission of monkeypox within households was low, suggesting that the\ndisease had a low potential for transmission from person-to-person and that\nan outbreak could not last long after the first patients recovered. However,\nthe recent study has shown that active cases in February 1997 were linked to\ncases that occurred during the preceding 12 month period. The study also\nrevealed the following:\nThe rate of transmission from person-to-person (73%) was higher than\npreviously reported (30%). This was associated with the clustering of cases\nin household compounds and prolonged chains of transmission from\nperson-to-person.\nThe proportion of deaths (3%) was lower than previously reported (10%).\nThe disease Monkeypox disease closely resembles ordinary forms of smallpox.\nThe viruses causing the two diseases are related and vaccination against\nsmallpox also protects against monkeypox. The emergence of monkeypox does\nnot mean that smallpox, which has been eradicated, is re-emerging.\nAll age groups are affected, but children who have not been vaccinated are\nat the highest risk of death, about a 10% case fatality rate. Most cases\noccur in remote villages of Central and West Africa close to tropical\nrainforests where there is frequent contact with infected animals. Monkeypox\nis usually transmitted to humans from squirrels and primates.\nIn the past, an outbreak of monkeypox would not go very far in the village\nor last long because it did not spread extensively after the first patients\nrecovered. However, what concerns WHO is that the present study indicates\nthat monkeypox disease is changing its pattern of infection in humans. This\noutbreak has a much higher rate of person-to-person transmission than seen\nbefore, and spread through many generations of transmission, thus\nmaintaining the outbreak for more than a year.\nConcern for WHO The ending of vaccination programmes against smallpox in the\nlate 1970's has probably led to an increase in susceptibility to monkeypox\nand could explain the larger size of the outbreak, the higher proportion of\npatients aged 15 and over, and the spread through many generations of\ntransmission. The changing nature of monkeypox disease is of concern to WHO.\nIn the past, before the eradication of smallpox in 1980, smallpox\nvaccination was widespread and protected against both smallpox and\nmonkeypox. Since the eradication of smallpox, vaccination programmes have\nbeen discontinued as recommended by WHO. Though monekypox has been shown to\nnot be a threat to smallpox eradication by studies done throughout the\n1980s, WHO is concerned that monkeypox could pose a localized public health\nproblem. WHO will therefore continue to maintain vigilance by strengthening\ndetection systems for monkeypox and completely investigating future\noutbreaks so that the best strategy for prevention and control may be\ndeveloped.\n\nNOTES CONCERNING THIS SERVICE:\nThe Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER) serves as an essential\ninstrument for the rapid and accurate dissemination of\nepidemiological information on cases and outbreaks of diseases\nunder the International Health Regulations, other communicable\ndiseases of public health importance, including the newly\nemerging or re-emerging infections, non-communicable diseases\nand other health problems. The WER is distributed every Friday\nin a bilingual English/French edition. The electronic edition\nis free of charge and can be obtained through FTP: ftp.who.ch,\nuser name should be 'anonymous', password should be your e.mail\naddress. The WER issues are in the subdirectory /pub/wer, or\nWWW: http://www.who.ch/wer/wer_home.htm\nAny queries on subscription to the printed edition should be\naddressed to: World Health Organization, Distribution and\nSales, 20 Avenue Appia, CH-1211 Geneva 27, Fax: (+4122) 791 48\n57\nIssues of the WER are in AdobeTM AcrobatTM portable document\nformat (.pdf). To view the WER, the programme Acrobat Reader\nis required\nSeparate .pdf files exist for each issue of the WER and are\nnamed according to the volume and issue number, for example the\nfile wer7048 contains the WER volume 70, number 48.\nAdditionally, when disease news is published on the World Wide\nWeb, at http://www.who.ch/programmes/emc/news.htm, it is also\ndistributed to all subscribers to this majordomo group\nTo obtain help on using e.mail majordomo discussion group, send\na message to majordomo@who.ch with the word 'help' as the body\nof the message.\n..........................................................mhj\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Most cases\noccur in remote villages of Central and West Africa close to tropical\nrainforests where there is frequent contact with infected animals.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "smallpox", "monkeypox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-04-14 00:00:00", "1980-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "1997-02-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zaire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Appia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2190606", "headline": "PRO/AH> Monkeypox - Zaire (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190606", "date": "1997-04-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "MONKEYPOX - ZAIRE (06)\n======================\nDate: Thu, 17 Apr 97 11:17:47 EST\nFrom: David J. McClain <dr._dave_mcclain@ftdetrck-ccmail.army.mil>\n[see\nMonkeypox - Zaire 970321182605\nMonkeypox - Zaire (02) 970411121901\nMonkeypox - Zaire (03) 970414154537\nMonkeypox - Zaire (04) 970415103327\nMonkeypox - Zaire (05) 970416143852]\n\nThe potential risks or benefit of vaccinia immunization, like any vaccine,\nshould be weighed against a traveller's relative risk of exposure to\nmonkeypox. The recent outbreak indicates that the rate of person-to-person\ntransmission of monkeypox (constituting 70% of cases) is significantly\ngreater than previous reports, probably attributable to a population with\ndeclining vaccinia immunity. Successful vaccinia virus immunization, as\njudged by the presence of a preexisting vaccination scar, affords\napproximately 85% protection against monkeypox.\nIf a traveller to Zaire remains in Kinshasa, I suspect that he/she will be\nmore at risk from stray bullets from the civil war than from poxviruses.\nHowever, if he/she will be involved in the trapping of squirrels (the\nprincipal animal reservoir of the virus) or medical care in the Kasai\nOriental region, I would suggest that vaccination should be given strong\nconsideration. It is correct to point out that vaccination does carry the\nrisk of adverse reactions, as documented by the Centers for Disease Control\nin 1968. However, some of these adverse reactions (e.g., secondary\ninoculation) would be less common among adults who have a measure of residual\nvaccinia immunity and would have a 'secondary or accelerated take'\n(vaccination of infants/toddlers gradually ceased in the U.S. circa 1971-72),\nand who could practice better contact precautions than the toddlers who\nconstituted the majority of primary vaccinees during the 1960's. The\ncontraindications to vaccination should be carefully noted: pregnancy;\naltered immunocompetence, HIV infection, history of eczema or presence of\nother acute, chronic, or exfoliative skin disease. Furthermore, vaccinia\nshould not be administered to persons who have household contacts with any of\nthe aforementioned conditions.\nIn the U.S., requests for Wyeth Dryvax (the remaining licensed vaccinia\nvaccine in this country) should be addressed to the CDC Drug Service D-09,\n1600 Clifton Rd, Atlanta, GA 30333, (404) 639-3670.\nThis experience with Wyeth (Dryvax) and other vaccinia vaccines of similar\nnature indicates that reactions for persons receiving their first smallpox\nvaccination notably included accidental secondary inoculation (of the virus\nto other sites on oneself or to other persons, occurring ~6/10,000\nvaccinations), and generalized vaccinia (viremic dissemination to produce\nskin and mucous membrane lesions away from the primary vaccination site,\n~3/10,000 vaccinations). Serious and life-threatening complications\nincluded: eczema vaccinatum (spread of virus from the vaccination site to\nskin previously affected by eczema or other chronic skin disorder, resulting\nin severe skin inflammation, with a rate of ~30/1 million vaccinations);\npostvaccinial encephalitis (< 9/1 million vaccinations); and vaccinia necrosum\n(progressive tissue necrosis at the inoculation site with spread of the virus\nthroughout the skin and internal organs, occurring < 2/1 million\nvaccinations). The latter complication occurred almost exclusively in\npersons with underlying defects in their immune system.\nThe views, opinions, and/or findings contained herein are those of the author\nand should not be construed as an official Department of the Army position,\npolicy, or decision.\n1. Fine PEM, Jezek Z, Grab B, Dixon J. The transmission potential of\nmonkeypox virus in human populations. Int J Epidemiol. 1988;17(3):643-650.\n4. Khodakevich L, Szczeniowski M, Manbu-ma-Disu, et al. The role of squirrels\nin sustaining monkeypox virus transmission. Trop Geogr Med. 1987;39:115-122.\n5. Lane JM, Ruben FL, Neff JM, Millar JD. The\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said at least 92 cases\noccurred last year in 12 villages in the Katako-Kombe zone of\nKasai-Oriental. Active cases were still being reported in February of this\nyear, the agency said.\nMonkeypox is related to smallpox but cannot mutate into smallpox. Smallpox\nvaccination is usually effective against monkeypox, but vaccination rates\nhave declined since the illness was eradicated in the late 1970s, the CDC\nsaid. Monkeypox is found in wild animals in the African rain forest.\nPrevious cases in Zaire have been linked to tree squirrels. The CDC said\nthat in last year's outbreak the disease may have been transmitted from\nperson to person.\n............................................mhj\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Increased activity of monkeypox was reported in Katako-Kombe health\nzone, Sankuru sub-region, Kasai Oriental during 1996 (see Weekly\nEpidemiological Record No.43, 25 October 1996). Medecins Sans Frontieres\ninvestigated those cases which could be traced in September 1996. Samples\nwere obtained from 11 cases all of which were subsequently confirmed as\nmonkeypox by the WHO Collaborating Centre for Smallpox and other Poxvirus\nInfections at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in\nAtlanta, USA.
